Ingestion of which of the following medication classes is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

 Laboratory value  Result 
Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   5.7 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Magnesium  0.8 mmol/L 
 Creatinine    0.9 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings suggestive of digoxin toxicity including visual disturbance, confusion, and hyperkalemia. Digoxin is used in the treatment of heart failure for its effects on increasing inotropy. The medication inhibits the sodium-potassium ATPase in the membrane of cardiac myocytes, thus increasing the intracellular sodium. This leads to increased activity of the sodium-calcium exchanger, resulting in increased intracellular calcium concentration and improved myocardial contractility.



Digitalis has a narrow therapeutic index, and toxicity can happen acutely or chronically. Acute toxicity more commonly occurs due to over-ingestion, whereas chronic toxicity is secondary to decreased clearance of digoxin by the kidneys. Certain medications (e.g., diuretics, beta blockers, amiodarone) and electrolyte abnormalities including hypokalemia, hypercalcemia and hypomagnesemia also increase the risk of digitalis toxicity.

Patients with digitalis toxicity usually complain of visual abnormalities including yellow-green discoloration (e.g. seeing a yellow hue), diplopia or photophobia. In addition, patients with acute toxicity present several hours following ingestion with gastrointestinal manifestations including nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain, and anorexia, as well as confusion. Chronic toxicity is associated with more severe neurological manifestations including lethargy, altered mental status, and coma.

Several ECG changes, including T-wave changes, short QT interval, and ST depressions, are also commonly seen with digitalis toxicity. The most common electrocardiographic abnormality observed is premature ventricular contractions, although any arrhythmia may occur (e.g., bidirectional ventricular tachycardia, SA and AV nodal blocks). Electrolyte abnormalities are typically seen, with the most common electrolyte abnormality being hyperkalemia--reflective of severe, acute toxicity.

Treatment of digitalis toxicity begins with electrolyte correction (e.g., hyperkalemia, hypomagnesemia) and arrhythmia monitoring. Digoxin-specific antibody antigen-binding fragments (Digifab) must be administered early. Digifab is composed of antibodies that bind directly to digoxin and inhibit its effects. Administration of digifab must take precedence in patients with ECG abnormalities (e.g. heart blocks), hypotension, or hyperkalemia.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.



Option Analysis

✅ Cardiac glycoside:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Beta blocker:
Incorrect: Beta blocker toxicity can lead to hypotension and bradycardia, and metabolic panels typically demonstrate hypoglycemia and hyperkalemia. Beta-blocker overdose is not associated with gastrointestinal manifestations or photophobia. In addition, ECG usually demonstrates bradycardia or heart block.
❌ Calcium channel blocker:
Incorrect: Like beta blockers, calcium channel blockers can also cause hypotension and bradycardia. Calcium channel blocker toxicity is not associated with visual abnormalities.
❌ Salicylate:
Incorrect: Salicylate (e.g. aspirin) toxicity is characterized by mixed respiratory alkalosis and wide anion-gap metabolic acidosis. Early clinical findings include nausea, vomiting, stupor, and tinnitus.
❌ Anticoagulant:
Incorrect: Warfarin toxicity presents with an increased risk of bleeding; it is not associated with gastrointestinal manifestations or visual disturbances.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe left eye pain that started while he was at work. The patient is a radiologist and spends most of the day in a dark room reading films. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. Physical examination of the left eye is shown below. Intraocular pressure is 39 mmHg in the left eye and 18 mmHg in the right eye. Which of the following pharmacologic agents is contraindicated in the treatment of this patient’s condition?

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute left eye pain while in a low light environment. Physical examination demonstrates a moderately dilated pupil with surrounding injection and corneal cloudiness, as well as an elevated intraocular pressure. Together, these findings are consistent with acute closed-angle glaucoma. In this condition, medications that cause mydriasis (e.g. atropine) will worsen the angle closure and further impair aqueous humor outflow.

Treatment options for closed-angle glaucoma include medications that decrease aqueous humor production or increase outflow, as well as surgical management. Medications that decrease aqueous humor production include beta blockers (e.g. timolol), carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide), and alpha agonists (e.g., apraclonidine, brimonidine). Medications that increase aqueous humor outflow include cholinomimetics (e.g. pilocarpine) and prostaglandins (e.g., bimatoprost, latanoprost). If the patient’s disease is advanced or refractory to medical therapy, then laser iridotomy or trabeculoplasty can be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Atropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Timolol:
Incorrect: Timolol is a beta-blocker that is used to treat closed-angle glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor production.
❌ Acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to treat closed-angle glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor production.
❌ Pilocarpine:
Incorrect: Pilocarpine is a cholinomimetic agent that increases aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork and is used in the treatment of acute closed-angle glaucoma.
❌ Latanoprost:
Incorrect: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that increases the outflow of aqueous humor through the uveoscleral pathway. This medication is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. Although latanoprost is not routinely used in treating closed-angle glaucoma, it is also not contraindicated.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the clinic for the first time complaining of excessive fatigue. He moved three months ago and is looking to establish care with a new physician. The patient states that he has felt tired and lethargic for the last 2 weeks. The patient is taking a medication for a “heart condition,” but he is unable to recall the name. He has also been taking acetaminophen daily to help relieve pain in his sore arms, which also started several weeks ago, and laxatives to help with bowel movements, which have slowed recently. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 58/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a slightly bluish hue to his skin. The upper extremities are diffusely tender to palpation. Laboratory studies are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  137 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  97 mEq/L 
 Glucose  97 mEq/L 
 Creatine kinase (CK)  145 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  66 U/L 
 Alanine aminotransferase  77 U/L 

Which of the following medications was this patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, constipation, myalgias) and is most likely taking a medication for atrial fibrillation (as demonstrated by the irregular pulse and history of a “heart condition”). Given the aforementioned, the presenting symptoms are likely due to the side-effects of amiodarone, which can be used for rhythm control in patients with atrial fibrillation.  

Amiodarone has a wide spectrum of side-effects, such as blue discoloration of the skin, pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity (e.g. elevation of AST/ALT), and hypothyroidism. Amiodarone, which is 40% iodine, causes hypothyroidism because the large iodine load can suppress thyroid hormone synthesis via the Wolff-Chaikoff effect. In addition, amiodarone also inhibits the conversion of T4 to T3 in peripheral tissues.    

Thyroid hormones have a significant impact on cellular metabolism, and their deficiency results in dysfunction of normal cells. Thyroxine (T4) deficiency leads to diminished mitochondrial oxidative capacity and abnormal glycogenolysis. This can cause atrophy, destruction of muscle cells, and myopathy. Laboratory testing will reveal an increase in creatine kinase.  




Option Analysis

✅ Amiodarone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pravastatin:
Incorrect: Statins are lipid-lowering drugs that inhibit hepatic cholesterol synthesis. Although statins can cause hepatotoxicity (e.g. elevated liver enzymes) and muscle toxicity (e.g. elevated creatine kinase levels), this patient has other clinical findings that suggest a different medication to be the underlying cause.
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that inhibits the Na+/K+/ATPase found on the outer cell surface of cardiac myocytes. Digoxin is sometimes used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation. However, this patient’s other symptoms suggest a different medication as the cause of this current condition.
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol, a beta blocker, is a drug that primarily blocks B1-receptors in the heart, resulting in decreased heart rate and cardiac contractility. Beta blockers can be used to treat atrial fibrillation, but this patient’s other symptoms suggest a different medication as the cause of his current condition.
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that is used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation. However, it would not cause the symptoms seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old male with a past medical history of Crohn disease treated with infliximab is admitted to the hospital after initiation of therapy for active tuberculosis. On day four of hospitalization, the patient reports worsening pain in the left great toe. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 120/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air.  Physical exam and laboratory findings are demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT)  150 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT)  175 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase   205 U/L 
 
Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the medication likely causing this observed side effect?

choices.text: Conversion to pyrazinoic acid and subsequent lowering of environmental pH
Inhibition of the enzyme arabinosyl transferase
Inhibition of bacterial DNA-dependent RNA synthesis

questions.solution:
This patient was initiated on RIPE therapy (rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol) for treatment of active tuberculosis. He has developed gouty arthritis and evidence of hepatotoxicity, which are consistent with the side effect profile of pyrazinamide.   
The mechanism of action of pyrazinamide is unclear. However, it is known that the drug is converted into pyrazinoic acid inside bacteria and works best at acidic pH levels. Its mechanism of resistance is thought to be due to mutations in pyrazinamidase, which is the enzyme responsible for converting pyrazinamide to pyrazinoic acid. The side effects of pyrazinamide are primarily hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia, which may manifest with symptoms of gout.  



Option Analysis

✅ Conversion to pyrazinoic acid and subsequent lowering of environmental pH:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of the enzyme arabinosyl transferase:
Incorrect: Ethambutol, while a component of RIPE therapy, does not induce hyperuricemia. Its primary side effects are optic neuritis and decreased visual acuity. 
❌ Inhibition of bacterial DNA-dependent RNA synthesis:
Incorrect: Rifampin works by inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase. Its side effect profile includes minor hepatotoxicity and red-orange bodily fluids. 
❌ Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis :
Incorrect: Isoniazid works by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis and only works in tuberculosis, as it needs to be processed by mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase in order to be activated. Its side effects include cytochrome p450 inhibition, hepatotoxicity, drug induced lupus, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia. However, isoniazid would not cause hyperuricemia or gout.
❌ Inhibition of the 30s ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside and is considered a second-line medication for the treatment of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. It is generally avoided as a first-line agent due to its nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider for evaluation of joint pain and stiffness. The symptoms are most prominent in the hands, worse in the morning, and gradually improve with activity. In addition, the patient reports feeling tired in the morning despite getting more than eight-hours of sleep each night. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals mild deformation of the bilateral metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The patient is prescribed a disease modifying anti-rheumatic drug. She is warned about its side effects, which include hepatotoxicity, stomatitis, and pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the prescribed medication?
questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Treatment mainly consists of long-term medications called disease modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), which can be non-biological or biological. Since persistent inflammation in affected joints can cause permanent, irreversible damage, prompt diagnosis and early recognition of active disease are important. DMARDs should be used in all RA patients to maintain control of inflammation and the underlying disease process, with the goal of remission or low disease activity in order to improve disease outcome.  

Most individuals are started on non-biological DMARDs. The most common is methotrexate, a folic acid analog that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase. The enzyme participates in tetrahydrofolate synthesis, so its inhibition reduces DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis. Its use in the treatment of RA is that it inhibits proliferation of the lymphocytes and other cells responsible for inflammation in the joints. Side effects include pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, stomatitis/mouth ulcers, and nephrotoxicity. Moreover, methotrexate can cause folate deficiency, megaloblastic anemia, and myelosuppression.  


Another DMARD is leflunomide, which reversibly inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, preventing pyrimidine synthesis and suppressing T-cell proliferation. Side effects include hypertension, hepatotoxicity, and teratogenicity. There is also hydroxychloroquine, which is considered to be the safest DMARD and can be used in pregnancy. It increases lysosomal pH in antigen-presenting cells and blocks toll-like receptors on dendritic cells. Side effects include eye toxicity, hepatotoxicity, and excessive coloring of the skin.  


There are also biological DMARDs, which suppress portions of the immune system. Abatacept suppresses T-cells, rituximab suppresses B-cells, while others block specific cytokines. Infliximab and adalimumab are two anti-TNF-alpha monoclonal antibodies. Side effects include predisposition to infection, reactivation of latent tuberculosis, and drug-induced lupus.  

Lastly, short-term medications, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and glucocorticoids, can be used to provide analgesia and symptom relief during an acute flare.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of intracellular NF-KB pathway:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids work via this mechanism and, as a result, suppress multiple inflammatory and immune pathways. Side effects include Cushing syndrome, osteoporosis, and hyperglycemia. However, corticosteroids would not cause the side effects described by the physician.
❌ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase:
Incorrect: This answer describes the mechanism of action of fluorouracil. Its side effects include photosensitivity, mucositis, and myelosuppression. However, it would be atypical for fluorouracil to cause hepatotoxicity or pulmonary fibrosis.  
❌ Inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) work by inhibiting the cyclooxygenase enzymes. NSAIDs can cause kidney injury, gastric ulcers, and increased bleeding risk as side effects. However, NSAIDs would not cause the side effects described by the physician.
✅ Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of tumor necrosis factor :
Incorrect: Tumor necrosis factor (TNFɑ) is a cytokine involved in systemic inflammation. Several fusion proteins and monoclonal antibodies have been developed to target TNFɑ. Side-effects include immunosuppression, reactivation of latent tuberculosis, and drug-induced lupus. However, hepatotoxicity, mucositis, and pulmonary fibrosis are generally not part of this medication class’s side-effect profile.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office due to 2 months of episodic jaw pain. She describes sharp shooting, “shock like” pain over the left side of her jaw that typically lasts for a few seconds. She has noticed a few times that the pain has occurred while she was eating dinner, and once while she was brushing her teeth. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on the first line medication for her condition. During her one month follow-up appointment, she states that her symptoms have improved significantly, but she describes feeling some dizziness and instability. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the medication being used by this patient?

choices.text: Inhibition of T-type calcium channels in the thalamus
Increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening
Increasing the duration of chloride channel opening

questions.solution:
This patient has trigeminal neuralgia, a debilitating neuropathic disorder that typically presents with episodic, unilateral, shooting, and “shock like” pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Symptoms are often precipitated by innocuous stimuli (e.g., brushing teeth, shaving, chewing) within the affected trigeminal nerve branch distribution. It has been hypothesized that this occurs due to compression of the trigeminal nerve root by arteries or veins, leading to demyelination in this area; however, the exact pathogenesis is unclear.  

The first line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia is carbamazepine, a neuroleptic medication that works by blocking Na+ channels, thus limiting influx of sodium ions throughout the CNS. Adverse effects of carbamazepine include diplopia, dizziness and ataxia, blood dyscrasias (agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia), liver toxicity, teratogenesis (cleft lip/palate, spina bifida), cytochrome P-450 induction, SIADH, and Steven-Johnson Syndrome.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of T-type calcium channels in the thalamus  :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of ethosuximide, which is used to treat absence seizures. Ethosuximide works by blocking T-type Ca2+ channels in the thalamus. Adverse side effects of ethosuximide include fatigue, GI distress, headaches, itching (and urticaria), and Steven-Johnson syndrome.   
❌ Inhibition of high-voltage calcium channels  :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of gabapentin used in peripheral neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia. Side effects of gabapentin include sedation and ataxia.   
❌ Decreasing the degradation of GABA :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of vigabatrin, which is used for infantile spasms and refractory complex partial seizures in adults. Vigabatrin works by irreversibly inhibiting GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for the degradation of GABA. Its use is now limited, as it carries a black box warning in the United States due to risk of permanent vision damage.   
✅ Inhibition of sodium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of benzodiazepines, which are used as anxiolytics and in surgical procedures. Side effects include sedation, tolerance, dependence, and respiratory depression.  
❌ Increasing the duration of chloride channel opening:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of barbiturates, which are used in anxiety, seizures, insomnia, and induction of anesthesia. Side effects include respiratory, cardiovascular, and CNS depression.   
❌ Decreasing the degradation of acetylcholine :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine, used in Alzheimer's disease. These work by inhibiting the acetylcholinesterase enzyme, which is responsible for acetylcholine degradation.  
❌ Inhibition of the phosphoinositol cascade:
Incorrect: This is thought to be the mechanism of lithium, which is used as a mood stabilizer for bipolar disorder and treats acute manic episodes. Side effects include tremor, hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and teratogenesis.

questions.text: A newborn female is delivered at 30 weeks gestation and presents with expiratory grunting and cyanosis in the neonatal intensive care unit. Her temperature is 37.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 225/min, and respirations are 85/min. Physical examination shows nasal flaring and chest wall retractions. Chest x-ray shows a "bell-shaped chest," a small, uniform right lower lobe infiltrate, and air-bronchograms. Which of the following interventions could have been used to prevent this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette, born at <36 weeks gestation, presents with respiratory distress and chest x-ray findings concerning for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, which is caused by developmental insufficiency of surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs. Antenatal corticosteroid therapy with intramuscular betamethasone is recommended in all pregnant women at 23-34 weeks gestation with increased risk of preterm delivery in the next seven days. When steroids are provided, they improve fetal lung compliance, volume, gas exchange, and surfactant production, and they enhance fetal lung antioxidant enzyme production. In addition, antenatal steroids have been shown to reduce the incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, sepsis, and neonatal mortality by approximately 50 percent.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ribavirin:
Incorrect: Ribavirin is an antiviral agent used to treat respiratory syncytial virus or bronchiolitis. While patients with bronchopulmonary dysplasia are at an increased risk of developing bronchiolitis, ribavirin is not useful in the prevention of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.  
✅ Betamethasone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hepatitis B vaccine  :
Incorrect: The hepatitis B vaccine is a vaccine that prevents hepatitis B. The first dose is recommended within 24 hours of birth, with subsequent admission of additional doses during childhood. This patient’s presentation aligns with a different diagnosis.  
❌ Surface-active lipoprotein complex:
Incorrect: Exogenous surfactant (e.g. Survanta), or perfluorocarbon aerosol, can be used for the treatment of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). However, there is no role for administration of these compounds as a preventative strategy.
❌ Influenza vaccine  :
Incorrect: The influenza vaccines protect against influenza. A new version of the vaccine is developed twice a year, as the influenza virus rapidly changes, and it is administered to children > 6 months old.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2 month history of chest pain and cough. The patient reports he frequently wakes up coughing with a substernal burning sensation.  He has no significant past medical history but reports a 20-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is  37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows faint end-expiratory wheezing bilaterally on chest auscultation. Initial troponin level is normal, and an ECG reveals normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication used to treat this patient's condition?

choices.text: Inhibition of the parietal cell H+/K+ ATP pump
Beta-2 agonist of bronchial smooth muscle cells
Stimulates angiogenesis and the formation of granulation tissue
Na+ channel blockade and inhibition of depolarization
Dilatation of large coronary arteries and arterioles

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a several month history of burning chest discomfort, cough, and wheezing with a normal ECG and troponin level consistent with a diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Appropriate treatment for GERD includes lifestyle modification and medications that reduce acid suppression, such as proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). GERD is caused by transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, which results in the reflux of stomach contents into the esophagus.  

Clinically, GERD presents with burning in the throat or chest, regurgitation, or an acidic taste in the mouth while lying flat or lying flat immediately after eating. GERD can also present with atypical features including chronic cough, globus sensation (the feeling that something is stuck in the throat), wheezing, or nausea. Risk factors for GERD include obesity, hiatal hernias, and pregnancy, since these conditions tend to increase intrathoracic pressure and regurgitation of stomach contents. Smoking is also a notable risk factor, due to its ability to relax the lower esophageal sphincter.  

If left untreated, GERD can progress to esophageal stricture, Barrett esophagus and ultimately esophageal cancer. Untreated GERD can also result in chronic laryngitis, asthmatic exacerbations, and wheezing due to reflux of stomach contents into the large airways.    

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of the parietal cell H+/K+ ATP pump:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Beta-2 agonist of bronchial smooth muscle cells:
Incorrect: Beta agonist therapy with albuterol is the primary treatment for patients with asthma. The wheezing in this patient is secondary to GERD, as stomach contents reflux into the airway causing bronchospasm.   
❌ Stimulates angiogenesis and the formation of granulation tissue:
Incorrect: This answer describes the mechanism of sucralfate, a medication often used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. Sucralfate can be used to treat GERD; however, given its short duration of effect, it is used for acute symptomatic relief as opposed to long-term therapy.  
❌ Na+ channel blockade and inhibition of depolarization:
Incorrect: Like sucralfate, viscous lidocaine can help provide symptomatic relief to patients with acute exacerbations of GERD, but it does not provide long-term symptomatic relief.   
❌ Dilatation of large coronary arteries and arterioles:
Incorrect: Nitrates are commonly used to treat anginal type chest pain. Coronary artery disease and GERD can often be difficult to distinguish clinically. The patient in this vignette does not have a history of diaphoresis or an exertional component to reproducing the chest pain. In addition, the ECG and troponin levels are normal, making acute coronary syndrome unlikely.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate diffuse skin blistering. Around four days ago, the patient developed fevers, muscle aches, and malaise. He attributed the symptoms to a viral infection. This morning, he noticed multiple bullae on his skin all over his body. He has also experienced ulceration and desquamation of the lips and oropharynx, which has made it difficult for him to eat or drink. The patient has recently been prescribed trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for cellulitis and acetaminophen to treat an ankle sprain. He has been taking lamotrigine for seizure prevention for the past ten years. He received a tetanus booster shot one week ago. Temperature is 39.2°C (103°F), blood pressure is 153/82 mmHg, and pulse is 93/min. Physical examination reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Painful lesions are present over 5% of the patient’s skin. Which of the following factors most likely precipitated this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with painful skin bullae and ulcerations, along with desquamation of mucosal surfaces. Given 5% of the patient’s skin is involved, his presentation is most consistent with Stevens-Johnsons syndrome (SJS). Of note, if skin involvement had exceeded 30%, the patient would have been diagnosed with toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

SJS and TEN are characterized by painful vesicles/bullae on the skin along with ulceration of mucosal membranes. SJS/TEN most often results from an adverse reaction to medications. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is most commonly implicated in SJS/TEN and is the underlying cause of around 26% of cases in the United States. Other medications that may trigger SJS/TEN include ꞵ-lactam antibiotics, anticonvulsants (e.g., lamotrigine, phenytoin), allopurinol, and NSAIDs.

Less commonly, SJS/TEN can arise after infection by pathogens such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae and herpes simplex virus.  



Option Analysis

❌ Tetanus booster vaccination  :
Incorrect: Vaccinations are a rare and highly debatable cause of Stevens-Johnsons syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Instead, medications cause almost 90% of SJS/TEN cases in the United States.  
✅ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole use  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Acetaminophen use  :
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is an unlikely cause of SJS/TEN and is not commonly implicated. Another component of this patient’s history places him at greater risk for developing SJS/TEN.  
❌ Recent upper respiratory tract infection  :
Incorrect: Patients with SJS/TEN may have a prodromal phase characterized by non-specific, flu-like symptoms such as fever, malaise, cough, and myalgias. However, viral infections are a rare and poorly-documented cause of SJS/TEN.  
❌ Lamotrigine use  :
Incorrect: Lamotrigine is an anticonvulsant associated with around 9% of SJS/TEN cases. Most cases of SJS/TEN occur during the first eight weeks of therapy, making it unlikely for this patient who has been taking it for many years. Additionally, antibiotics (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, ꞵ-lactams) are more commonly implicated as the underlying cause of SJS/TEN.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the office because of worsening acne.  She has had multiple bouts of acne affecting her shoulders, chest, and face. The acne was treated with topical benzoyl peroxide and oral antibiotics with a slight improvement over the past three months. She is concerned because recently, her acneiform lesions have increased in size, transforming into nodules, thereby affecting her appearance. The patient immigrated from India with her family ten years ago. Past medical history is noncontributory. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and uses condoms consistently. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. After performing a complete physical examination, a decision to start oral isotretinoin is made. Which of the following laboratory investigations should be performed before initiating this drug?
questions.solution:
Acne vulgaris, an inflammatory skin condition with multifactorial etiology (follicular hyperkeratinization, increased sebum production, and infection by Cutibacterium acnes), can present with inflammatory papules, pustules, or nodules. Treatment options depend on the severity and include retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, antibiotics, and isotretinoin.  

This patient suffering from nodulocystic acne needs treatment with oral isotretinoin. Isotretinoin is a known teratogen, and pregnancy should be actively ruled out by measuring serum or urine beta-hCG levels twice. Sexually active patients should be started on two different types of contraception before its initiation. Other standard pretreatment tests include a liver function test and lipid panel (serum triglyceride and cholesterol levels).  

Isotretinoin, a retinoid, is a last resort for treating severe (nodulocystic acne with scarring) or unresponsive acne vulgaris. It acts by shrinking the sebaceous glands (reducing sebum production), inhibiting the growth of Cutibacterium acnes, and preventing the formation of comedones. It has several adverse effects, including teratogenicity (craniofacial, cardiac, thymic, and central nervous system malformations), cheilitis, xerosis, conjunctivitis, pruritus, photosensitivity, and hypertriglyceridemia. It can also cause decreased bone mineral density, hepatotoxicity, fatigue, and lethargy.

Option Analysis

❌ Pulmonary function test:
Incorrect: Baseline pulmonary function testing is recommended before the initiation of amiodarone as it has a high tendency to cause pulmonary toxicity. Isotretinoin is not reported to affect the lung parenchyma. 
✅ Urine ꞵ-hCG test :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Eye examination:
Incorrect: Hydroxychloroquine, a medication used to treat systemic lupus erythematosus, is typically a well-tolerated and safe drug; however, there is a small risk of retinal toxicity in patients with prolonged use. Therefore, patients should have a baseline ophthalmologic evaluation with periodic assessment.   
❌ International normalized ratio:
Incorrect: A baseline international normalized ratio (INR) should be obtained prior to warfarin administration to monitor its activity and prevent unwanted bleeding diathesis. Isotretinoin does not affect INR level.  
❌ Purified protein derivative test:
Incorrect: A purified protein derivative (PPD) test is recommended before administering immunosuppressive drugs like infliximab, an anti-TNF agent, to prevent the reactivation of underlying latent tuberculosis. Isotretinoin does not compromise the immune system.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious near the doorway of a smoke-filled house. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 120/minute, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows generalized flushing of the skin as well as black soot near the nares and mouth. There is no evidence of any burns or trauma. Capillary refill time is 5 seconds. Supplemental oxygen is administered. Laboratory results are shown below. Hydroxocobalamin is provided for medical management. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Increases the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI
Increase the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase

questions.solution:
This patient has flushed skin and soot in the oropharynx (which is suggestive of smoke inhalation injury) after being in a house fire. Hydrogen cyanide and carbon monoxide are two major products of combustion. As a result, cyanide toxicity should be considered in patients with a history of smoke inhalation, carbonaceous material in the oropharynx, neurologic dysfunction, metabolic acidosis, and elevated serum lactate level.

For patients in whom clinical suspicion is high, airway protection should be achieved and high-flow supplemental oxygen should be given. Hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate can be used for treatment. Both medications avidly bind cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted via urine.

Alternatively, a combination of sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate may be used for the induction of methemoglobinemia. When cyanide binds methemoglobin (formed by nitrites), a relatively less toxic cyanmethemoglobin is formed. It then combines with thiosulfate to form thiocyanate, which is renally excreted.

In case of dermal exposure to cyanide, clothing should be removed, and the exposed skin should be cleaned to prevent further absorption. Similarly, in cases wherein cyanide is ingested, decontamination with activated charcoal should be performed.

  

Option Analysis

❌ Opiate receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: Naloxone works via opiate receptor antagonism; it is used as an antidote for opioid overdose, which can result in altered mental status and respiratory depression. This patient is unconscious but her respiratory rate is elevated. Furthermore, this patient was in a house fire and has an anion gap metabolic acidosis, which is more suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Chelation of serum iron:
Incorrect: Deferoxamine is a chelating agent that can be used to treat iron poisoning, which can present acutely with abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Although iron poisoning can cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis, this patient’s history of being in a house fire is more suggestive of cyanide or carbon monoxide toxicity.  
❌ Increases the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for acetaminophen intoxication; it works by increasing the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI. Affected individuals can present with nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Severe intoxication can cause liver damage and transaminitis. However, acetaminophen toxicity would not account for the patient’s flushed skin. Moreover, this patient’s history of being in a house fire is more suggestive of cyanide or carbon monoxide toxicity.  
❌ Increase the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase  :
Incorrect: Methylene blue is an antidote for methemoglobinemia, which works by increasing the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase. Methemoglobinemia usually occurs secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents (e.g., dapsone, nitrates, topical and local anesthetics). Exposure to a house fire is more likely to cause cyanide or carbon monoxide poisoning.  
✅ Forms cyanocobalamin for urinary excretion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to sudden onset of a spinning sensation accompanied by instability and nausea for the past 2 days. She had a cold one week ago that resolved spontaneously. Since the symptoms have started, she has vomited 3 times. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 25 years. The patient appears to be in distress. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals mild hearing loss in the right ear. The patient is given a medication that is known to affect the vestibular end-organ receptors to control her symptoms. The physician advises the patient to not use the medication while driving because drowsiness is a potential side effect. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication prescribed by the physician?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with acute onset of vertigo, hearing loss, nausea, and vomiting following a viral infection, most likely has the peripheral vertigo associated with vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis. Vestibular neuritis refers to the post-viral inflammatory disorder of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII).  

Regardless of the etiology, vertigo is treated symptomatically, and disease-specific treatment is added depending on the etiology. Symptomatic treatment of vertigo includes 3 drug classes: antihistamines (e.g., meclizine, diphenhydramine), antiemetics (e.g., ondansetron, metoclopramide), and benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam, lorazepam). The latter is rarely used due to the serious side effect profile. Antihistamines are the drugs of choice in most cases.  

Antihistamines work by blocking the H1 histamine receptor, which suppresses vestibular end-organ receptors and inhibits activation of central cholinergic pathways. Antihistamines can cause drowsiness, and patients should be advised to not use this medication prior to activities that require focus.  

Option Analysis

❌ Antagonism of 5-HT3 serotonin receptors:
Incorrect: 5-HT3 antagonism is the mechanism of action of ondansetron, a powerful central-acting antiemetic. This medication blocks serotonin receptors both centrally, in the chemoreceptor trigger zone, and peripherally, on vagal nerve terminals. It is used to prevent vomiting in post-operative patients and in patients undergoing cancer chemotherapy. It can be used to treat nausea in the setting of vertigo, but it would not cause drowsiness.  
❌ Antagonism of D2 dopamine receptors:
Incorrect: Antagonism of D2 dopamine receptors is the mechanism of action of metoclopramide. This medication blocks dopamine receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone of the CNS. It enhances motility and gastric emptying, and it increases lower esophageal sphincter tone. Uses include diabetic and postoperative gastroparesis, antiemetic, and persistent GERD. It can be used to treat nausea in the setting of vertigo, but it would not cause drowsiness.  
✅ Antagonism of H1 histamine receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Antagonism of the neurokinin-1 Receptor :
Incorrect: Aprepitant prevents vomiting by inhibiting the substance P/neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptor in the area postrema. This medication is mainly used for chemotherapy-induced emesis. It is not used as a treatment for vertigo.  
❌ Antagonism of muscarinic receptors  :
Incorrect: Antagonism of muscarinic receptors is the mechanism of action of scopolamine. This medication is used for prevention of nausea/vomiting associated with motion sickness, recovery from anesthesia and surgery. However, it is not used as a treatment for vertigo.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because her body started shaking violently 10 minutes ago at a nearby bus stop. She was waiting for a bus with her partner when she suddenly fell down and started having stiffening and jerking movements involving all four extremities. Past medical history is significant for epilepsy, for which the patient takes lamotrigine. The partner notes the patient recently started taking a combined oral contraceptive pill. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 112/min and regular, respirations are 22/min and blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg. The patient is unable to respond to vocal commands. Physical examination shows ongoing symmetric rhythmic jerking of the limbs. After appropriate supportive treatment, the patient is given a drug intramuscularly, after which the jerking subsides. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug administered?

choices.text: Sodium channel blocker at excitatory neuron
Increase in the frequency of chloride channel opening

questions.solution:
Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE) is a medical emergency and is defined as continuous seizure activity for ≥5 minutes or ≥2 discrete seizures between which there is incomplete recovery of consciousness. This patient recently started taking combined oral contraceptive pills, which are known to increase the metabolism and clearance of lamotrigine; this metabolic alteration results in decreased serum levels of the antiepileptic medication, with subsequent increased risk of seizure recurrence.  

 The general management of GCSE involves the following:  

  1.  Assessment and supportive treatment: This step includes a rapid neurological examination, in addition to supportive therapy in order to maintain their airway, breathing, and circulation.  
  2.  Initial pharmacologic therapy with a benzodiazepine: Benzodiazepines are potent GABAA receptor analogues which facilitate the uptake of chloride ions by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening. This influx results in hyperpolarization of the neuron, aborting excess neuronal activity. In cases where intravenous (IV) access is available, IV lorazepam or diazepam is used. In cases where IV access is unavailable, intramuscular midazolam is typically used, as shown here.  
  3.  Urgent therapy with a nonbenzodiazepine anti-epileptic drug (e.g. fosphenytoin): In addition to a benzodiazepine, a nonbenzodiazepine is typically given IV for long-term control, in order to prevent seizure recurrence.  

Option Analysis

❌ Thalamic T-type Ca+2 channel blocker:
Incorrect: Ethosuximide blocks T-type Ca+2 channels found in the thalamus. It is used as a first-line agent for the management of absence seizure, which is a type of generalized seizure usually observed in children that presents with brief blank staring spells multiple times a day.  
❌ Synaptic vesicle protein (SV2A) receptor blocker:
Incorrect: Levetiracetam binds to synaptic vesicle protein (SV2A) to alter its fusion with the membrane, thereby inhibiting the release of neurotransmitters. It is widely used in the management of idiopathic generalized epilepsy, but it is not indicated for status epilepticus.  
❌ Inhibition of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) breakdown:
Incorrect: Valproate and vigabatrin are antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) known to inhibit the breakdown of GABA by blocking GABA transaminase, an enzyme present in inhibitory neurons. Valproate also inhibits Na+ channels at excitatory neurons. These drugs are not effective in emergency management of status epilepticus.  
❌ Sodium channel blocker at excitatory neuron:
Incorrect: Phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, topiramate and valproate inhibit excessive neuronal discharges that can precipitate a seizure by blocking voltage-gated Na+ channel on the membrane of presynaptic excitatory neurons. Phenytoin or valproate can be tried if benzodiazepine therapy fails, but none of these medications should be used as a first-line agent in status epilepticus.  
✅ Increase in the frequency of chloride channel opening:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent due to sudden-onset shortness of breath and wheezing. The patient has been taking aspirin for several days due to a sprained ankle. On review of systems, she endorses a persistent sensation of nasal congestion over the past several months. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination reveals a girl in moderate distress. Nasal examination reveals bilateral, gray, glistening mucoid masses. The loss of which of the following mediators after aspirin ingestion is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath and wheezing in the setting of aspirin use and bilateral nasal polyps. She most likely has aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD).  

AERD is caused by abnormalities in the arachidonic acid biosynthesis pathway. Arachidonic acid can be metabolized via two different pathways: the 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO) pathway and the cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) pathway. The 5-LO pathway produces leukotrienes from arachidonic acid (e.g., leukotrienes C4, D4, and E4), whereas the COX-1 pathway produces prostacyclins, prostaglandins, and thromboxanes from arachidonic acid. Normally, COX-1 pathway products counterbalance the effects of leukotrienes. Most notably, prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) has potent bronchodilatory properties and can inhibit eosinophils and mast cells, thereby preventing leukotriene release.  

Patients with AERD have an underlying defect resulting in constitutive overproduction of leukotrienes and concomitant underproduction of COX-1 pathway products. When these patients take aspirin or an NSAID, there is further COX-1 inhibition and leukotriene overproduction. Patients classically present with asthma, chronic/recurrent rhinosinusitis, and nasal polyps, which can manifest with nasal congestion and reduced olfactory sensation.  



Option Analysis

✅ PGE2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ PGI2:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin I2 (PGI2) is synthesized from arachidonic acid by the enzyme COX-1. PGI2 is involved in vasodilation and inhibits platelet aggregation. It is not, however, involved in suppressing the production of leukotrienes. 
❌ PGF2:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin F2 (PGF2) is synthesized from arachidonic acid by the enzyme COX-1. PGF2 is involved in smooth muscle contraction. It is not, however, involved in suppressing production of leukotrienes.
❌ TXA2:
Incorrect: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is involved in vasodilation and promotes platelet aggregation. It is not, however, involved in suppressing production of leukotrienes.
❌ PGH2:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin H2 (PGH2) is synthesized from arachidonic acid by the enzyme COX-1. It is not, however, involved in suppressing production of leukotrienes.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the office because of nocturnal back pain that is not relieved by rest or change in position. He was diagnosed with localized prostate cancer 6 months ago and was started on long-acting gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist after refusal of surgical prostatectomy and radiation therapy. Further evaluation confirms the diagnosis of metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma. A decision to start flutamide is made to help relieve pain and decrease the size of the tumor. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this agent?
questions.solution:
Treatment options for metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma include chemotherapy, radiotherapy (external beam radiation therapy or brachytherapy) and hormonal therapy. Flutamide is a competitive testosterone receptor inhibitor that blocks the androgen binding to its receptor, preventing the stimulatory effect of androgen on the tumor (tumor flare) and helping in reducing its size.  

Since prostate cancer is androgen-dependent and most androgens in men are made in Leydig cells of the testes, the initial treatment targets on reducing systemic androgens either medically by GnRH analogues or surgically by orchiectomy. GnRH analogues (leuprolide), when administered continuously, inhibits pituitary gonadotrophs, leading to downregulation of hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. The result is reduced luteinizing hormone (LH) and, consequently, decreased testicular androgen production. A transient rise in androgens can be observed after its initiation; therefore, anti-androgen (flutamide) is prescribed concurrently to prevent tumor flare.  

Localized prostate cancer is treated with surgical resection (prostatectomy) along with radiotherapy and hormonal therapy. Erectile dysfunction, urinary incontinence, urethral stricture and inguinal hernia are some of the complications of prostatectomy.  

Option Analysis

❌ 5-α reductase inhibitor:
Incorrect: 5-α reductase inhibitors block the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone and reduce the size of the prostate gland. It is one of the primary treatment options for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Examples include finasteride and dutasteride.
✅ Testosterone receptor inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phosphodiesterase-5-inhibitor:
Incorrect: Phosphodiesterase-5-inhibitors (PDE5) belong to a class of drugs that cause prolonged nitric oxide-induced vasodilation by decreasing the breakdown of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (GMP). These medications are commonly used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. They have no role in the management of metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma.
❌ Aromatase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Aromatase inhibitors (e.g. anastrozole) act by blocking the conversion of androgens to estrogens. These agents are used in post-menopausal women with breast carcinoma. They do not decrease androgen levels and have no activity against prostate adenocarcinoma.
❌ Tyrosine kinase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Tyrosine kinase inhibitor (e.g. imatinib) inhibits the action of bcr-abl tyrosine kinase, which is an abnormal gene product of the Philadelphia chromosome in chronic myeloid leukemia. It has no role in the treatment of prostate adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of Parkinson disease comes to the office for follow-up. He was diagnosed 6 years ago, and since then, the condition has been well-controlled with levodopa/carbidopa. However, for the past 2 months, the patient reports increased difficulty ambulating, loss of balance and increased rigidity. He is compliant with the treatment and describes fluctuations in the symptoms that improve after he takes the medication. Physical examination reveals diffuse cogwheel rigidity and difficulty walking. A decision is made to add a medication that will descrease the symptoms between levodopa/carbidopa doses. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Inhibits the conversion of L-dopa to dopamine in the periphery
Inhibits the peripheral degradation of L-DOPA to 3-O-methyldopa (3‑OMD) by inhibiting catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) enzyme
Inhibits the conversion of dopamine to 3,4-Dihydroxyphenylacetic acid (DOPAC)
Increases dopamine release and inhibits its reuptake

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with motor fluctuations and dyskinesia, a common complication of levodopa therapy that is seen in many patients with advancing Parkinson disease (PD). Motor fluctuations refer to the alterations between periods of positive response to levodopa ("on") and periods marked by reappearance of parkinsonian symptoms ("off"), when levodopa’s effects wear off. The etiology of motor fluctuations is considered to be multifactorial and relates to progressive degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons, and the ability of the presynaptic neurons to store and release dopamine. Conversely, dyskinesia is caused by overstimulation of dopamine receptors.  

Entacapone works by inhibiting the peripheral degradation of L-DOPA to 3-O-methyldopa (3‑OMD) by inhibiting catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) enzyme. It is used in conjunction with levodopa, thereby increasing the plasma levels of levodopa and increasing dopaminergic stimulation. Tolcapone has the same mechanism of action but works both in the periphery and the central nervous system. These treatments are used to decrease the “off” symptoms of patients with PD on levodopa therapy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibits the conversion of L-dopa to dopamine in the periphery:
Incorrect: This answer describes the mechanism of carbidopa, which works by inhibiting DOPA decarboxylase enzyme. Carbidopa also helps to reduce the side effects of peripheral L-DOPA conversion into dopamine, such as nausea and vomiting. The patient is already taking carbidopa.
✅ Inhibits the peripheral degradation of L-DOPA to 3-O-methyldopa (3‑OMD) by inhibiting catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) enzyme:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibits the conversion of dopamine to 3,4-Dihydroxyphenylacetic acid (DOPAC) :
Incorrect: This answer describes the mechanism of selegiline, which works by inhibiting monoamine oxidase B enzyme (MAO-B). Selegiline is a primary treatment for Parkinson disease, but it is not specifically used to decrease the “off” time of levodopa therapy.
❌ Directly activates dopamine receptors:
Incorrect: This answer describes the mechanism of dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine, pramipexole and ropinirole. These medications are not used to decrease the “off” time of levodopa therapy.
❌ Increases dopamine release and inhibits its reuptake:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of amantadine. Amantadine is used as a primary treatment for Parkinson disease, but it is not specifically used to decrease the “off” time of levodopa therapy.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain and nausea. The patient has been experiencing a flare of his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and took more than his usual dose of medications to help with his symptoms. His past medical history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, and a thirty pack-year smoking history.  His temperature is 37.1C (98.78F), pulse is 120/minute, respirations are 20/minute, and blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. On initial assessment, the patient appears irritated and agitated. On physical examination, the patient has noted tremors in the bilateral upper extremities and audible wheezing. The patient begins seizing and is immediately provided intravenous lorazepam. Initial laboratory findings are demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

 Glucose  210 mg/dL 
 Sodium   140 mEq/L 
 Potassium  2.5 mEq/L 
 Calcium   11 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with nausea, vomiting, hyperglycemia and hypokalemia following a presumed overdose of a medication used to treat symptoms associated with a COPD flare. Together, these findings are consistent with theophylline toxicity. Theophylline is a bronchodilator that is not frequently used due to its narrow therapeutic index and ease of potential overdose.

Therapeutic index (TI) refers to the ratio of the dose of a given medication that produces a toxic effect to the dose of the same medication that produces a therapeutic effect. TI is calculated using the following formula:

TI=TD50/ED50

TD: the toxic dose of a drug for 50% of the population  
ED: the minimum effective dose for 50% of the population

The range between ED and TD varies amongst medications, and those with higher a TI are associated with safer profiles (as these medications have a very high toxic dose and low therapeutic dose, while a range of doses can produce therapeutic effects). Medications with a lower TI are associated with increased toxicity, as a slight change in plasma levels may lead to toxicity due to the small difference in toxic and therapeutic doses. Medications with this low value are known as having a narrow therapeutic index.

Patients taking medications with narrow TI require close monitoring to avoid increases in serum levels, to avoid severe adverse effects. Examples of medications with a narrow therapeutic index include theophylline, digoxin, flecainide, phenytoin, lithium, cyclosporine and warfarin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Theophylline toxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lithium toxicity:
Incorrect: Lithium toxicity, another medication with a narrow therapeutic index, is characterized by tremor, seizures, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. However, this patient most likely developed a toxicity after using a medication for COPD.
❌ Beta blocker toxicity:
Incorrect: Beta blockers toxicity is associated with hyperglycemia, rather than hypoglycemia. Additional findings include bradycardia and heart block.
❌ Calcium channel blocker toxicity:
Incorrect: Calcium channel blockers (CCB) are not associated with hypercalcemia or hypokalemia. Seizures are also not typically observed with CCB toxicity.
❌ Digitalis toxicity:
Incorrect: Digitalis toxicity is characterized by nausea, vomiting, and neurological abnormalities (e.g. confusion). However, hyperkalemia is observed, not hypokalemia. Additionally, this medication is used in the treatment of heart failure and rate control for atrial fibrillation--not COPD.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after her mother found her unresponsive on the bathroom floor with an empty pill bottle next to her. She has a history of severe depression, and her mother reports she stopped using her antidepressants several days ago. The patient’s pulse is 40/minute, respirations are 20/minute, and blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. The patient is intubated and sedated. On physical examination, wheezes are appreciated over the bilateral lung fields. Serum glucose level is 45 mg/dL. Ingestion of which of the following medication classes is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is suggestive of a suicide attempt, and the findings of hypotension, bradycardia, wheezing and hypoglycemia suggest beta-blocker overdose.

Beta-blockers inhibit epinephrine from binding to beta-adrenergic receptors in the heart and peripheral tissues. Overdose with beta-blockers typically presents with bradycardia, heart block, and hypotension. Additionally, certain beta-blockers can cross the blood-brain barrier (e.g. propranolol) and exert toxic effects in the central nervous system (e.g. seizures). Beta blockade in the bronchioles can lead to bronchospasm and wheezing, as seen in this patient. Finally, beta blockers also inhibit glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, resulting in hypoglycemia.





Treatment of beta blocker toxicity aims to mitigate the effects of arrhythmias, seizures, and cardiac arrest. Glucagon is the primary pharmacologic treatment for beta blockers toxicity, as it increases serum glucose levels and exerts both positive inotropic and chronotropic effects on the heart. In addition, patients who present early in their clinical course may receive activated charcoal or undergo gastrointestinal decontamination with gastric lavage.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

Option Analysis

✅ Beta-blocker:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Calcium-channel blocker:
Incorrect: Calcium-channel blocker toxicity is associated with hypotension and bradycardia, as in this patient. However, it is not associated with hypoglycemia or wheezing. 
❌ Tricyclic antidepressant:
Incorrect: TCA toxicity is associated with hypotension, seizures, and fatal arrhythmias. The presence of wheezing and hypoglycemia suggests beta-blocker toxicity, rather than TCA toxicity.
❌ Anticholinergic:
Incorrect: Anticholinergic toxicity (e.g. atropine) is associated with hypertension, tachycardia, skin flushing, and hyperthermia.
❌ Cardiac glycoside:
Incorrect: Digitalis toxicity can lead to nausea and vomiting, confusion, and electrolyte abnormalities (e.g. hyperkalemia). However, it is not associated with hypoglycemia or wheezing.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinician by his parents due to easy fatigability and growth delay. They recently immigrated to the United States. The mother did not receive any prenatal care in her home country. The child was born at term by a normal vaginal delivery. He is at the 30th percentile for length and below the 10th percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing is obtained and the patient is diagnosed with β-thalassemia major. The patient is given the appropriate treatment and his condition dramatically improves. Which of the following is a likely long-term complication resulting from this treatment?
questions.solution:
The patient was recently diagnosed with β-thalassemia major and now requires chronic blood transfusions in order to prevent complications and increase survival. Transfusions are a necessity for this condition; however, without the appropriate supportive treatment, iron overload from these transfusions can lead to secondary hemochromatosis.   

Hemochromatosis can either be caused by a hereditary autosomal recessive C282Y or H63D mutation on the HFE gene (chromosome 6) or due to chronic blood transfusions. Iron overload results in iron deposition within various organs, leading to cellular damage via the formation of oxygen free radicals. The classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation in hemochromatosis is often called "bronze diabetes." Iron deposition in the pituitary gland can cause secondary hypogonadism or hypothyroidism. Hypogonadism in men presents with low testosterone and libido, and in women with amenorrhea. The hypogonadism can eventually lead to decreased bone density.  



Option Analysis

❌ Chronic pancreatitis  :
Incorrect: Chronic pancreatitis can be caused by chronic alcohol use. Iron overload, as seen in patients with excessive transfusions due to β-thalassemia major, can damage the pancreas and lead to type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, the condition seems to selectively damage the beta cells responsible for insulin and spares other parts of the pancreas.
❌ Parkinsonism:
Incorrect: Parkinsonism and extrapyramidal symptoms can be seen with Wilson disease, a condition characterized by copper overload due to a genetic defect leading to reduced copper excretion. In contrast, this patient is at risk of iron overload due to the frequent blood transfusions needed to manage his β-thalassemia major. Iron overload can cause generalized cognitive impairment from deposition in the central nervous system, but not specifically Parkinsonism.
❌ Pigment gallstones:
Incorrect: Bilirubin (pigment) gallstones and biliary tract inflammation in beta-thalassemia patients arise secondary to high red blood cell turnover and hemolytic anemia. However, pigmented gallstones are not directly caused by chronic blood transfusions.
✅ Hypogonadism:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Skeletal changes:
Incorrect: Skeletal changes are commonly seen in severe forms of thalassemia (e.g., thalassemia major, many cases of thalassemia intermedia). It is caused secondary to ineffective erythropoiesis, which induces extramedullary hematopoiesis.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of excessive fatigue for the last several weeks. The patient gave birth to her first child 7 months ago; the pregnancy and vaginal delivery were uneventful. She breastfed for the first 6 months. The patient noted that after delivery, she was constantly worried about the wellbeing of her child. She states that she had trouble sleeping, anxiety, and diminished concentration; these symptoms resolved after 2 weeks. She has recently gained 12-lb in the last 5 weeks and experienced constipation, which is well-managed with an oral laxative. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 58/min, and blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg. Heart and lung sounds are normal. There is mild non-pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory studies reveal the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  137 mEq/L 
 Potassium  4.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  99 mEq/L 
 Glucose  97 mEq/L 
 Hemoglobin  12.6 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  38% 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with peripartum onset

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, weight gain, non-pitting edema) within a year of delivery, making postpartum thyroiditis the likely diagnosis. Postpartum thyroiditis can occur up to 1 year following delivery and is considered to be a variant of chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto thyroiditis). Oftentimes, affected women develop antithyroid peroxidase antibodies early in pregnancy. Clinical presentations can vary greatly; patients may develop transient hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism, or even hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism. Since this condition is linked closely with Hashimoto thyroiditis, the biopsy results would also be similar. On histology, there would be lymphocytic infiltrate with occasional germinal center formation. In women with symptomatic thyroiditis, replacement T4 (levothyroxine) can be given to alleviate symptoms.  



Option Analysis

✅ Postpartum thyroid inflammation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pituitary ischemic necrosis:
Incorrect: During pregnancy, the pituitary gland increases in size, which makes it particularly vulnerable to hypotensive states, such as during severe postpartum hemorrhages. During these hypotensive episodes, the pituitary lacks sufficient blood supply and can undergo ischemia and necrosis (Sheehan syndrome). This patient lacks the history consistent with severe postpartum hemorrhage, such as requiring blood transfusions after delivery. Additionally, since Sheehan syndrome results in panhypopituitarism, prolactin secretion would be decreased, resulting in an impaired ability to breastfeed, which is not seen in this patient. 
❌ Major depressive disorder with peripartum onset :
Incorrect: While this patient initially had signs of depression (e.g., trouble sleeping, diminished concentration), these resolved after 2 weeks, which makes it more consistent with postpartum blues. Symptoms of major depressive disorder with peripartum onset can often overlap with those of hypothyroidism. Therefore, if this patient still has depressive symptoms, then thyroid function should be evaluated, as it is a reversible cause of depression.
❌ Peripartum cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Peripartum cardiomyopathy can occur within 6 months following delivery, and patients most commonly present with cough, dyspnea, and orthopnea. Lower extremity edema may also be seen, but unlike this patient, a 3rd heart sound may be heard along with crackles in the lungs. 
❌ Primary adrenal insufficiency :
Incorrect: Primary adrenal insufficiency may also present with fatigue, but it typically demonstrates altered serum chemistry, such as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, due to lack of aldosterone, and hypoglycemia, due to lack of cortisol. 
❌ Iron deficiency anemia:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) can present with fatigue, lethargy, and pallor. This patient’s normal hemoglobin makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of intermittent muscle weakness that began around three months ago. He reports having episodes of “seeing-double” and having difficulty chewing that occur in the evening and resolve the next morning. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he intermittently uses an albuterol inhaler. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 65/min and blood pressure is 122/71 mmHg. During the physical examination, the patient is asked to look upwards toward the ceiling for 60 seconds. This maneuver elicits bilateral diplopia. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. Workup is sent to confirm the diagnosis, and the patient is started on the first-line medication for his condition. Which of the following is a likely side-effect from overdose of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient has oculobulbar muscle weakness that worsens after prolonged activity and improves with rest, which is most consistent with myasthenia gravis (MG). Patients with MG develop auto-antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine (ACh) receptors. These antibodies can block and destroy the receptors.

First-line therapy consists of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine, pyridostigmine). These drugs prevent acetylcholinesterase from degrading ACh, which increases ACh concentration at the neuromuscular junction and subsequently counteracts the effects of ACh receptor antibodies.

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors can cause adverse effects related to nicotinic and muscarinic overstimulation, the two receptors for ACh. Side effects include muscular weakness and fasciculations, bradycardia, diaphoresis, hypersalivation, and miosis. The side-effects can be managed by using an antimuscarinic agent (e.g. scopolamine).

Immunosuppressive drugs (e.g. steroids), intravenous immunoglobulin therapy, and plasmapheresis can also be used in the treatment of severe MG by reducing serum auto-antibody levels. Lastly, many patients with MG undergo thymectomy (surgical removal of the thymus), which can improve symptoms even if the patient has no issues with the thymus itself.  





Option Analysis

❌ Pupillary dilation:
Incorrect: Pupillary dilation, also termed mydriasis, is a side effect of anticholinergic medications (e.g., atropine, oxybutynin, and scopolamine). Additional side-effects include increased body temperature, dry and flushed skin, urinary retention, and altered mental status. However, the patient in this vignette has oculobulbar muscle weakness that worsens with use, which raises concerns for MG. Anticholinergic drugs are not used in the treatment of this condition.
✅ Muscle fasciculations:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Elevated bleeding risk:
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis can be used to treat MG by removing auto-antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors from the patient’s bloodstream. The procedure can also deplete coagulation factors and increase bleeding risk. However, plasmapheresis is not the first-line treatment option for MG.
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Urinary retention is a side effect of anticholinergic medications. Additional side-effects associated with this medication class include increased body temperature, dry and flushed skin, cycloplegia/mydriasis, and altered mental status. However, the patient in this vignette has oculobulbar muscle weakness that worsens with use, which raises concern for myasthenia gravis. Anticholinergic drugs are not used in the treatment of this condition.
❌ Increased muscle breakdown:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids, such as prednisone and methylprednisolone, can be administered to treat MG. The medication can increase the rate of muscle breakdown. However, corticosteroids are generally not used as the first-line treatment option. Instead, they are used in patients who remain symptomatic after treatment with a cholinomimetic agent.

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a well-child check. The patient was born at 32-weeks gestational age and shortly afterward was diagnosed with bronchopulmonary dysplasia, which resulted in an admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. Since discharge from the hospital, the patient has been meeting developmental milestones and has been otherwise healthy. During this visit, the pediatrician recommends administration of a medication that has demonstrated efficacy in preventing severe cases of bronchiolitis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Antagonization of antigenic site A on the F protein
Inhibition of viral synthesis of guanine nucleotides

questions.solution:
Palivizumab is a monoclonal antibody that works via antagonization of antigenic site A on the F protein of the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). RSV is a paramyxovirus that can cause bronchiolitis in patients less than 2-years-old. The condition is characterized by upper airway disease (e.g., cough, runny nose) followed by lower airway involvement (e.g., wheezing, rales) several days later, and it is a generally benign condition. However, children with poor lung development, prematurity, or cardiac conditions are at risk of developing severe disease from bronchiolitis, which may result in mechanical ventilation.

Normally, RSV utilizes its F protein to fuse and enter host cells. However, administration of palivizumab mitigates this effect, resulting in milder or absent disease. Palivizumab is used only in select cases and can be administered to premature and high-risk infants. More specifically, palivizumab can be administered if one or more of the following criteria are met:

 1. Born at 35-weeks of gestation or less and is less than 6-months-old of age at onset of the RSV season.  
2. Less than 2-years-old and requiring treatment for bronchopulmonary dysplasia within the last 6 months.  
3. Less than 2-years-old and has a history notable for congenital heart disease.

Option Analysis

✅ Antagonization of antigenic site A on the F protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activation of ꞵ2-receptors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of albuterol. The medication can be used to treat asthma. However, albuterol and other bronchodilators are neither effective in preventing bronchiolitis nor in treating symptoms associated with the condition.
❌ Reversible inhibition of 30S ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: Antibiotics, such as aminoglycosides and tetracyclines, reversibly inhibit the 30S ribosomal subunit of bacterial cells. These medications can be used to treat bacterial infections. However, they would not help prevent bronchiolitis, which is predominantly caused by viruses.
❌ Inhibition of neuraminidase:
Incorrect: Medications such as oseltamivir and zanamivir work by inhibiting viral neuraminidase. They are for influenza prophylaxis and treatment. However, these medications would not be effective in providing prophylaxis against bronchiolitis, which is most frequently caused by the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).
❌ Inhibition of viral synthesis of guanine nucleotides:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of ribavirin, which is used to treat hepatitis C infection. However, the medication would not be effective in preventing or treating bronchiolitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by local paramedics. She was rescued from inside a burning building and had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure en route to the hospital. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder and multiple suicide attempts. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/minute, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg.  Oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals flushing of the skin. She is able to localize pain and respond to commands. There is no evidence of any burns or trauma. Laboratory results are shown below. 100% FIO2 is applied to the patient via non-rebreather. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this practice?

choices.text: Increase the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase
Competition with carbon monoxide to oxygenate tissues
Increases the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status and seizures after being rescued from a building fire. Laboratory testing reveals an anion gap metabolic acidosis and elevated carboxyhemoglobin level. She is most likely suffering from carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.

CO is an odorless and tasteless gas that avidly binds hemoglobin with an affinity approximately 250 times that of oxygen. Thus CO displaces oxygen and impairs oxygen delivery to tissue, resulting in hypoxia.

Treatment involves removing the exposure source, maintaining a patent airway, and providing ventilation assistance if necessary. Administration of 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather face mask (or endotracheal tube) provides oxygen to help displace CO from hemoglobin and decreases the half-life of CO (from 5 hours to 2 hours). Hyperbaric oxygen should be administered in cases of severe CO toxicity (CO level >25%, loss of consciousness, pH <7.1, and/or concern for end-organ ischemia) or in cases wherein the patient fails to improve after receiving face mask administered oxygen.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.   

Option Analysis

❌ Increase the activity of NADH-methemoglobin reductase:
Incorrect: Methylene blue is an antidote for methemoglobinemia, which usually occurs secondary to exposure to oxidizing agents (e.g., dapsone, nitrates, topical and local anesthetics). Affected patients present with cyanosis and bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes.
