In contrast, this patient has elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels, which is more suggestive of carbon monoxide poisoning.  
❌ Forms cyanocobalamin for urinary excretion:
Incorrect: Hydroxocobalamin is an antidote for cyanide poisoning. Although building fires may lead to cyanide poisoning, this patient’s elevated carboxyhemoglobin level is more suggestive of carbon monoxide poisoning.  
❌ Sodium channel blockade:
Incorrect: Phenytoin is an anti-seizure medication which works via sodium channel blockade. Patients with carbon monoxide poisoning may develop seizures, but the first step in management is to start oxygen therapy. Phenytoin therapy is generally not indicated in patients with carbon monoxide poisoning whose seizures are self-limited.  
✅ Competition with carbon monoxide to oxygenate tissues:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increases the concentration of glutathione available for the conjugation of NAPQI  :
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for acetaminophen intoxication. Affected individuals can present with nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Severe intoxication can cause liver damage and transaminitis. However, acetaminophen toxicity would not account for the patient’s flushed skin or elevated carboxyhemoglobin. Moreover, this patient’s history of being in a building fire is more suggestive of cyanide or carbon monoxide toxicity.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parent due to concern that the patient is struggling in school. The patient’s teacher has noticed that there are times when the patient seems distracted and does not respond to his name. The patient was born at term via a normal vaginal delivery, and he has reached all developmental milestones. An electroencephalogram shows generalized spike-wave discharges of 4 Hz with abrupt onset and termination. Further laboratory tests and imaging show no abnormalities. The clinician prescribes the most appropriate treatment for the patient’s condition. This medication works by which of the following mechanisms of action?

choices.text: Increasing the release of catecholamines into the synaptic cleft
Increasing the duration of Cl− channel opening

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old child is having episodes of staring into space and not responding when being called by his name, which is impacting his performance at school. He is most likely suffering from absence seizures, which is a type of generalized seizure.  

Childhood absence epilepsy is one of the most common forms of generalized epilepsy syndromes in the pediatric population. An absence seizure is characterized by episodes of sudden impairment of consciousness, without loss of body tone or postictal confusion. Ictal signs include staring, oral automatisms, and eye involvement; however, not all three signs must be present. Absence seizures can be provoked by hyperventilation and corresponds with typical 2.5-5 Hz spike-wave activity on EEG. The seizures are often subtle, and thus they can go unnoticed for prolonged periods or be confused with conditions such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The first-line treatment is ethosuximide, which works by blocking T-type Ca2+ channels in the thalamus.  



Option Analysis

❌ Increasing the release of catecholamines into the synaptic cleft:
Incorrect: Increasing the release of catecholamines in the synaptic cleft is the mechanism of methylphenidate, a medication used for the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, not for the treatment of absence seizures.   
✅ Blocking T-type Ca2+ channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibiting high voltage-activated Ca2+ channels:
Incorrect: Inhibiting high voltage-activated Ca2+ channels is the mechanism of gabapentin, a GABA analog that is used mainly to treat peripheral neuropathy and postherpetic neuralgia. It is not indicated in the treatment of absence seizures.  
❌ Inhibiting GABA breakdown:
Incorrect: Inhibiting GABA breakdown is the mechanism of vigabatrin, which is used for partial (focal) seizures. It is not indicated for the treatment of absence seizures.   
❌ Increasing the duration of Cl− channel opening:
Incorrect: Increasing the duration of Cl− channel opening is the mechanism of barbiturates. These medications can be used as a sedative agent for anxiety, seizures, insomnia, and induction of anesthesia. However, they are not commonly used, due to a high side effect profile. They are not indicated for the treatment of absence seizures.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chest discomfort and shortness of breath that started two hours ago while watching television. Past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. During the past 10 years, the patient has had similar episodes of chest pain, which resolved with rest. The patient’s pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 134/86 mmHg. The patient appears to be in distress and is diaphoretic. Physical examination shows normal heart sounds with no murmurs or gallops on auscultation. An ECG is obtained (see image below). Treatment is administered, and the patient suddenly reports feeling faint and loses consciousness. Which of the following medications is most likely the cause of the patient’s worsened condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons
questions.solution:
Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) should be considered in any patient with chest discomfort, shortness of breath, or other suggestive symptoms, especially given this patient's risk factors of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s known history of similar pain episodes that resolve with rest (consistent with stable angina) raises clinical suspicion that these present symptoms, which have persisted despite rest, represent myocardial infarction (MI). The ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, confirming the diagnosis of ST-elevation MI (STEMI). The involvement of these inferior leads indicates an inferior wall infarction, involving the right coronary artery. The next best step is to obtain right-sides leads (mirror position) to assess possible infarction of the right ventricle.  

Since right ventricular function is highly preload-dependent, treatment with nitrates can further decrease right-sided cardiac output, leading to hypotension and cardiogenic shock. Other drugs that can negatively affect the preload (opioids) or cardiac contractility and heart rate (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers) are also relatively contraindicated, particularly in patients who are hemodynamically unstable.  




Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: All patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome should be given aspirin unless previously taken. Potential contraindications include a history of an anaphylactic reaction. The patient has no history of an anaphylactic reaction.   
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: Clopidogrel is a platelet P2Y12 receptor blocker that is used in acute myocardial infarction (AMI) together with aspirin. Hypotension is not a known complication of clopidogrel.   
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits epoxide reductase enzyme which impedes γ-carboxylation of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors and has no role in the treatment of AMI. Hypotension is not a side effect of warfarin.   
✅ Nitrates:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Dopamine:
Incorrect: Dopamine is an inotropic agent used during right ventricular MI when fluid resuscitation is insufficient. It causes vasoconstriction and elevation of blood pressure, not hypotension.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency room due to progressive difficulty breathing through the nose, excess nasal drainage, and difficulty smelling. Past medical history is notable for asthma, well-managed with an albuterol inhaler. The patient cannot think of any possible triggers but notes that the symptoms started soon after she sustained an ankle sprain two weeks ago. The injury has caused considerable pain, and she has been taking aspirin daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the lungs reveals occasional wheezing. Multiple polyps are noted in the bilateral nasal cavities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with progressive breathing difficulties, excess drainage from the nose, and difficulty smelling. These symptoms started after she began taking aspirin for an ankle sprain. Given these factors, the patient most likely has an aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD).   

AERD arises since aspirin and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) work by inhibiting cyclooxygenase. This inhibition, in turn, shunts the arachidonic acid metabolic pathway towards leukotriene production. Increased leukotriene production leads to submucosal edema and breathing difficulties.  

Patients with AERD may present with nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin sensitivity. This combination of symptoms is termed the Samter triad. In this patient's case, the history of nasal drainage and smelling difficulty are likely due to the nasal polyps.



Option Analysis

❌ Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:
Incorrect: Nasopharyngeal angiofibromas are benign but locally aggressive tumors of the nasal mucosa composed of large blood vessels and fibrous tissues. They often present with profuse epistaxis, unilateral complaints of nasal obstruction, and trouble breathing. They are most commonly seen in adolescent males. This patient’s presentation does not correlate with a nasopharynx angiofibroma. 
❌ Moderate asthma:
Incorrect: Moderate asthma can present with dyspnea, chest tightness, and persistent cough. Patients may also have increased respiratory rate, tachycardia, and wheezing audible throughout exhalation. Although this patient has been diagnosed with asthma, her presentation correlates more with symptom exacerbation due to a medication side-effect than disease progression. 
✅ Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chronic rhinitis:
Incorrect: Chronic rhinitis is characterized by long-term irritation and inflammation of the mucous membrane of the nasal cavity. Patients typically present with sneezing, runny nose, and postnasal drip. Bacteria, viruses, and allergens can trigger inflammation. However, this patient's symptoms developed after she began taking aspirin, which is more consistent with the presentation of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease. 
❌ Status asthmaticus:
Incorrect: Status asthmaticus describes a severe asthma exacerbation refractory to bronchodilator therapy. Patients present with severe dyspnea, accessory muscle use, and absence of lung sounds. In contrast, the patient in this vignette lacks such findings.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office because of intermittent knee pain for three months. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is associated with swelling at the knee following strenuous exertion. The pain is not associated with fever, rash or malaise. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin and metformin. BMI is 35.3 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a small effusion, tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the left knee. A plain x-ray of the left knee joint shows narrowing of the joint space with osteophytes. The patient is advised to follow a weight loss, supervised exercise program, and treatment with diclofenac is initiated to help relieve the associated knee pain. Which of the following steps in the pathway below will be inhibited by the medication used to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis of the knee. The patient is started on diclofenac, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAIDs), which inhibits cyclooxygenase via the arachidonic acid pathway.  

During inflammation, cleavage of membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2, leads to the formation of arachidonic acid–a substrate for cyclooxygenase (COX). Cyclooxygenase exists in two isoforms: COX-1 and COX-2. COX-1 remains constitutively active, whereas COX-2 serves as an inducible enzyme. Arachidonic acid gets converted by these enzymes into prostaglandins and leukotrienes.  

NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin and nonselective NSAIDs) inhibit cyclooxygenase isoforms (COX-1 and COX-2);  thereby, decreasing prostaglandin and thromboxane synthesis. Decreased production of prostaglandins results in a reduced inflammatory response.



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Cleavage of membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2 leads to the formation of arachidonic acid, which gets converted into prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Phospholipase A2, is inhibited by corticosteroids.  
✅ B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ C:
Incorrect: The enzyme that facilitates this conversion-step is lipoxygenase. Zileuton is a selective lipoxygenase inhibitor and prevents the formation of leukotrienes. It is effective in the management of exercise-induced asthma by decreasing airway inflammation. 
❌ D:
Incorrect: Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. These agents are used in the treatment of chronic asthma prophylaxis.
❌ E:
Incorrect: Colchicine exerts its anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting polymerization of beta tubulin into microtubules; thereby, preventing migration and activation of neutrophils.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of intractable vomiting and lethargy. The patient’s parent reports that the family was on vacation for the past six days. Three days ago, the patient developed a headache, cough, coryza, sore throat and a temperature of 39.2°C (102.6°F). The parent reports that the patient was given multiple medications to bring down his fever. The fever resolved yesterday, but the patient has become increasingly lethargic and began having non-bilious, non-bloody emesis one day prior to presentation. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min and blood pressure is 95/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows a lethargic child who is minimally reactive. Abdominal examination reveals mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following medications is the most likely etiology of this patient’s current condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  14.5 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  8000/mm3 
 Platelet count    180,000/mm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   0.6 g/dL 
 BUN  10 mg/dL 
 Bilirubin   
 Total   0.8 mg/dL 
 Direct  0.2 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT  405 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT  417 U/L 
 Ammonia  94 mcg/dL 
 Coagulation studies
 Prothrombin time  19 sec 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time  45 sec
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vomiting, lethargy, hepatomegaly and laboratory evidence of hepatic injury after taking over-the-counter medications for a presumed viral infection. Together, these findings are suspicious for Reye syndrome secondary to aspirin administration.   

Reye syndrome is caused by aspirin metabolites that inhibit hepatic mitochondrial enzymes, thereby decreasing beta-oxidation in the liver. This manifests clinically with nausea, vomiting, encephalopathy and hepatomegaly. Laboratory derangements include abnormal hepatic aminotransferases, coagulation profile (prolonged PT and PTT) and hyperammonemia. Histologically, the liver may demonstrate microvesicular steatosis, which is characterized by small intracytoplasmic liposomes within hepatocytes that do not distort the hepatocyte nucleus. Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children except in the case of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is the antipyretic/analgesic of choice in children with viral infections. Its use is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.
✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Celecoxib:
Incorrect: Celecoxib is a cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitor, which can be used as an anti-inflammatory agent in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It does not have antipyretic effects and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.
❌ Cetirizine:
Incorrect: Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine that is typically used in the management of seasonal allergies.  It does not have an antipyretic effect and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.   
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is a second-generation antihistamine that is typically used in the management of allergic reactions. It does not have an antipyretic effect and is not associated with the development of Reye syndrome.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents to the office for a follow-up visit. Five years ago, the patient was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease, secondary to adult polycystic kidney disease. The patient is currently on dialysis. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. In an attempt to prevent bone destruction, the patient is started on a medication that binds to and activates a G-protein-coupled membrane receptor. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?  

Laboratory Value
Result
Serum parathyroid hormone
400 pg/mL
Serum calcium
8.1 mg/dL
Serum phosphorus
5.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic renal disease is started on cinacalcet to prevent further bone damage. Patients with chronic renal disease usually develop secondary hyperparathyroidism as a result of hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and decreased production of calcitriol in the kidneys. Elevated levels of parathyroid hormone then increase bone resorption and destruction, leading to renal osteodystrophy.  

Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent that decreases parathyroid hormone levels by binding to and activating calcium sensing receptors (CaSR). CaSR is a G-protein coupled receptor found on chief cells within the parathyroid gland that regulates parathyroid hormone (PTH) release. Activation of CaSR leads to suppression of PTH synthesis and release.  

In addition to preventing bone destruction, cinacalcet is also indicated to prevent calciphylaxis (calcium accumulation in blood vessels and soft tissues) in patients with chronic renal disease. Furthermore, patients with primary hyperparathyroidism who are not fit for surgical treatment can also be given cinacalcet.  

Common side effects of cinacalcet include nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. Some patients also develop diarrhea and decreased appetite. One dangerous adverse side effect is hypocalcemia secondary to PTH suppression.  

Option Analysis

✅ Suppressing parathyroid hormone release.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increasing gastrointestinal absorption of calcium  :
Incorrect: Calcitriol (vitamin D analog) is frequently used in patients with chronic kidney disease to prevent bone loss. Calcitriol increases the absorption of calcium and phosphorus from the gastrointestinal tract; however, the vitamin D receptor is an intracellular receptor as opposed to a membrane receptor.  
❌ Decreasing gastrointestinal absorption of phosphorus:
Incorrect: Sevelamer is a non-absorbable resin that binds to and inhibits the absorption of phosphorus in the gastrointestinal tract. Sevelamer is used frequently in chronic kidney disease to treat hyperphosphatemia. The medication does not act on G-protein-coupled membrane receptors.  
❌ Inhibiting osteoclasts resorption of bone:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates attach to hydroxyapatite in the bone, thereby inhibiting the action of osteoclasts and preventing bone resorption. The medication has also been shown to induce osteoclast apoptosis.  
❌ Reducing renal calcium excretion  :
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are sometimes used to decrease renal calcium excretion. Thiazides block sodium reabsorption at the luminal surface in the distal convoluted tubules, thereby enhancing the activity of calcium sodium exchangers in the basolateral membrane and increasing calcium reabsorption.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the nephrologist for a routine visit. Two-years ago, the patient was diagnosed with end-stage renal disease. The patient currently receives dialysis twice per week. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and the patient is not taking any medications. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 70/minute, and blood pressure is 125/82 mmHg. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. The patient is prescribed sevelamer. Which of the following best describes the effects of this medication?

Laboratory Value
Result
Sodium
138 mEq/L
Potassium
4 mEq/L
Chloride
96 mEq/L
Calcium
8.6 mg/dL
Phosphate
6 mg/dL

choices.text: Increases gastrointestinal absorption of vitamin D

questions.solution:
This patient has end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and laboratory testing is notable for hyperphosphatemia. Patients with ESRD may develop hyperphosphatemia secondary to the loss of the kidney’s ability to excrete phosphate. Hyperphosphatemia in patients with ESRD has a significant influence on the quality of life and mortality rate. The condition can be treated with sevelamer.  

Sevelamer is a nonabsorbable resin that is taken orally and binds phosphate in the gastrointestinal tract to prevent its absorption. It is frequently used to control hyperphosphatemia secondary to end-stage renal disease. The use of sevelamer in patients with ESRD has been shown to decrease serum phosphate, decrease bone resorption and tissue calcification, and improve overall mortality. Moreover, unlike older phosphate binding resins (e.g. calcium carbonate), sevelamer does not contain calcium and is therefore not associated with hypercalcemia.  

Side effects of sevelamer include gastrointestinal upset (e.g., nausea, vomiting), bloating, abdominal pain, and diarrhea or constipation. The medication interferes with fat absorption due to its ability to bind bile salts and may cause fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits gastrointestinal absorption of phosphate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increases renal excretion of phosphate:
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) helps increase phosphate excretion via the kidneys. Sevelamer inhibits absorption of phosphate from the gastrointestinal tract, but does not interfere with renal phosphate excretion.  
❌ Increases gastrointestinal absorption of calcium:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal absorption of calcium is mainly mediated by vitamin D. Sevelamer has no direct effects on calcium absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.  
❌ Increases gastrointestinal absorption of vitamin D  :
Incorrect: Sevelamer may attach to bile salts within the gastrointestinal lumen and interfere with fat absorption. These changes may decrease the absorption of fat soluble vitamins (e.g., vitamin K, vitamin D).  
❌ Suppresses parathyroid hormone release  :
Incorrect: Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent that is usually given to patients with end-stage renal disease to help protect the bones. Cinacalcet prevents the synthesis and release of parathyroid hormone. In contrast, sevelamer has no direct influence on parathyroid hormone release.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents with her parents for a follow-up appointment. Past medical history is notable for Turner syndrome. Last year, the patient was seen due to concerns of short stature and was started on a medication to promote height growth. The patient consumes a well-balanced diet and is physically active. Vitals are within normal limits. The physical examination shows the patient has a webbed neck, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and swelling of the lower extremities. The patient’s height is in the 30th percentile and weight is in the 40th percentile. The patient’s height was in the 12th percentile last year. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. The patient’s HbA1C was normal last year. Which of the following most likely accounts for this change?
 
Laboratory Value
Result
Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL
Hematocrit
42%
Leukocyte count  
4800/mm3   
Platelet count  
300,000/mm3   
HbA1C  
6.7%

choices.text: Blockage of pancreatic ducts with viscous secretions

questions.solution:
This patient has Turner syndrome and presents with an elevated hemoglobin A1C. This laboratory finding is due to elevated blood glucose levels, likely arising as a complication of growth hormone therapy used to treat short stature in patients with Turner syndrome.

Growth hormone (GH) is an anabolic hormone that exerts its physiological effects via two mechanisms. First, GH binds and activates GH receptors found in various tissues (e.g., bones, muscles, adipocytes). Second, GH stimulates hepatocytes to produce insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), which also promotes growth and development.

Both GH and IGF-1 affect almost every tissue in the body and enhance their growth. Their most notable growth promoting effects are in the bones and cartilage. In patients whose growth plates are not yet fused, GH therapy leads to enhanced growth velocity and final height.

In addition to promoting growth, GH plays a major role in affecting peripheral tissue metabolism. These effects are mainly mediated by IGF-1 and include increased protein synthesis, increased amino acid uptake, decreased protein catabolism, and increased fat metabolism. GH also decreases insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues and promotes hepatic gluconeogenesis, thereby resulting in hyperglycemia.

Recombinant human GH (HGH) is indicated in the treatment of short stature in Turner syndrome. Moreover, it is used in patients with growth hormone deficiency, Prader-Willi syndrome, idiopathic short stature, and children with chronic kidney failure.

Adverse effects are mainly due to the increased metabolism and growth. They include diabetes mellitus, arthralgias, hypertension, and heart failure.  

Option Analysis

❌ Autoimmune destruction of the pancreas:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the pathophysiology of type I diabetes mellitus. Although patients with Turner syndrome have an increased incidence of type I diabetes mellitus, this patient’s interval increase in HbA1C is more likely due to the side effects of growth hormone therapy.  
✅ Medication side effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blockage of pancreatic ducts with viscous secretions:
Incorrect: Patients with cystic fibrosis produce viscous secretions that can lead to pancreatic ductal obstruction and subsequent pancreatic insufficiency. However, this patient does not have a history of cystic fibrosis.  
❌ Amyloid deposition in the pancreas:
Incorrect: Amyloid deposition in the pancreas is one of the hallmarks of type II diabetes mellitus. In this condition, amyloid polypeptide deposition in the islets of Langerhans results in β-cell dysfunction. Patients with Turner syndrome have an increased incidence of type II diabetes mellitus; however, this is seen in older age (e.g. age 40). Furthermore, this patient’s glucose intolerance developed after starting growth hormones, making this the most likely cause.  
❌ Mutation in glucokinase:
Incorrect: Glucokinase mutation is seen in patients with maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). MODY is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by impaired insulin secretion and onset of diabetes often before the age of 25. However, this patient’s interval increase in HbA1C is more likely due to a side effect of growth hormone therapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks gestation is brought to the delivery room in active labor. The contractions began six hours ago and are occurring every five minutes. The patient does not have leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding. Fetal movement is normal. The patient was diagnosed with HIV in the first trimester and she has not been compliant with antiretroviral therapy or her prenatal visits. The uterus is soft and nontender between contractions. The fetal heart rate tracing shows accelerations with variability and does not show decelerations. The cervix is 6 cm dilated, 100% effaced and the fetal vertex is at +1 station. The amniotic sac is tense and palpable and has not ruptured. Maternal HIV viral load is 750 cells/ml. The patient delivers the infant who is subsequently initiated on zidovudine. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Selective inhibition of HIV reverse transcriptase

questions.solution:
This patient with untreated HIV and a high viral load presents in active labor and carries a high risk of vertical transmission to the fetus. Ideally, delivery via cesarean section should be pursued to mitigate any risks of vertical transmission followed by administration of a multi-drug antiviral regimen to the baby.

Antiretroviral therapy should be administered to all HIV-positive pregnant patients, regardless of the CD4 count or viral load to mitigate the risk of vertical transmission and treat the maternal infection.  The regimen of choice in pregnant patients with HIV includes a dual NRTI with a protease inhibitor or an integrase inhibitor such as tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine with dolutegravir. Earlier initiation of treatment can reduce the risk of transmission and can improve chances of viral suppression at term.

Cesarean delivery is indicated in HIV-positive patients if the viral load at the time of delivery is more than 1000 copies/mL. Intrapartum zidovudine along with the continuation of an ART regimen is indicated for patients who have viral loads >1000 copies/ml at the time of delivery. Operative vaginal delivery, intrapartum scalp monitoring, and artificial rupture of membranes should be avoided.

Post-exposure prophylaxis with multidrug ART is indicated for all neonates born to HIV-infected mothers (viral load>1000 cells/mL) and should be initiated within 6-12 hours of birth. Neonates born to mothers with viral loads <50 cells/mL (low risk) can receive zidovudine for 4 weeks as antiretroviral therapy. In resource-rich settings such as the United States, breastfeeding is contraindicated in neonates born to HIV-positive patients, as transmission can occur despite adequate viral suppression.

Option Analysis

✅ Selective inhibition of HIV reverse transcriptase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ HIV Integrase inhibition:
Incorrect: Medications such as bictegavir, dolutegravir, elvitegravir, and raltegravir are characterized by inhibition of intengrase.  
❌ HIV protease inhibition:
Incorrect: Medications including atazanavir, darunavir, and ritonavir are characterized by protease inhibition.  
❌ Viral entry inhibition:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide and maraviroc are characterized as HIV viral entry inhibitors.  
❌ Inhibition of the 50s ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: This stem describes the mechanism of action of macrolide antibiotics, which are not a component of acute HIV therapy or prophylaxis.

questions.text:
A pharmacist compares several inhaled anesthetic agents in a series of experiments. The obtained results are summarized below. Which of the following best describes the property of halothane when compared to that nitrous oxide?
 
Table 1: Properties of different inhaled anesthetic agents

Blood-gas partition coefficient  
Brain-blood partition coefficient  
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)
Nitrous oxide
0.47
1.1
>104%
Desflurane
0.42
1.3
6-7%
Isoflurane
1.402.61.4%
Halothane
2.302.90.75%
questions.solution:
Inhaled anesthetics are gasses or volatile liquids given through a mask or endotracheal tube for the patient to inhale. The anesthetics then pass from the lungs' alveoli into the blood and finally to different body parts.

Uptake of the anesthetic into the blood depends on several factors, including:

  • Blood-gas partition coefficient, which is the ratio of anesthetic concentrations in the blood and alveolar space when partial pressures in the two compartments are equal—the higher the blood-gas partition coefficient, the greater the anesthetic’s solubility in the bloodstream.
  • Lung ventilation, volumes, and perfusion
Distribution and uptake into the brain directly depend on the brain-blood partition coefficient, the ratio of anesthetic concentrations between brain tissue and blood when partial pressures are equal. A higher brain-blood partition coefficient signifies greater solubility of the anesthetic in brain tissue.

Inhaled anesthetics' onset of action and recovery time depends on the blood-gas partition coefficient. Drugs with high blood-gas partition coefficients are more soluble in blood, demonstrate slower equilibrium with the brain, and have longer onset and recovery times.

Finally, minimum alveolar concentration (MAC), which is the alveolar concentration of an inhaled anesthetic that prevents movement in 50% of patients in response to a noxious stimulus, is inversely related to anesthetic potency. The lower the MAC value, the more fat-soluble the anesthetic.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Lower blood solubility:
Incorrect: The blood-gas coefficient measures how soluble an anesthetic is in the bloodstream. Halothane has a higher blood-gas coefficient, meaning it is more soluble in blood than nitrous oxide.  
❌ Lower potency:
Incorrect: Potency is inversely correlated to an anesthetic’s MAC. Halothane has a lower MAC than nitrous oxide. Therefore, halothane is more potent.  
❌ Lower brain solubility:
Incorrect: The brain-blood partition coefficient is the ratio of anesthetic concentrations in the brain tissue and bloodstream when partial pressures are equal. The higher the brain-blood partition coefficient, the greater the solubility of the anesthetic in brain tissue. Therefore, halothane has higher brain solubility than nitrous oxide.  
✅ Longer recovery time:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Shorter induction time:
Incorrect: The lower the blood-gas partition coefficient of an inhaled anesthetic, the faster the medication takes effect (faster induction). Halothane has a higher blood-gas partition coefficient and requires more time to take effect (slower induction).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the obstetrician for evaluation of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Over the past two weeks, the patient has noticed a fishy vaginal odor. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 110/79 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Upon pelvic examination, gray-white discharge is apparent. She has never had a sexually transmitted infection but has recently been sexually active with a new partner. An amine whiff test is performed, which enhances the odor. The patient is started on a medication for the treatment of her symptoms. Three days later, while at a restaurant, she develops flushing, hypotension, nausea, and vomiting after consuming a glass of wine. Which of the following best characterizes the mechanism causing this reaction?
questions.solution:
This patient has a fishy-smelling vaginal odor and gray discharge. These findings are suggestive of bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. She was most likely prescribed metronidazole, which causes a disulfiram-like reaction after consuming alcohol since the drug leads to acetaldehyde accumulation within the body.

Metronidazole is an antibiotic and antiprotozoal medication. It functions by generating toxic metabolites that damage pathogenic DNA. However, some of these metabolites inhibit the hepatic enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase. Aldehyde dehydrogenase plays a vital role in ethanol metabolism by breaking down acetaldehyde into acetate. As a result, when patients consume alcohol while taking metronidazole, acetaldehyde builds up and produces symptoms of a disulfiram-like reaction (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, flushing, headache).
   

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of alcohol dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis, often treated using metronidazole. Although metronidazole can cause a disulfiram-like reaction if the patient consumes alcohol while taking the drug, it does not inhibit the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase.  
❌ Rapid accumulation of ethanol:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on metronidazole to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. Metronidazole does not directly cause excessive ethanol accumulation.  
❌ Accumulation of acetate:
Incorrect: Acetate is formed via the catalysis of acetaldehyde by the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. Metronidazole inhibits this enzyme and causes the accumulation of acetaldehyde, not acetate.  
✅ Accumulation of acetaldehyde:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deficiency of adequate reducing agents:
Incorrect: This patient was most likely started on metronidazole to treat bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardenrelalla vaginalis. Metronidazole does not deplete reducing agents required for the metabolism of alcohol.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of intermittent fevers, chills, malaise, and fatigue for the past month. The symptoms develop sporadically, last anywhere from 1-4 days, and spontaneously resolve. The patient returned from a safari trip in Africa 2-months ago. He received chemoprophylaxis with chloroquine during the trip and continued it for four weeks after returning. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva and an enlarged spleen. Peripheral blood smear shows trophozoites and schizonts. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s infection?

choices.text: Release of dormant hypnozoites from hepatocytes
Infection with parasites resistant to chloroquine
Mosquito bites after returning to the United States
Unprotected intercourse with a new partner

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irregular fever pattern, chills, and myalgias after returning from a malaria-endemic area. In combination with the trophozoites and schizonts seen on peripheral smear, these findings are concerning for infection by chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium falciparum.

Chloroquine is an antimalarial drug and a quinoline derivative. Other quinoline derivatives include quinidine, mefloquine, and primaquine. These medications work by entering the Plasmodium and accumulating in their food vacuoles. Here, they bind to heme and prevent its conversion into hemozoin. Heme is toxic to the Plasmodium, and its accumulation eventually leads to their death.

Chloroquine is one of the most commonly used antimalarial medications and is an effective blood schizonticide (kills Plasmodium found in erythrocytes). It is effective against all species of Plasmodium. Still, its widespread use has caused P. falciparum in many parts of South America, Africa, and Asia to develop resistance via a membrane efflux pump that can pump out drug molecules. In these regions, mefloquine, quinidine, and quinine can be used as the main schizontocidal medication.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Release of dormant hypnozoites from hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Plasmodium ovale and Plasmodium vivax have a dormant hepatic phase (hypnozoite) that may reactivate in patients several months after returning from a malaria-endemic region. However, the irregular pattern of this patient’s symptoms is more concerning for Plasmodium falciparum infection, which does not have a dormant hepatic phase.  
✅ Infection with parasites resistant to chloroquine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mosquito bites after returning to the United States:
Incorrect: Malaria has been eradicated mainly from the United States. Individuals who develop malaria in the United States usually acquire the infection in different countries.  
❌ Unprotected intercourse with a new partner:
Incorrect: Syphilis, caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum, is usually transmitted via unprotected sexual intercourse. Patients can develop a chancre (painless ulcer) early in the disease course. In combination with trophozoites and schizonts on peripheral smear, fever and chills are more suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Inadequate duration of chemoprophylaxis:
Incorrect: Chemoprophylaxis against malarial infection should begin at least 2-weeks before traveling to an endemic region, be continued during the trip, and discontinued 4-weeks after returning. This patient completed the entire chemoprophylaxis regimen.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman comes to the office at 18-weeks gestation because of a week-long history of headaches, muscle pain, and recurrent fever spikes every two days. He returned from a 3-week-long trip to the Dominican Republic two weeks ago. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. The spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Hemoglobin concentration is 10 g/dL. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following agents should be avoided in treating this patient’s condition?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient recently returned from a trip to a malaria-endemic region. The presence of tertian fever and trophozoite rings in erythrocytes suggest infection by Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale, both of which are treated with a combination of chloroquine and primaquine.

Primaquine is usually well tolerated but may cause gastrointestinal distress, pruritus, headaches, and methemoglobinemia. It can cause hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Thus, it is contraindicated in pregnancy since the G6PD status of the fetus is uncertain.

Therefore, pregnant women are often treated with chloroquine monotherapy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mefloquine:
Incorrect: Mefloquine is associated with several side effects, including gastrointestinal distress, cardiac conduction defects, and neuropsychiatric complications (e.g., seizures, psychosis, depression). However, it is not contraindicated in pregnancy.  
❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Chloroquine is well tolerated and is not known to have harmful effects in pregnancy.  
❌ Quinine:
Incorrect: Quinine is safe and effective and should be used when needed. However, glucose levels should be monitored, as the drug can cause maternal and fetal hypoglycemia.  
❌ Clindamycin:
Incorrect: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends treating uncomplicated Plasmodium falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy with quinine plus clindamycin for seven days.  
✅ Primaquine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider in the winter for evaluation of nasal congestion and clear nasal discharge. These symptoms began two days ago and have been bothersome as she frequently feels the urge to blow her nose. The patient has also experienced a cough and sore throat. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg, and pulse is 69/min. Mild erythema is present in the oropharynx. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The patient is prescribed a nasal decongestant and is provided with anticipatory guidance on its side effects, which include hypertension, anxiety, and rebound congestion with prolonged use. Which of the following best describes this medication’s mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of the common cold and was started on a nasal decongestant. The side effect profile described in the question stem is most consistent with that of an alpha-adrenergic decongestant (e.g. phenylephrine, pseudoephedrine, oxymetazoline).  

Alpha-adrenergic decongestants stimulate α-receptors and induce vasoconstriction. These changes decrease respiratory mucosa edema and hyperemia, thereby improving symptoms of nasal congestion. Alpha-adrenergic decongestants can be administered orally or topically via nasal sprays.   

Topical administration is well-tolerated but may cause rebound congestion if used for more than four to six days. Systemic administration can cause hypertension secondary to vasoconstriction as well as central nervous system stimulation and anxiety.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of NMDA receptors:
Incorrect: Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that works by suppressing NMDA receptors. Side effects, particularly with overdose include hallucinations, confusion, euphoria, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. In severe cases, patients may experience seizures, coma, and respiratory depression. In contrast, dextromethorphan is not typically associated with hypertension, sensation of nervousness, or rebound congestion.  
❌ Antagonization of H1 receptors:
Incorrect: Antihistamines (e.g. diphenhydramine, loratadine, cetirizine) can be used to treat symptoms of nasal congestion caused by allergies or the common cold. Antihistamines can cause drowsiness, anticholinergic symptoms (e.g. urinary retention, mydriasis, dry mouth), and anti-α-adrenergic symptoms (e.g. postural hypotension). However, they would not account for the constellation of side effects described in the question stem.  
❌ Inactivation of NF-KB:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids inactivate NF-KB and impair the production of downstream inflammatory cytokines. Intranasal corticosteroids can be used to treat nasal congestion csed by allergies. However, these medications are not typically used in the treatment of cold symptoms and would not account for the constellation of side effects described in the question stem.  
✅ Stimulation of α-receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blockade of leukotriene receptors:
Incorrect: Medications such as montelukast and zafirlukast block leukotriene receptors and can be used for the treatment of asthma. Overall, these drugs are safe but can cause side effects, including hypersensitivity reactions, headaches, upper respiratory infections, and gastrointestinal irritation. In contrast, leukotriene receptor antagonists do not typically cause hypertension, sensation of nervousness, or rebound congestion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of persistent cough for the past month. She has occasionally coughed up bright red blood. Past medical history is notable for asthma and three uncomplicated pregnancies. The patient immigrated to the United States from China one year ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 117/76 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination is notable for increased resonance to percussion over the left upper lung. A chest radiograph reveals a cavitary lesion in the left upper lobe. The patient is started on multiple medications, one of which may cause hepatitis, gastrointestinal irritation, and orange discoloration of body fluids. Which of the following best describes this medication's mechanism of action?

choices.text: Generation of free radicals that damage DNA

questions.solution:
Chest radiography demonstrates the presence of a left lung cavitary lesion. This patient immigrated from a tuberculosis-endemic country and presented with cough and hemoptysis. She has active tuberculosis and is initiated on multiple medications. One of these medications, rifampin, can cause side effects.    

Rifampin is part of the rifamycin antibiotic class. These medications work by inhibiting mycobacterial RNA polymerase, impairing RNA synthesis. Rifampin can treat both active and latent mycobacterial infections; however, mycobacterium can develop resistance to rifampin via mutations in the gene encoding for RNA polymerase.  

This medication can cause numerous side effects. It can cause orange discoloration of body fluids, including urine, saliva, tears, and sweat. Rifampin can also cause hepatitis, which is more severe at high doses, and induce the enzyme cytochrome P450. Finally, rifampin can cause nonspecific side effects, including rash, fever, and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting).  



Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of arabinogalactan synthesis:
Incorrect: Ethambutol inhibits the enzyme arabinosyltransferase, thereby preventing the synthesis of arabinogalactan–a component of the mycobacterial cell wall. Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis and hyperuricemia.   
❌ Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis:
Incorrect: Isoniazid inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acid, which is a major component of the mycobacterial cell wall. Although this medication can be hepatotoxic, it would not typically lead to orange discoloration of body fluids.  
✅ Inhibition of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Generation of free radicals that damage DNA:
Incorrect: Metronidazole is an antibiotic that generates free radicals, which can damage bacterial and protozoal DNA. This medication treats protozoal (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica, Giardia lamblia) and anaerobic bacterial infections. Metronidazole is not used to treat tuberculosis, and it does not lead to orange discoloration of body fluids.  
❌ Blockade of bacterial topoisomerase enzymes:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones work by inhibiting bacterial topoisomerase. These medications can cause gastrointestinal irritation, tendonitis, rupture, and QT-interval prolongation.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a persistent cough. The cough began five months ago, worsens at night, and is associated with intermittent episodes of hemoptysis. She has experienced night sweats, fatigue, and decreased appetite. The patient immigrated to the United States from Nigeria one year ago. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 132/78 mmHg, and pulse is 77/min. Physical examination is notable for wheezing in the bilateral lung fields, axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy, and hepatomegaly. Chest imaging is performed and shown below. A sputum sample is obtained and sent for a polymerase chain reaction assay, which reveals the presence of mycobacterial DNA. She is started on multiple medications, one of which prevents bacterial protein synthesis by inhibiting the 30S ribosomal subunit. Which of the following side effects may develop as a compilation of this medication?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with cough, hemoptysis, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and night sweats. Imaging reveals multiple small nodules in the bilateral lung fields, and the polymerase chain reaction is positive for mycobacterial DNA. In combination, these findings are consistent with miliary (disseminated) tuberculosis.    

Streptomycin can be used to treat miliary tuberculosis and Mycobacterium tuberculosis meningitis. The medication is an aminoglycoside that acts on the 30S subunit of the mycobacterial ribosome, thereby blocking protein synthesis.  

Side effects of streptomycin include hypersensitivity rash and fever. Like other aminoglycosides, streptomycin can also cause nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity, which may manifest with tinnitus, hearing loss, and loss of balance.  



Option Analysis

✅ Tinnitus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Seizures:
Incorrect: Isoniazid overdose can precipitate seizures that may be refractory to benzodiazepine therapy. The drug works by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis instead of inhibiting the bacterial 30S ribosomal subunit.  
❌ Orange discoloration of body fluids:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms and imaging findings concerning disseminated tuberculosis. Rifampin can be used to treat disseminated tuberculosis and may cause orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, sweat) as a side effect. However, the drug works by inhibiting RNA polymerase instead of inhibiting the 30S ribosomal subunit.  
❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy is a well-documented side effect of isoniazid. This side effect arises since the medication reduces biologically active vitamin B6 (pyridoxine). However, isoniazid works by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis instead of inhibiting the bacterial 30S ribosomal subunit.  
❌ Red-green color blindness:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms and imaging findings concerning disseminated tuberculosis. Ethambutol can be used to treat disseminated tuberculosis and may cause red-green color blindness as a side effect. However, the drug works by inhibiting arabinosyltransferase instead of inhibiting the 30S ribosomal subunit.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a persistent cough. The patient has been experiencing daily coughing episodes for the past five months, which sometimes produce bright right blood. He has also experienced fatigue and night sweats. He initially attributed these symptoms to viral pneumonia but became concerned after they failed to resolve. He is a photographer and frequently travels overseas–most recently to Thailand. Medical history is notable for hypertension and seasonal allergies. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 146/82 mmHg, and pulse is 91/min. Rhonchi are auscultated in the right lung. Chest imaging is shown below. The patient is started on multiple medications, one of which can cause elevations in serum uric acid levels, liver injury, and joint pain. In which of the following cellular components will this drug work most effectively?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
Chest radiography demonstrates cavitary lesions in the left lung. This patient presents with a persistent cough, hemoptysis, fatigue, night sweats, and a history of potential travel to tuberculosis-endemic regions. He was likely started on pyrazinamide, which can cause hepatotoxicity, hyperuricemia, and arthralgias. In combination, these findings are concerning for active tuberculosis.   

Pyrazinamide is a prodrug that gets converted to pyrazinoic acid, which is the active form of the medication. This conversion is greatest at acidic pHs, and hence the drug is most effective in acidic environments, such as in host phagolysosomes. Pyrizanimide’s exact mechanism is still uncertain but most likely disrupts cell membrane function, protein synthesis, and other cellular processes. It can be used in combination with other medications to treat active tuberculosis.  

In terms of side effects, pyrazinamide inhibits uric acid excretion, causing hyperuricemia and increased risk of gout. The drug is also hepatotoxic and should be avoided in patients with liver disease. Other side effects are arthralgias, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lysosome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nucleus:
Incorrect: Pyrazinamide is an antituberculosis medication that can cause hyperuricemia, hepatotoxicity, and arthralgias. The medication works best at acidic pHs. Although the nucleus has a slightly acidic pH (7.2), lysosomes are more acidic.   
❌ Golgi apparatus:
Incorrect: Pyrazinamide is an antituberculosis medication that can cause hyperuricemia, hepatotoxicity, and arthralgias. The medication works best at acidic pHs. Although the Golgi apparatus has a slightly acidic pH (6.0-6.8), lysosomes are more acidic.   
❌ Mycolic acid:
Incorrect: Isoniazid inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acid, which is a component of the mycobacterial cell wall. Although isoniazid can be hepatotoxic and lead to elevated liver enzymes, this medication does not typically cause hyperuricemia.  
❌ Cytoplasm:
Incorrect: This patient was started on pyrazinamide, which can lead to hyperuricemia, hepatotoxicity, and arthralgias. This medication works best in acidic environments, such as within phagolysosomes. In contrast, the cellular cytoplasm has a neutral pH of approximately 7.3.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care provider to evaluate lower back pain. The symptoms began two days ago after he attempted to lift a heavy bookshelf. The patient has not experienced incontinence or muscular weakness in the lower extremities. He currently rates the pain as 5 out of 10 in severity.  His past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which he takes amlodipine and lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 135/73 mmHg, and pulse is 62/min. On physical examination, there is mild tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles. Pain is exacerbated with flexion and extension of the lumbar spine. Strength and sensation are intact in the bilateral lower extremities. The remainder of the physical exam is noncontributory. Laboratory testing is shown below. The patient is prescribed a short course of cyclobenzaprine. Which of the following side effects is associated with this medication?
 
Laboratory Value
Results (U.S. conventional units)
Results (SI units)
Hemoglobin
15.1 g/dL
9.38 mmol/L
Leukocyte Count
7,500/mm3
7.5*109/L
Platelet count
270,000/mm3
270*109/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)

13 mm/hr

48 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with musculoskeletal low back pain that has persisted despite applying heat packs and ibuprofen use. As a result, he was started on cyclobenzaprine, which can cause xerostomia as a side effect.

Cyclobenzaprine is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Its exact mechanism of action is not fully understood, but studies have demonstrated that the medication antagonizes 5-HT2 receptors within the spinal cord. A similar medication is methocarbamol (its mechanism of action also remains unclear).

Both cyclobenzaprine and methocarbamol can treat musculoskeletal pain (e.g., low back pain, neck pain). In addition, cyclobenzaprine can be used off-label to treat fibromyalgia.

These medications can cause decreased skeletal muscle tone, sedation, drowsiness, confusion, and visual hallucinations. Furthermore, cyclobenzaprine can cause anticholinergic side effects, such as xerostomia, mydriasis, hyperthermia, and constipation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Truncal obesity:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids can be used to treat inflammatory myopathies such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis. These medications can result in the redistribution of adipose tissue from the extremities to the abdomen and subsequent truncal obesity. This patient has a normal ESR and creatinine kinase, making an inflammatory myopathy unlikely.  
❌ Diarrhea:
Incorrect: This patient was prescribed cyclobenzaprine, a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Cyclobenzaprine also has anticholinergic properties. As a result, the medication can cause constipation, not diarrhea.  
❌ Miosis:
Incorrect: Opioids are a class of pain medications that can cause miosis. These medications bind to mu, kappa, and gamma opioid receptors. In contrast, this patient was started on cyclobenzaprine, a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. Cyclobenzaprine has anticholinergic properties and can cause mydriasis, not miosis.  
✅ Xerostomia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Myoclonus:
Incorrect: This patient was started on cyclobenzaprine to treat low back pain. Serotonin syndrome may develop in patients taking cyclobenzaprine and another pro-serotonergic medication. In contrast, serotonin syndrome would be highly unlikely in patients on cyclobenzaprine monotherapy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) presents to the oncologist for a follow-up visit. The patient was diagnosed with CML last year and was started on imatinib therapy; however, his leukocyte count has remained elevated even after starting imatinib. Hydroxyurea is added to the patient’s treatment regimen. Which of the following steps is inhibited by hydroxyurea?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) that is not well-controlled with imatinib and is also started on hydroxyurea therapy. Hydroxyurea is a ribonucleotide reductase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides, thereby inhibiting DNA synthesis. It is used to treat resistant CML, as well as head and neck cancers.

Nucleotides are the building blocks of DNA and RNA. They consist of ribose sugar (in DNA deoxyribose), pyrimidine or purine base, and phosphate groups. Nucleotide synthesis can occur de novo or through the salvage pathway. In de novo synthesis, purine and pyrimidine bases are synthesized in the cell from small precursors.

De novo synthesis of pyrimidines starts when CO2, aspartate, and glutamine are used to create orotic acid. Orotic acid is then converted to uridine and cytidine nucleobases (e.g., UMP, CMP), which can be used to synthesize RNA.
 

However, in order for these ribonucleotides to be used in DNA synthesis, they have to be converted into the deoxy form. This step is mediated by an enzyme called ribonucleotide reductase.
 
 
Ribonucleotide reductase inhibitors (e.g. hydroxyurea, fludarabine) inhibit the conversion of ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides. In the absence of deoxyribonucleotides, DNA synthesis cannot proceed. Therefore, these agents indirectly inhibit DNA synthesis and halt cellular division.  

Option Analysis

✅ Uridine diphosphate to deoxyuridine diphosphate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Orotic acid to uridine monophosphate:
Incorrect: Conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate is one of the initial steps in pyrimidine synthesis. This step is mediated by uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase, an enzyme that is deficient in patients with orotic aciduria. In contrast, hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase, as opposed to UMP synthase.  
❌ Deoxyuridine monophosphate to deoxythymidine monophosphate:
Incorrect: The conversion of deoxyuridine monophosphate to deoxythymidine monophosphate is mediated by thymidylate synthase. This enzyme is inhibited by 5-fluorouracil, not hydroxyurea.  
❌ Dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate:
Incorrect: Dihydrofolate reductase mediates the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, which is needed to synthesize pyrimidine bases. This enzyme is inhibited by methotrexate.  
❌ Hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate:
Incorrect: Conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate, is part of the purine salvage pathway and is mediated by the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT). Patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome are deficient in HGPRT. Hydroxyurea does not affect HGPRT activity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. The patient last visited the physician 3-months ago with difficulty seeing distant objects, especially at night, despite wearing glasses. She has recently been prescribed a new drug for her chronic eye condition. Past medical history is significant for open-angle glaucoma, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral narrowing of peripheral visual fields, cupping of the optic discs, and elevated intraocular pressure. Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. Intraocular pressure is normal, but the darkening of the iris and an increase in the length of the eyelashes is observed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current examination findings?
questions.solution:
This patient was most likely started on topical latanoprost to manage open-angle glaucoma OAG). Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that increases the outflow of aqueous humor by decreasing the flow resistance through the uveoscleral pathway. It is the first-line treatment for OAG.

All the prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost and bimatoprost) may produce conjunctival hyperemia, hyperpigmentation of periorbital skin, eyelash growth, and permanent darkening of the iris (particularly in green-brown and yellow-brown irides).   

Option Analysis

✅ Topical latanoprost:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide is a first-line treatment for acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. It may cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis due to type 2 renal tubular acidosis. Other important adverse effects of acetazolamide include hypokalemia, sulfa allergy, and hyperammonemia with paresthesias.  
❌ Inhaled glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Inhaled glucocorticoids are associated with a hoarse voice, oral candidiasis, cough, and throat irritation. Darkening of the iris and an increase in the length of the eyelashes would not be observed.  
❌ Topical pilocarpine:
Incorrect: Pilocarpine, a cholinomimetic drug, can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma by increasing trabecular aqueous humor outflow. However, it is not the first-line treatment. Moreover, the most common side effects include cholinergic side effects (sweating, rhinorrhea, dizziness, and nausea), none seen in this patient.  
❌ Topical timolol:
Incorrect: Local side effects of topical timolol include dry eyes and superficial punctate keratopathy, neither of which is seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to the office for a follow-up appointment after he is found to have elevated aspartate and alanine transaminase levels on laboratory testing. He has not experienced abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or fatigue. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, glyburide, and aspirin. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 30-pack-year smoking history. The patient also has a history of intravenous drug use and was undomiciled in his early 30s. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on interferon-ɑ therapy. This drug works via which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Inhibition of virion release from infected cells
Prevention of viral entry into the target cell

questions.solution:
This patient has elevated liver enzymes and hepatitis C virus (HCV) IgG titers, and high HCV RNA levels. These findings are consistent with HCV infection, and the patient is started on interferon-alpha (IFN-α) therapy.

Interferons (IFNs) are cytokines that exhibit a broad spectrum of antiviral activities and immunomodulating and antiproliferative properties. Currently, only two types of interferons are available for clinical use: IFNα2A and IFNα2B.

The selective antiviral action of IFN-α is primarily due to its ability to activate host cell ribonucleases that preferentially degrade viral mRNA. IFN-α also promotes the formation of natural killer cells that destroy liver cells infected by HCV. It is usually given either as an intramuscular or subcutaneous injection. Sometimes INFs can be provided in pegylated IFN (i.e. IFN plus polyethylene glycol).

IFNs are used in the treatment of both chronic HBV and HCV infections. When treating HCV infection, IFNs are used either as monotherapy or in combination with other antiviral medications such as ribavirin. Other indications include herpes virus infection, papillomavirus infection, and Kaposi sarcoma occurring in the setting of HIV infection.

Side effects of IFN-α include flu-like symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting), bone marrow suppression leading to neutropenia and thrombocytopenia, neurotoxicity (e.g., sleepiness, depression, behavioral disturbances), and liver dysfunction leading to elevated liver enzymes. It can also cause alopecia, which is more common in children.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Activation of host cell ribonuclease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of viral protease activity:
Incorrect: Protease inhibitors are drugs that inhibit the action of HIV-1 protease, an enzyme that cleaves precursor proteins into smaller fragments. These fragments are needed for viral growth, infectivity, and replication. Examples of protease inhibitors include ritonavir and indinavir.  
❌ Inhibition of virion release from infected cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that can treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.  
❌ Prevention of viral entry into the target cell:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.  
❌ Inhibition of viral DNA replication:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B medications, including nucleoside analogs (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) and nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir), are incorporated into growing viral DNA strands. Once these analogs have been incorporated, no additional nucleotides can be added, and DNA synthesis stops. Interferon-ɑ, however, works via a different mechanism of action.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for a general physical examination. The patient has not been to a physician in the last 20 years. The patient frequently experiences fatigue and dull abdominal pain. Past medical history is significant for a diagnosis of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus in her 40s, but these conditions remain untreated. The patient received a blood transfusion several decades ago following complicated childbirth. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on a combination of sofosbuvir and daclatasvir. Daclatasvir acts via the inhibition of which of the following?

choices.text: Viral entry into the target cell

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, dull abdominal pain, elevated hepatitis C virus (HCV) IgG titers, and high HCV RNA levels. These findings are consistent with HCV infection. The patient is started on sofosbuvir and daclatasvir.

Daclatasvir is an NS5A inhibitor often used in combination with sofosbuvir to treat HCV infection. NS5A is a membrane-associated phosphoprotein part of the HCV RNA replication complex and is essential for viral replication and assembly. Inhibition of this phosphoprotein prevents HCV RNA replication. Other NS5A inhibitors include elbasvir, ledipasvir, ombitasvir, and velpatasvir.

Side effects associated with NS5A inhibitor use include mild to moderate headache, fatigue, and gastrointestinal irritation. Daclatasvir is primarily metabolized through CYP3A metabolism and should not be given strong inducers or inhibitors of this enzyme.  

Option Analysis

❌ Viral DNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Hepatitis medications, including nucleoside analogs (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) and nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir), are incorporated into growing viral DNA and RNA strands. Once these analogs have been incorporated, viral polymerase, and the synthesis of genetic material stops, no additional nucleotides can be added. In contrast, daclatasvir works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ HCV-encoded proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Ribavirin is an antiviral medication that inhibits viral production of guanine nucleotides through competitive inhibition of inosine monophosphate (IMP) dehydrogenase. It is usually used as an adjunct to interferon therapy.  
❌ Virion release from infected cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that blocks the enzyme neuraminidase. NAIs can be used to treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.  
❌ Viral entry into the target cell:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.

The patient was diagnosed with HIV infection ten months ago and initiated on a medication that inhibits the virus’s ability to cleave Gag-Pol polyproteins. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 155/87 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. No lymphadenopathy, tonsillar swelling, or oral thrush is observed. choices.text: Reduced pinprick sensation in the bilateral upper extremities
Epigastric pain radiating towards the back
Increased dorsocervical and abdominal adipose tissue
Blistering and desquamation of the skin and mucous membranes

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with HIV infection and initiated on a medication that prevents the virus from cleaving the Gag-Pol polyprotein. Laboratory results are notable for hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia. As a result, this patient was likely started on a protease inhibitor, which can lead to lipodystrophy.

Protease inhibitors bind and inhibit HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing the Gag-Pol polyprotein into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication. Protease inhibitors are generally used with other medications as part of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

A common side effect of protease inhibitors is metabolic disorders, such as insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, and hyperlipidemia. These metabolic disorders are often followed by lipodystrophy. Lipodystrophy is characterized by abnormal accumulation of fat tissue in the abdomen, breasts (in women), and around the cervical vertebrae and loss of fat in the extremities and face. As a result, affected patients will classically have thin extremities, emaciated-appearing faces, and truncal obesity. Some studies have reported the incidence of lipodystrophy to be over 50% in patients taking protease inhibitors.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Reduced pinprick sensation in the bilateral upper extremities:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes peripheral neuropathy associated with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) such as lamivudine stavudine and didanosine. Although NRTIs can cause hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia as side effects, these medications function by inhibiting viral reverse transcriptase, not by inhibiting viral cleavage of the Gag-Pol polyprotein. In contrast, peripheral neuropathy in protease inhibitor use is rare.  
❌ Unilateral calf erythema and swelling:
Incorrect: A deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can manifest with unilateral calf erythema, swelling, and pain. However, the incidence of DVT or pulmonary embolism after initiating protease inhibitor therapy is infrequent, with some studies reporting the incidence rate to be less than 2%. In contrast, this patient already has laboratory findings suggestive of metabolic disorder (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia) and is at a far greater risk of developing lipodystrophy secondary to protease inhibitor use.  
❌ Epigastric pain radiating towards the back:
Incorrect: Certain nucleotide/nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) can cause pancreatitis, which classically manifests with epigastric pain radiating to the back. In contrast, the instance of pancreatitis following protease inhibitor therapy is rare. Furthermore, although this patient has hypertriglyceridemia, triglyceride levels exceeding 1000 mg/dL are generally required to increase an individual’s risk of developing pancreatitis significantly.  
✅ Increased dorsocervical and abdominal adipose tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blistering and desquamation of the skin and mucous membranes:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which affects less than 30% of the total skin surface and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), which affects more than 30% of the total skin surface. Patients on non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) therapy are at risk of developing SJS/TEN. In contrast, this patient was initiated on a protease inhibitor, which has a higher likelihood of causing metabolic syndrome and lipodystrophy than SJS/TEN.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of severe, right-sided abdominal pain. The pain began earlier in the day, fluctuating in intensity, and radiated towards the groin. She has also experienced nausea and one episode of non-bloody, non-bilious emesis after symptom onset. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, asthma, and HIV infection. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 142/79 mmHg, and pulse is 97/min. Physical examination reveals right abdominal tenderness that is exacerbated by deep palpation. No costovertebral angle tenderness is present. The most recent CD4 count is 1,200/mm3. Urinalysis is shown below. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?  

Laboratory Value  
Results
White blood cells  
1-2/hpf  
Red blood cells  
50/hpf  
Bacterial
Negative
Nitrites
Negative
Leukocyte esterase  
Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain radiating towards the groin, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria on urinalysis. She likely has nephrolithiasis. Among the medications listed to treat HIV infection, indinavir is most strongly associated with nephrolithiasis.

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor. It binds and inhibits HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing Gag-Pol polyproteins into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication.

As with other protease inhibitors, indinavir can cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, nausea, vomiting), metabolic disorders (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia), and lipodystrophy. Furthermore, patients on indinavir may develop nephrolithiasis and associated hematuria. Nephrolithiasis occurs since around 20% of the drug molecules are renally excreted and may subsequently aggregate to form stones. Therefore, individuals treated with indinavir should maintain good hydration to reduce the risk of nephrolithiasis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that inhibits viral DNA polymerase. The medication can treat infection by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Although acyclovir can cause crystalline nephropathy and nephrolithiasis, this patient has no indications warranting acyclovir treatment. As a result, it is unlikely that acyclovir is responsible for the patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Zidovudine:
Incorrect: Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV infection. The medication can cause side effects, including anemia, leukopenia, lactic acidosis, and lipodystrophy. However, the medication is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis.  
✅ Indinavir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Efavirenz:
Incorrect: Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used to treat HIV infection. It can cause side effects, including hepatotoxicity, hypersensitivity rash, and vivid dreams. However, the medication is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis.  
❌ Ritonavir:
Incorrect: Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor that prevents HIV from cleaving the Gag-Pol protein into its functional parts, hindering viral replication. The various protease inhibitors can cause hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, and lipodystrophy as side effects. Nephrolithiasis, in contrast, tends to be more strongly associated with the protease inhibitor indinavir.

questions.text:
