Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody that works against soluble tumor necrosis factor-alpha. It suppresses the immune response and lymphocyte activation and is used in certain autoimmune disorders (e.g. Crohn’s disease)
❌ Etanercept:
Incorrect: Etanercept is a fusion protein that binds to and sequesters tumor necrosis factor alpha, thereby preventing its action in stimulating the immune response and leukocyte activation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to his cardiologist for a follow-up appointment after being prescribed a new medication several weeks ago. Symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and lower extremity swelling have improved. However, he has noticed that his chest wall has been more tender than usual. Moreover, the patient has had difficulty achieving an erection. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for bilateral gynecomastia. Which medications were most likely prescribed to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of heart failure, presents several weeks after initiating a new medication. His history and physical examination demonstrate gynecomastia and sexual dysfunction, which are concerning for antiandrogenic side effects. Of the medications listed, only spironolactone carries this side effect profile.    

Spironolactone works primarily as a competitive aldosterone receptor antagonist in the cortical collecting tubule. It induces diuresis while preserving plasma potassium levels. In addition to this mechanism, spironolactone carries moderate anti-androgen effects via the blockade of androgen receptors. This blockade can result in gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido, and mood changes in men. When used in women, anti-androgen effects can result in breast enlargement and menstrual disturbances.  

Despite these side effects, spironolactone’s anti-androgenic effects make it a useful medication in treating several clinical conditions and heart failure. It is often used to treat acne vulgaris and hirsutism in women and acts as hormone therapy for transgender females. 

Option Analysis

✅ Spironolactone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic often prescribed for treating heart failure and hypervolemia. It does not carry anti-androgenic properties that would cause gynecomastia and erectile dysfunction.
❌ Carvedilol:
Incorrect: ꞵ-blockers are often employed in treating heart failure and can cause depression. However, they are not known to cause gynecomastia. 
❌ Milrinone:
Incorrect: Milrinone is another medication often used in the treatment of heart failure and pulmonary hypertension that works via activation of protein kinase A and inhibition of PDE3, which leads to increased inotropy and chronotropy. 
❌ Eplerenone :
Incorrect: Eplerenone, like spironolactone, works as a competitive aldosterone antagonist. However, it lacks the anti-androgenic properties associated with spironolactone.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician due to fatigue and low energy for the past two months. The patient tells the physician she can barely perform her daily activities and her work performance has declined. In addition, the patient reports that when she goes to the bathroom early in the morning, her urine is red in color. Last year she was diagnosed with Budd-Chiari syndrome and was prescribed anticoagulants. The patient’s labs show pancytopenia. Early morning urinalysis is positive for blood, but microscopy reveals no blood. Flow cytometry was performed and it showed decreased CD55 and CD59. The physician decides to start the patient on eculizumab. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: It binds to and blocks the activation of C5 complement protein
It binds soluble tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and prevents the activation of its receptor
It Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor
It binds to integrins in blood vessel walls and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation.

questions.solution:
This patient has anemia, venous thrombosis (e.g. Budd-Chiari syndrome), and pancytopenia. In addition, flow cytometry reveals decreased expression of CD55 and CD59, indicating paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

PNH is a rare hematopoietic stem cell disorder that manifests with hemolytic anemia, bone marrow failure, and thrombosis. Hemolysis in PNH is directly mediated by the complement system and is due to a mutation in the PIGA gene that results in the absence of GPI anchor expression erythrocytes. Deficiency of GPI on erythrocytes results in the inability of complement inhibitors CD55 and CD59 to function properly. Since CD55 and CD59 protect RBCs from complement damage, their absence results in excessive hemolysis of RBCs by the complement system.

Eculizumab is the first-line treatment for PNH. It is a human monoclonal antibody that binds to and blocks the activation of C5, thereby inhibiting the formation of membrane attack complexes (MAC). By doing so, eculizumab compensates for the absence of complement inhibitors (e.g. CD59) on the erythrocytes and therefore protects them from intravascular hemolysis by MAC.

The use of eculizumab in patients with PNH has been shown to improve anemia, inhibit intravascular hemolysis and decrease the need for transfusions; reduce the risk of venous thrombosis, and improve overall quality of life.  

Option Analysis

✅ It binds to and blocks the activation of C5 complement protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It binds soluble tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and prevents the activation of its receptor:
Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody against TNF and is used in inflammatory disorders like rheumatoid arthritis. It has no role in the management of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.  
❌ It Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor:
Incorrect: IL-17A inhibitors are medications that can be used in the management of severe psoriasis.  
❌ It binds to integrins in blood vessel walls and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation.:
Incorrect: Natalizumab binds to integrins on the endothelial cells of blood vessels, thereby inhibiting leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation. It is a drug used to treat Multiple Sclerosis.  
❌ It inhibits interleukin 12/23:
Incorrect: Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits interleukin-12/23. It can be used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to her physician for joint pain. The patient was diagnosed with psoriasis two years ago and was started on methotrexate. However, her skin lesions have not improved. Currently, the patient is having pain in the joints of both hands and fingers. Physical examination reveals inflammation of the distal interphalangeal joints, in addition to signs of joint destruction. The physician discusses a new medication with the patient called secukinumab. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor
Inhibits the interaction of Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) with its receptors
Inhibits C5 complement protein and the activation of membrane attack complexes
It binds integrins of the blood vessel wall and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing joint pain as a result of psoriatic arthritis. The physician decided to start the patient on secukinumab, which is an interleukin-17A (IL-17A) inhibitor.

IL-17A inhibitors belong to a new class of medication, which are monoclonal antibodies that prevent the interaction of IL-17A with its receptors. Examples include secukinumab, brodalumab, and ixekizumab.  These medications were introduced after the discovery of the role of Th-17 cells in the pathogenesis of many inflammatory disorders. Th-17 produces IL-17, which is a proinflammatory cytokine that once produced, stimulates the recruitment of neutrophils and other inflammatory cells and induces sustained chronic inflammation. IL-17A has been implicated in the pathogenesis of many immune-mediated disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, crohn’s disease, and multiple sclerosis.

IL-17A inhibitors are currently under investigation and their uses are promising. One of the indications of Il-17A inhibitors is moderate to severe psoriasis, with or without arthritis. Additionally, there are studies underway to determine their efficacy in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disorder.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits the interaction of Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) with its receptors:
Incorrect: Anti-TNF monoclonal antibodies can be used in the treatment of psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. Examples include adalimumab and infliximab. However, secukinumab is an IL-17A inhibitor.  
❌ Inhibits C5 complement protein and the activation of membrane attack complexes:
Incorrect: Eculizumab binds to and inhibits C5, thereby inhibiting the activation of membrane attack complexes.  
❌ Inhibits interleukin-12/23:
Incorrect: Ustekinumab inhibits interleukin-12/13  
❌ It binds integrins of the blood vessel wall and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation:
Incorrect: Natalizumab binds integrins on the endothelial cells of the blood vessels and thereby inhibits the use of integrins by leukocytes to cross to the inflammation site.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. The patient was insufflating a white powder earlier in the evening, and his symptoms developed shortly after that. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 201/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals diaphoresis and mydriasis. Which of the following medications is contraindicated, given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chest pain and significant vital sign derangements, which are suggestive of hypertensive emergency in the setting of alleged cocaine use. ꞵ-blockers like labetalol are contraindicated in managing these patients due to the risk of unopposed α-stimulation.

Indirect sympathomimetics like cocaine work by indirectly increasing the concentration of endogenous catecholamines within the synaptic cleft. In the case of cocaine, the concentration of neurotransmitters, including dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, and serotonin, are elevated. Peripherally, these catecholamines can stimulate postsynaptic α1- and α2-adrenoceptors, resulting in smooth muscle contraction and vasoconstriction. When this occurs in the coronary vasculature, patients often present with symptoms reminiscent of an acute coronary syndrome.

When a β-blocker is administered, the β2-vasodilator influence opposing α-adrenoceptor-mediated vasoconstriction is removed, potentially worsening blood pressure and its subsequent effects on the coronary vasculature.  

Option Analysis

✅ Labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: GABA-agonists such as lorazepam, midazolam, and diazepam are indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies induced by cocaine use.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin has been shown to have beneficial effects in managing acute coronary syndrome and should be administered to patients with an underlying suspicion of this condition. It is not contraindicated for patients with chest pain secondary to cocaine use.  
❌ Midazolam:
Incorrect: GABA-agonists such as lorazepam, midazolam, and diazepam are indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies induced by cocaine use.  
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is a potent direct-acting vasodilator. It is not the first-line medication to manage hypertensive emergencies secondary to amphetamine use. However, the medication is also not contraindicated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man visits the physician for a follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic primary hypogonadism one year ago after experiencing erectile dysfunction and decreased energy. He was then started on androgen replacement using intramuscular testosterone cypionate. Currently, he is feeling better, with improvement in his energy levels and sexual function. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is expected to be seen in this patient due to his treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient is being treated for hypogonadism using testosterone cypionate, a testosterone derivative used in androgen replacement therapy. It can cause an elevation in hematocrit as a side effect.

Testosterone derivatives are a group of androgenic hormones that have the structure of testosterone. Testosterone cypionate is one of these derivatives used intramuscularly, while fluoxymesterone and methyltestosterone are oral ones. Testosterone derivatives are usually used in androgen replacement therapy in patients with primary or secondary hypogonadism. It can also stimulate anabolism in patients with severe catabolic states (e.g. burn patients).

Side effects of testosterone derivatives are common. First, these drugs stimulate erythropoiesis, leading to increased erythrocyte production and hematocrit. Furthermore, they can increase the growth of the prostate gland as testosterone will be converted to dihydrotestosterone, which directly stimulates the growth of the prostate gland. Because of this effect, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can increase in patients taking testosterone derivatives, and sometimes there is a slightly increased risk of prostate cancer. Other side effects include increased LDL and decreased HDL, gynecomastia, gonadal atrophy, and infertility.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated hematocrit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated follicle stimulating hormone:
Incorrect: This patient is expected to have a decreased follicle stimulating hormone after starting testosterone treatment because it causes feedback inhibition of the gonadotrophs in the pituitary gland, leading to suppression of FSH release.  
❌ Elevated high-density lipoprotein (HDL):
Incorrect: Patients taking testosterone are expected to have an increased LDL and decreased HDL.  
❌ Decreased prostate gland size:
Incorrect: Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-alpha reductase enzyme. DHT then stimulates the growth of the prostate gland. Therefore, patients on testosterone replacement therapy usually have an increase in the size of the prostate gland.  
❌ Galactorrhea:
Incorrect:  Although testosterone hormone supplementation can lead to gynecomastia due to peripheral aromatization to estrogens, it is not associated with galactorrhea.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate nocturia and difficulty urinating. The patient has had these symptoms for a year, and it has been worsening. Currently, the patient wakes up three times a night to urinate. In addition, the patient noticed that it takes longer than usual for him to start urinating. Digital rectal examination reveals symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodularity. Urinalysis is within normal limits, and urinary culture is negative. The physician decided to start the patient on tamsulosin and finasteride. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of finasteride?

choices.text: Inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone
Blocks androgen receptors in the prostate gland
Relaxes the smooth muscles in the prostate gland and prostatic urethra
Inhibits testosterone production in the scrotum

questions.solution:
This patient with urinary flow obstruction (urinary hesitancy and straining) and irritative symptoms (frequency and nocturia) most likely have benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It is a common disease in the elderly that occurs due to overgrowth of the prostate gland, leading to obstruction of the prostatic urethra and urinary symptoms. Finasteride is sometimes used in the treatment of BPH.

Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) is an androgen that stimulates the growth of the prostate gland and is also associated with male pattern hair loss (i.e. androgenetic alopecia). Finasteride inhibits the conversion of testosterone to DHT by blocking the action of enzyme 5-alpha reductase, leading to decreased growth and, ultimately, shrinkage of the prostate gland, thereby reducing the blockage on the urethra. However, these effects usually take months to develop; therefore, finasteride's effects will only be seen after continuous use for a long period. Finasteride can also be used in the treatment of androgenetic alopecia.

Side effects of finasteride are common and include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and gynecomastia. In addition, some patients may also experience orthostatic hypotension. Finally, patients taking finasteride at high doses may develop infertility, which in severe cases, may be irreversible.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocks androgen receptors in the prostate gland:
Incorrect: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist usually used in metastatic prostate cancer. It is not frequently used in benign prostatic hyperplasia because of its feminization effects. Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor.  
❌ Relaxes the smooth muscles in the prostate gland and prostatic urethra:
Incorrect: Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonists (e.g. tamsulosin) are the first-line treatment of BPH, and they work via relaxing the smooth muscles in the prostatic urethra and prostate glands, thereby resolving the urinary blockage. However, finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor, not an alpha-1 receptor antagonist.  
❌ Inhibits testosterone production in the scrotum:
Incorrect: Certain medications inhibit testosterone synthesis (e.g. ketoconazole). However, finasteride does not inhibit testosterone synthesis and sometimes increased testosterone levels can be seen in patients taking finasteride.  
❌ Inhibits the synthesis of gonadotropins:
Incorrect: Use of Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (e.g. Leuprolide) can lead to suppression of production of gonadotropins, leading to decreased testosterone production. However, finasteride does not inhibit the synthesis of gonadotropins.

questions.text: A 32-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman is evaluated by an obstetrician after delivering a healthy baby 24 hours ago. The delivery was complicated by protraction in the first labor stage and augmented by an infusion bolus of oxytocin. After delivery, she suffered from excessive postpartum bleeding, which was successfully managed with oxytocin infusion and bimanual uterine massage. Which of the following side effects might develop as a result of oxytocin administration?
questions.solution:
This patient was administered oxytocin for labor induction and to treat her postpartum hemorrhage–increasing the risk of developing associated side effects. One known side effect is the development of hyponatremia.

Oxytocin is a peptide hormone produced by the hypothalamus and stored and released in the posterior pituitary. It stimulates uterine contraction by binding to Gq protein-coupled receptors. Once activated, these receptors activate another molecule called phospholipase C. Phospholipase C cleaves phosphatidylinositol 4,5 bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate. Finally, inositol triphosphate promotes the opening of calcium channels in the endoplasmic reticulum, enhancing calcium release into the cytoplasm, which mediates the contraction of the smooth muscle.

Exogenous oxytocin administration is indicated for both ante- and postpartum conditions. In the antepartum period, oxytocin is administered to strengthen uterine contractions to induce or facilitate labor. Oxytocin is also administered to treat postpartum hemorrhage as it mediates the contraction of the uterus and subsequent closure of uterine vasculature.

Side effects of oxytocin include vasodilation, which may result in hypotension and tachycardia. In addition, patients may develop water retention and hyponatremia. This occurs secondary to the ability of oxytocin to act on antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the renal tubules, promoting free water retention. Finally, oxytocin can lead to tachysystole (5 or more contractions in 10 minutes over a 30-minute duration).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hyponatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypernatremia:
Incorrect: When oxytocin is administered excessively or for prolonged periods, it acts similarly to antidiuretic hormone, promoting free water reabsorption and hyponatremia.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia is not a side effect of oxytocin.  
❌ Venous thromboembolism:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid (TXA) is sometimes used in patients with severe postpartum hemorrhage. TXA is an antifibrinolytic medication that prevents blood clots from breaking down. VTE is not a known side effect of oxytocin administration.  
❌ Bronchoconstriction:
Incorrect: Bronchoconstriction is a known side effect of prostaglandins and prostaglandin analogs (carboprost).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 31 weeks gestation, gravida 1 para 0, is admitted to the delivery unit due to preterm labor. The patient presented with regular uterus contractions and evidence of cervical dilation. Her pregnancy was uneventful, and she has regularly followed up with her prenatal care. The physician starts the patient on indomethacin and betamethasone. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of indomethacin?

choices.text: Inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium
Stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus

questions.solution:
This patient presented in preterm labor and was administered indomethacin to delay labor and allow for timely administration of glucocorticoids.

Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that works by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX), which are responsible for the synthesis of prostaglandins. Prostaglandins are necessary for uterine contraction.

Indomethacin can be used as a tocolytic only if the gestational age is less than 32 weeks. After 32 weeks, prostaglandins are contraindicated, as they may lead to premature closure of the ductus arteriosus. In addition, indomethacin inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins in other organs like the stomach, increasing the risk of gastritis and gastric bleeding. Indomethacin can also induce placental dysfunction (due to vasoconstriction).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inhibits the synthesis of prostaglandins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blocks oxytocin receptors:
Incorrect: Indomethacin is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor that blocks the synthesis of prostaglandins. It does not affect oxytocin receptors.  
❌ Increase the prostaglandin synthesis:
Incorrect: Indomethacin is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor resulting in decreased prostaglandins synthesis.  
❌ Inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium:
Incorrect: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that inhibits calcium channels in the myometrium, resulting in decreased intracellular calcium and, therefore, inhibition of the uterine contractions.  
❌ Stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is another tocolytic that stimulates Beta-2 adrenergic receptors in the uterus. Indomethacin does not exert any effects on this receptor.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician to evaluate palpitations, excessive sweating, and increased anxiety. The symptoms began four months ago. She consumes two cups of coffee per day. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which she uses an albuterol inhaler. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg. Physical exam is notable for diffusely enlarged, symmetrical, and non-tender thyroid. The remainder of the head and neck exam is non-contributory. TSH receptor antibody levels are elevated. The patient is started on a medication that reduces the peripheral conversion of T<sub>4</sub> to T<sub>3</sub> and inhibits thyroid peroxidase function. Which of the following side effects is associated with this medication?

choices.text: Diffuse skin blistering and epidermal detachment

questions.solution:
This patient has Graves disease and was started on a thionamide. Thionamides (e.g., methimazole, propylthiouracil) work by preventing thyroid hormone synthesis via inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. In addition, propylthiouracil (PTU) prevents the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 via inhibition of 5’-deiodinase.

Side effects include pruritic skin rash, vasculitis, hypothyroidism, lupus-like syndrome, agranulocytosis, and hypoprothrombinemia. Thionamides are also associated with hepatotoxicity, which is more common with PTU use. These side effects are reversible, meaning they resolve once the medications are discontinued.

It is important to note that methimazole and PTU are used in pregnancy even though they can cross the placenta. During the first trimester, when organogenesis is taking place, and the fetus is susceptible to drug-induced damage, PTU is preferred. The rationale is that PTU is less likely to cross the placenta due to its extensive plasma protein binding. On the other hand, methimazole is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is associated with aplasia cutis, a condition characterized by the absence of portions of skin. During the second and third trimesters, once organogenesis is complete, methimazole is preferred due to its lower risk of hepatotoxicity.  

Option Analysis

❌ Resting heart rate of 52/min:
Incorrect: Bradycardia, defined as a heart rate less than 60/min, is a side effect of beta blockers. Beta-blockers can be used to manage hyperthyroidism by inhibiting sympathetic activation of the beta-adrenergic receptors. Beta-blockers can also inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 at high doses. However, this medication class does not affect thyroid peroxidase function.  
❌ Subjective sensation of dry mouth:
Incorrect: Xerostomia, a sensation of oral dryness, is a side effect of radioactive iodine therapy. This occurs since the radioactive iodine can also be uptaken by the salivary glands, resulting in their damage. However, radioactive iodine does not directly inhibit thyroid peroxidase function or peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.  
❌ Random plasma glucose of 250 mg/dL:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids can cause insulin resistance and lead to glucocorticoid-induced diabetes mellitus. The medication suppresses immune system function and prevents the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. However, corticosteroids do not affect thyroid peroxidase function.  
✅ Aspartate aminotransferase level of 180 U/L:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse skin blistering and epidermal detachment  :
Incorrect: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS) are immune-mediated skin conditions that result in blistering and epidermal detachment. TEN (affecting > 30% of skin) can be thought of as a severe form of SJS (affecting ≤ 30% of skin). It would be atypical for a propylthiouracil, which functions via the mechanisms of action described in the question stem, to cause SJS or TEN.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a skin rash. It began a week ago on his trunk and has spread to his entire body now. He also reports low-grade fever, malaise, sore throat, and headache. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. He has had three female sexual partners over the past year. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus managed with lifestyle modifications. Temperature is 37.2°C (99 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a full-body maculopapular rash as shown below. Several gray, mucosal patches are seen in the mouth. Cervical, axillary and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy is present. HIV testing is negative. The patient is administered an intramuscular dose of penicillin G and sent home. He later presents to the emergency department three hours later with a worsening rash, muscle pain, rigors, and chills. His temperature is now 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current symptoms?


Reproduced from Flickr
questions.solution:
This patient’s initial presentation with a diffuse maculopapular rash, oral lesions, and lymphadenopathy  (especially epitrochlear), in combination with a history of multiple sexual partners, is consistent with secondary syphilis. A single dose of intramuscular penicillin G-benzathine is the treatment of choice. The development of rigors, myalgias, further rise in the body temperature, increased respiratory rate, and hypotension within four hours of penicillin administration is most likely secondary to Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR).  

JHR is a short-lived immunologic response to antimicrobial treatment characterized by fever, onset of constitutional symptoms, and worsening of rash (if initially present). It typically begins two to eight hours after the initial dose of antibiotic is given and resolves spontaneously within 24 hours.    

The exact cause is unknown, but it is thought to result from accelerated phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes followed by the release of bacterial toxins and/or lipoproteins and cytokines from killed organisms. Although the symptoms often resolve without intervention within 12 to 24 hours, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or other antipyretics can be used to decrease the severity. It can occur following the treatment of syphilis, Lyme disease, brucellosis, and enteric fever.  

Option Analysis

❌ Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome:
Incorrect: Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome is seen in some cases of AIDS or immunosuppression when the immune system starts to recover after the initiation of effective treatment of HIV or the removal of other causes of immunosuppression. A sudden increase in the inflammatory response produces nonspecific symptoms such as fever and in some cases a worsening of damage to the infected tissue. This patient was diagnosed with secondary syphilis and was subsequently started on an antibiotic therapy that triggered his current state. 
✅ Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute urticaria:
Incorrect: Acute urticaria refers to the development of dermal edema after the initiation of a new drug or exposure to an allergen. Presence of constitutional symptoms (rigors, myalgias, further rise in the body temperature, increased respiratory rate, and hypotension) is atypical.
❌ Procaine reaction:
Incorrect: Procaine reaction is a pseudo-anaphylactic reaction caused by unintentional intracapillary penetration of procaine penicillin during administration by intramuscular injection. Microembolization of the drug crystals can cause confusion and psychotic symptoms, which are not present in the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR). The acute onset of the reaction and its brief duration (30 min) also differentiate it from JHR.
❌ Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome:
Incorrect: Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome is an idiosyncratic reaction consisting of fever, rash, eosinophilia, and internal organ involvement and tends to occur between 2-6 weeks after starting a new medication (as opposed to this patient’s presentation within 4 hours of penicillin administration). The most commonly implicated drugs include anticonvulsants, sulfonamides, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of high-grade fever, headache, watery diarrhea, and cough for the past two days. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Temperature is 40.1 C (104 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. On physical examination, there are rhonchi in multiple lung fields. Organisms found on induced sputum stain poorly on Gram stain but are easily visualized on silver staining. The patient declines to be admitted to the hospital and is discharged home on appropriate pharmacotherapy. Two days later, the patient returns to the emergency department after an episode of syncope. The family noticed brief twitching while the patient was unconscious, but there is no current evidence of tongue bite or urinary or fecal incontinence. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this event?
questions.solution:
This patient’s episode of syncope most likely occurred due to azithromycin prescribed for the treatment of Legionella pneumonia (high-grade fever, headache, watery diarrhea, cough, and organisms visible on silver staining).  

Macrolides (e.g., azithromycin, erythromycin) have been reported to cause cardiac arrhythmias via QT prolongation, most likely by delaying the repolarizing potassium current via the blockade of voltage-gated potassium channels of the cardiomyocyte. QT prolongation can precipitate ventricular arrhythmias, resulting in syncope or cardiac arrest. Convulsions can be present briefly in syncope due to poor cerebral perfusion and do not always signify a seizure. Other adverse effects, including gastrointestinal intolerance (anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea) and the rare hypersensitivity-based acute cholestatic hepatitis, are widespread with erythromycin. Macrolides, except for azithromycin, also inhibit several forms of hepatic cytochrome P450 and can increase the plasma levels of many medications.



Option Analysis

❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Antiviral medications, including protease inhibitors (e.g. atazanavir), may prolong the QT interval, but no significant association has been found with the use of acyclovir. Moreover, Legionella pneumonia is treated with an antibacterial agent.
✅ Azithromycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Griseofulvin:
Incorrect: Although azoles (e.g. fluconazole) have been shown to prolong QT interval, griseofulvin and most other antifungal medications do not affect it.
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone and other beta-lactam antibiotics have not been shown to prolong the QT interval.
❌ Gentamicin:
Incorrect: Gentamicin has not been shown to prolong QT interval and is not used to manage Legionella pneumonia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of confusion, dyspnea, and cough with yellow sputum. The patient was seen in the clinic last week and diagnosed with a viral upper respiratory tract infection. Past medical history is significant for a prior episode of pneumonia due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Temperature is 40.1 C (104 F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 130/60 mmHg. Auscultation of lungs reveals bilateral diffuse rhonchi. Chest x-ray shows bilateral alveolar infiltrates in the midlung fields and several thin-walled cavities. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit and started on an intravenous antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit to prevent the formation of an initiation complex. Which of the following adverse effects is most likely associated with the long-term use of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient initially presented with a viral upper respiratory infection and has now developed secondary bacterial pneumonia with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. This patient was started on empiric therapy with linezolid which, if used for long-term, can lead to bone marrow suppression, especially thrombocytopenia.  

Linezolid belongs to the class oxazolidinones and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit to prevent initiation complex formation. Linezolid is active against most gram-positive organisms, including staphylococci, streptococci, and enterococci. It is often reserved for bacterial infections resistant to other antibiotics, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium (VRE). Resistance in enterococci and staphylococci is most commonly due to point mutations of the 23S rRNA. When used for short periods, linezolid is a safe drug, with minor side effects, like diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and rash. Long-term use is associated with the development of bone marrow suppression, peripheral neuropathy, and optic neuropathy. It is a weak nonspecific monoamine oxidase inhibitor and co-administration in patients taking selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). It is associated with the development of serotonin syndrome and should be avoided in such patients.  



Option Analysis

✅ Bone marrow suppression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prolonged QT interval:
Incorrect: Macrolides are associated with the development of prolonged QT interval and subsequent arrhythmia. They inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit and blocking translocation.
❌ Nephrotoxicity:
Incorrect: Nephrotoxicity is a known side effect of aminoglycosides that block the formation of initiation complex by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit, not 50S.
❌ Vitamin K deficiency:
Incorrect: Long-term use of cephalosporins can reduce the intestinal absorption of vitamin K leading to vitamin K deficiency and bleeding complications. They block bacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting transpeptidase.
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Long-term use of clindamycin can cause bacterial superinfection by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile leading to pseudomembranous colitis. It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking peptide transfer (translocation) at the 50S ribosomal subunit.

questions.text: A 50-year-old-man comes to the office for a follow-up. Two weeks ago, the patient was started on aspirin by his primary care physician for the primary prevention of coronary artery disease. Today, the patient reports difficulty maintaining sleep and waking up in the middle of the night due to shortness of breath and coughing attacks. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and seasonal allergies. Current medications include aspirin and lisinopril. After evaluation, the physician discontinues aspirin and starts the patient on a medication that directly inhibits the effects of leukotrienes. Which of the following is an example of this new medication?
questions.solution:
Soon after the initiation of aspirin, this patient's respiratory symptoms most likely resulted from aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). In addition to discontinuing aspirin, the patient should be started on a leukotriene receptor antagonist (e.g., montelukast or zafirlukast).    

Leukotriene receptor antagonists are oral medications that prevent leukotrienes from binding to their receptors in the smooth muscles of the respiratory airways, thereby weakening smooth muscle contraction, decreasing mucus secretion, and reducing inflammation. They are especially effective in preventing exercise or aspirin-induced asthma. They have a slower onset of action than inhaled bronchodilators, which is why they are used for asthma prophylaxis and not during an acute asthma attack.  

Since leukotriene receptor antagonists have mild, nonspecific side effects like headache and rash, they are given in combination with other asthma medications with more significant side effects like corticosteroids, which can cause immunosuppression, and long-acting beta-agonists, which can cause arrhythmias. Adding them to the regimen lowers the necessary dose of these more dangerous medications, which make montelukast and zafirlukast great supportive medications.  



Option Analysis

❌ Zileuton:
Incorrect: Although zileuton effectively manages aspirin-induced bronchospasms, it acts by inhibiting the 5-lipoxygenase enzyme rather than inhibiting leukotriene receptors.
✅ Zafirlukast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cromolyn sodium:
Incorrect: Cromolyn sodium stabilizes the membrane of mast cells and prevents its degranulation (release of histamine and leukotrienes). Although it is one of the treatment options for managing chronic asthma, it does not inhibit the leukotriene receptor.
❌ Tiotropium:
Incorrect:  Tiotropium binds to M3 muscarinic receptors on the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles, blocking acetylcholine binding, consequently leading to smooth muscle relaxation. It does not affect the leukotriene receptor.
❌ Albuterol:
Incorrect: Albuterol is a beta-2 (β2)-agonist that relaxes the airway smooth muscle cells. It does not inhibit the leukotriene receptor. It activates the enzyme adenylyl cyclase, leading to increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production that ultimately causes relaxation of the smooth muscles. It is usually used for symptomatic relief in patients with acute asthmatic exacerbation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office of her pulmonologist for a routine follow-up. The patient was recently hospitalized for an asthma exacerbation and had a history of poorly controlled asthma. It is her third hospitalization in the past five years. Past medical history is significant for psoriasis. Current medications include inhaled salmeterol and medium-dose inhaled budesonide with an as-needed albuterol inhaler. She does not smoke, drink or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral wheezes that are loudest at the bases. The physician decides to start the patient on zileuton. This medication will inhibit which steps in the pathway above?
questions.solution:
The patient with poorly controlled asthma is started on zileuton, a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes.    

Leukotrienes augment leukocytes’ migration, aggregation, and adhesion, which contribute to inflammation, edema, mucous secretion, and bronchoconstriction in the airways. Zileuton blocks the formation of leukotrienes, thereby preventing asthma attacks. It is sometimes used for asthma prophylaxis and is somewhat effective in preventing exercise or aspirin-induced asthma. It is hepatotoxic and, therefore, is used less frequently.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Cleavage of membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2 leads to the formation of arachidonic acid, which is converted into prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Corticosteroids inhibit phospholipase A2.
❌ B:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (e.g. aspirin) inhibit both cyclooxygenase isoforms (COX-1 and COX-2) and thereby decrease prostaglandin, prostacyclin, and thromboxane synthesis throughout the body. These medications have the potential to exacerbate bronchial reactivity by inhibiting prostacyclin synthesis.
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. These agents are used in chronic asthma prophylaxis.
❌ E:
Incorrect: Colchicine exerts its anti-inflammatory effects by inhibiting the polymerization of beta-tubulin into microtubules, thereby preventing migration and activation of neutrophils. It does not affect leukotriene synthesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She does not have a prior history of seizure disorder. Past medical history is significant for severe persistent asthma, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Five days ago, the patient was started on ciprofloxacin for a urinary tract infection. Her other medications include inhaled fluticasone/salmeterol combination, theophylline, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Her BMI is 37 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which medications is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has recently started on ciprofloxacin, likely developed theophylline toxicity and resultant seizure due to drug-drug interaction.  

Theophylline is an oral methylxanthine. It inhibits phosphodiesterase, converting cAMP into an inactive form called 5-AMP. Blocking this enzyme increases the cAMP level within the cell, causing smooth muscle relaxation in the bronchial airways. Blocking adenosine receptors throughout the body blocks adenosine typically increases smooth muscle contraction in the respiratory tract. This mechanism could explain some of its bronchodilator effects.  

Methylxanthines are metabolized by cytochrome p450. This medication is sometimes considered in patients with mild asthma or as an add-on long-term control medication in moderate to severe asthma after the failure of other medications. Its use in patients with COPD is controversial, with only a few studies showing improvement in functional impairment. However, theophylline is generally avoided because it has a narrow therapeutic index and is very easy to reach supratherapeutic levels. This could cause insomnia, nausea, and vomiting, but the most dangerous side effects include overstimulation of the central nervous and cardiovascular systems, leading to seizures and arrhythmias. Medications that inhibit these enzymes (e.g., fluoxetine or ciprofloxacin) should be avoided.

Option Analysis

❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. Its typical side effects include cough and angioedema. It is, however, not associated with the development of seizures.
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that inhibits NaCl reabsorption in the early distal convoluted tubule. Its significant side effects include hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hyponatremia, and hyperglycemia. It does not interact with ciprofloxacin and is unlikely to cause seizures.
✅ Theophylline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Salmeterol:
Incorrect: Salmeterol is a long-acting beta-agonist that relaxes bronchial smooth muscle by selective action on beta-2 receptors with little effect on heart rate. It acts locally in the lung. It does not interact with ciprofloxacin and is unlikely to cause seizures.
❌ Fluticasone:
Incorrect: Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid associated with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. It does not interact with ciprofloxacin and is unlikely to cause seizures.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman comes to the hospital for evaluation of intermittent episodes of chest pain that started four months ago. The patient reports that the chest pain is triggered by physical activity and improves with rest. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 150/75 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and BMI is 29 kg/m2. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. An ECG is performed and shown below. The patient is started on a medication for her chest pain and is counseled on its side effects, which include constipation, facial flushing, and gingival hyperplasia. This medication works via which of the following mechanisms of action?


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are a class of vasodilators or medications that promote dilation of blood vessels. These medications are most commonly used to treat hypertension, supraventricular tachycardia, and angina pectoris (also called stable angina), pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. Of note, this patient has chest pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest as well as a normal resting EKG, which is consistent with angina pectoris.    

As its name suggests, CCBs work by blocking voltage-gated calcium channels. This decreases the frequency with which calcium channels open, hence reducing calcium influx and intracellular calcium concentrations. In the sinoatrial node, CCBs are able to slow down cellular depolarization, which in turn decreases heart rate.    

Moreover, by reducing calcium influx, CCBs reduce calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, ultimately impairing muscle contractions. In the heart, this phenomenon causes decreased myocardial contractility as well as vasodilation of the coronary vessels.  

Ultimately, CCBs treat angina via two mechanisms: 1) decreasing the heart’s oxygen demand by reducing heart rate and contractility, and 2) increasing its oxygen supply via coronary artery vasodilation. Side effects of CCBs include peripheral edema, headaches, flushing, reflexive tachycardia, and gingival hyperplasia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Blockade of L-type calcium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stimulation of intracellular guanylyl cyclase:
Incorrect: Medications such as nitrates promote vasodilation via this mechanism. The activated guanylyl cyclases increase cGMP concentration, which in turn causes dephosphorylation of myosin light chains. As a result, light chains are unable to interact with actin and vasodilation occurs. While nitrates can be used to treat angina, they would not typically cause gingival hyperplasia
❌ Blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of class I antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., quinidine, lidocaine, propafenone). These medications can cause side effects ranging from thrombocytopenia to drug-induced lupus. However, class I antiarrhythmics are not used in the treatment of angina and would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.
❌  Inhibition of beta-adrenergic receptors:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers can be used to treat angina by decreasing heart rate and contractility, which in turn reduces myocardial oxygen demand. Side effects include bradycardia, bronchospasm, and fatigue. However, it would be atypical for beta-blockers to cause the side effects described in the question stem. 
❌ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of PDE-5 inhibitors, such as sildenafil. PDE-5 inhibitors can treat erectile dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Side effects include headaches, flushing, and dyspepsia. However, PDE-5 inhibitors are not involved in the treatment of stable angina and would not cause gum hypertrophy.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine evaluation. He has no acute complaints. On review of history, he endorses intermittent episodes of dizziness and palpitation, which he attributes to natural aging. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and asthma, for which he uses an albuterol inhaler. The patient consumes one pack of cigarettes per day. In the office, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 141/83 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. An EKG is performed and shown below. Cardiac exam reveals an irregular rhythm. The remainder of the physical exam is non-contributory. The patient is started on the first-line rate controlling medication for his condition. Which of the following best describes its mechanism of action?


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Reduction of signal conduction through atrioventricular node

questions.solution:
This patient has a history and EKG findings consistent with atrial fibrillation. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) are a class of vasodilators, or medications that promote dilation of blood vessels, that can be used as a first-line treatment for atrial fibrillation. CCBs can be subdivided into non-dihydropyridine and dihydropyridine CCBs.  

Non-dihydropyridine CCBs (e.g., verapamil, diltiazem) act predominantly at the heart but have minor vasodilatory properties. They are useful in treating tachyarrhythmias, angina, and hypertension. Non-dihydropyridine CCBs decrease SA node discharge rate (reduces heart rate), AV node discharge rate (terminates supraventricular tachycardia), and intracellular calcium (reduces cardiac contractility).  

Dihydropyridine CCBs (e.g., amlodipine, nifedipine) act predominantly at the smooth muscle of blood vessels. They are used to treat hypertension, Raynaud phenomenon, angina pectoris (via coronary artery vasodilation, which increases oxygen supply to cardiac myocytes), and prevent cerebral vasospasm.   


Option Analysis

❌ Relaxation of vascular smooth muscle:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the chief mechanism of action of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs), such as nifedipine and amlodipine. These medications can be used to treat hypertension, angina, Raynaud phenomenon, and prevent cerebral vasospasm after a subarachnoid hemorrhage. However, they are rarely used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.
❌ Selective inhibition of PDE-3 :
Incorrect: Milrinone works via this mechanism of action. Inhibition of PDE-3 leads to increased cAMP levels, which helps increase intracellular calcium and myocyte contractility. The medication is used to treat heart failure, but it is not used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.
❌ Inhibition of Na+/K+ ATPase pump:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes digoxin’s mechanism of action. Inhibition of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump leads to indirect inhibition of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. Digoxin ultimately increases intracellular calcium concentrations and cardiac myocyte contractility. However, digoxin is not used as the first-line treatment for atrial fibrillation.
✅ Reduction of signal conduction through atrioventricular node :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activation of intracellular guanylyl cyclase:
Incorrect: Medications such as nitrates promote vasodilation via this mechanism. The activated guanylyl cyclases increase cGMP concentration, which in turn causes dephosphorylation of myosin light chains. As a result, light chains are unable to interact with actin and vasodilation occurs. Nitrates are not used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of difficulty chewing. He reports his gums have become red, swollen, and painful. Past medical history is notable for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient takes multiple medications which his son helps him manage; thus he cannot remember the names of the medications. His younger brother has a history of idiopathic seizures that persisted into adulthood. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 160/89 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Physical exam reveals firm and painful nodular enlargement of the interdental papilla. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s physical exam findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has physical exam findings consistent with gingival hyperplasia, a side effect classically associated with dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs). The reason for this is that CCBs are also known to downregulate the degradation of connective tissue fibers; collagenase is essential to connective tissue breakdown, and calcium is essential to collagenase activation. By blocking cytoplasmic uptake of calcium, CCBs disrupt the tissue breakdown pathway. Of note, while gingival hyperplasia can present in patients taking either dihydropyridine or non-dihydropyridine CCBs, it is more strongly associated with dihydropyridine CCBs on board examinations.  

Additional side effects of dihydropyridine CCBs, which primarily act on vascular smooth muscle, include reflex tachycardia as well as flushing, dizziness, and peripheral edema secondary to vasodilation.  

Side effects of non-dihydropyridine CCBs, which primarily act on the heart, include bradycardia, constipation, and hyperprolactinemia.

Option Analysis

❌ Pravastatin:
Incorrect: Statins can treat hyperlipidemia by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase. Side effects may include hepatotoxicity and myopathy. However, statins would not cause the gingival hyperplasia observed in this patient. 
❌ Phenytoin:
Incorrect: Phenytoin is an anticonvulsant that works by inactivating sodium channels. The medication can cause gingival hyperplasia as a side effect. However, this patient has no history of seizures and hence it would be unlikely that he was prescribed phenytoin.
✅ Nifedipine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Losartan:
Incorrect: Losartan is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. ACE inhibitors are used in the treatment of hypertension and diabetic nephropathy. Side effects include angioedema, coughing, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. However, the medication would not account for the side effects experienced by this patient.
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB) that acts primarily on the heart. It can be used to treat tachyarrhythmias, angina, and hypertension. Although verapamil can cause gingival hyperplasia (prevalence: 4.2%), this side effect is more frequently seen in patients taking nifedipine (prevalence: 14%). In general, gingival hyperplasia occurs more frequently in patients taking dihydropyridine CCBs.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office because of vulvar pain and dysuria. She does not have increased urinary frequency or flank pain. She has never experienced similar symptoms before and her past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is sexually active and has had 4 sexual partners in the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Current medications include a combined oral contraceptive and a hair vitamin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows grouped shallow ulcers with erythema on the right labia majora. Right inguinal lymph nodes are tender to palpation. After further evaluation, the patient is started on an oral medication that requires a specific thymidine kinase for activation. Which of the following is an important adverse effect of the medication used in this patient when it is administered intravenously?
questions.solution:
This patient’s physical examination findings of grouped shallow genital ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy are consistent with herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Primary HSV infection is usually treated with acyclovir, which requires thymidine kinase for activation.  

Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that is effective against HSV-1, HSV-2, and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections. When used orally, it is only partially absorbed; therefore, it is used for mild mucocutaneous lesions and genital lesions or for herpes prophylaxis in immunocompromised individuals, such as individuals with AIDS. The oral drug is well tolerated but may cause gastrointestinal (GI) distress and headache. On the other hand, intravenous acyclovir is the treatment of more severe herpes infections, such as HSV encephalitis or neonatal HSV infection. Toxic effects of parenteral administration include delirium, tremor, seizures, hypotension, and nephrotoxicity (obstructive crystalline nephropathy and acute kidney injury). Acyclovir has no effect on latent forms of HSV and VZV. Resistance can involve changes in viral DNA polymerase or a mutation in viral thymidylate kinase.

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is an important side effect of ganciclovir, which is effective against cytomegalovirus. This patient most likely has an HSV infection.
❌ Pancreatitis:
Incorrect: Pancreatitis is an important side effect of didanosine, a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Didanosine is not effective against HSV.
✅ Obstructive crystalline nephropathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acute interstitial nephritis:
Incorrect: Acute interstitial nephritis is usually associated with exposure to beta-lactams and proton pump inhibitors. This patient’s HSV infection is most likely being treated with acyclovir.
❌ Disulfiram-like reaction:
Incorrect: Disulfiram-like reactions can occur commonly with metronidazole or griseofulvin, neither of which is effective against HSV.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a nearby clinic for evaluation of hypertension. At the clinic, his blood pressures were 184/124 mm Hg and 186/126 mm Hg on two separate readings. Past medical history is notable for chronic alcohol use, hypertension, and type I diabetes. Current medications include insulin, hydrochlorothiazide, and occasional ibuprofen for lower back pain associated with his occupation as a construction worker. The patient has been sober for 2 months. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 184/120 mm Hg. BMI is 18.5 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination is within normal limits. Blood alcohol concentration is 0. The patient is started on oral labetalol for blood pressure management. Blood work is performed to determine the serum concentration of the medication, and it is shown to be significantly elevated in comparison to that of other patients receiving a similar dose. Which of the following best explains the increased drug serum concentration in this patient?
questions.solution:
The route of administration and the dose of a drug has a significant impact on both the rate and extent of bioavailability. For example, an oral drug must pass through the gastrointestinal system, which makes it subject to intestinal absorption as well as hepatic first-pass metabolism. On the other hand, an intravenously (IV) delivered drug is immediately delivered to the systemic circulation and does not undergo the process of absorption or first-pass metabolism.

Following absorption across the intestinal wall, the portal blood delivers the drug to the liver prior to entry into systemic circulation. First-pass metabolism causes various drugs to be inactivated or turned into excretable metabolites, lessening the drug’s effects. Furthermore, underlying conditions in the patient can affect first-pass metabolism. For example, liver cirrhosis, which results in damage to liver enzymes, can reduce this process and lead to higher serum concentrations of certain drugs.

The first-pass effect can be mitigated by changing the route of administration. For instance, hepatic first-pass metabolism can be markedly decreased via the use of sublingual tablets, transdermal preparations, and rectal suppositories (a portion of the rectal blood flow empties into the iliac veins).  

Option Analysis

✅ Underlying liver cirrhosis   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Chronic malabsorption syndrome   :
Incorrect: Chronic malabsorption syndromes would cause a decrease in gastrointestinal absorption, and therefore, reduced serum concentrations. This patient’s elevated serum concentration is likely the result of decreased first-pass metabolism.   
❌ Uncontrolled diabetes   :
Incorrect: While uncontrolled diabetes can result in various comorbidities, it would not significantly alter the serum drug concentration. This patient’s elevated serum concentration is likely the result of decreased first-pass metabolism.   
❌ Lower body mass index   :
Incorrect: In patients with higher BMIs, lipophilic drugs can be taken up into adipose cells, resulting in a longer therapeutic effect. This patient’s lower BMI, however, would not result in this complication.   
❌ Drug-drug interaction   :
Incorrect: Some drugs that inhibit CYP activity (e.g., valproic acid, cimetidine) can cause decreased metabolism of substrates and result in increased serum concentration. This patient is not on any CYP inhibitors. As a result, this answer choice would not explain the patient’s elevated serum labetalol concentration.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of bleeding gums over the past 18 hours. After brushing her teeth in the morning, the patient noticed persistent oozing of blood from the gums. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation, for which she is taking appropriate medications. She recently visited her family doctor for evaluation of tinea versicolor and was started on an oral antifungal medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 136/84 mmHg, pulse is 92/min and irregularly irregular, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination is unremarkable except for oral examination, which reveals bleeding and mildly swollen gums. The patient’s international normalized ratio (INR) is 3.6 as compared to 2.2 two weeks earlier. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
The cytochrome P450 system is classified by similar gene sequences. Enzymes are assigned a family number (e.g., CYP1, CYP2), a subfamily letter (e.g., CYP1A, CYP2D), and a number for the isoform or individual enzyme (e.g., CYP1A1, CYP2D6). It is important to note that medications that share a common metabolism pathway may cause drug-drug interactions.

Typically, if a drug acts as a CYP inducer, then it causes concurrently administered drugs metabolized by the same CYP isozyme to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure.

In contrast, if a drug acts as a CYP inhibitor, then it causes other drugs to accumulate to toxic levels where overdoses and side effects may occur. For example, this patient, who was on warfarin and then developed increased bleeding despite no changes in warfarin dosing, was likely given a CYP inhibitor. The CYP inhibitor slowed the metabolism of warfarin, thereby increasing serum warfarin levels to supratherapeutic levels.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ketoconazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Griseofulvin:
Incorrect: Griseofulvin, an antifungal medication, is a CYP inducer, which causes medications to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure. In this patient’s case, CYP inducers in conjunction with warfarin would likely lead to subtherapeutic INR levels and subsequent episodes of strokes or other embolic phenomena.   
❌ Topical clotrimazole   :
Incorrect: Topical antifungals have minimal effect on the liver. These medications would be neither CYP inducers nor inhibitors.   
❌ Carbamazepine:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine, an antiepileptic medication, is a CYP inducer, which causes medications to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure. In this patient’s case, CYP inducers in conjunction with warfarin would likely lead to subtherapeutic INR levels and subsequent episodes of strokes or other embolic phenomena.   
❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: Rifampin, an antibacterial medication, is a CYP inducer, which causes medications to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure. In this patient’s case, CYP inducers in conjunction with warfarin would likely lead to subtherapeutic INR levels and subsequent episodes of strokes or other embolic phenomena.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of urinary incontinence. The patient has been waking up every morning with his underwear soaked in urine. He has noticed that if he does not take regular bathroom breaks at work, his underwear will have some urine in it. The patient urinates 8 to 11 times per day, with each episode producing small volumes of urine. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 167/108 mmHg. Physical examination reveals decreased pinprick sensation in the lower extremities. The patient is prescribed bethanechol. Which of the following complications is this patient most at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a neurogenic bladder secondary to long-standing type II diabetes mellitus. He is prescribed bethanechol, which is a cholinomimetic agent. The medication can cause peripheral vasodilation and subsequent reflex tachycardia.

Other adverse effects associated with the use of direct cholinomimetics includes central nervous system stimulation (e.g. anxiety, restlessness), miosis, bronchoconstriction, excessive gastrointestinal and genitourinary smooth muscle activity, and increased secretory activity (e.g. increased sweat production).

Option Analysis

❌ Constipation:
Incorrect: Bethanechol is a cholinomimetic that stimulates muscarinic receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and facilitates peristalsis. It can potentially cause diarrhea due to a sudden increase in motility. In contrast, constipation can be caused by anticholinergic agents such as atropine.  
✅ Reflex tachycardia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dry mouth:
Incorrect: Anticholinergic agents can cause dry mouth secondary to decreased salivary gland activity. In contrast, cholinomimetics such as bethanechol stimulate the salivary glands and increase salivation.  
❌ Muscle spasm:
Incorrect: Muscle spasms can be caused by cholinergic drugs that activate nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the skeletal neuromuscular junction (e.g., succinylcholine). Although bethanechol is a cholinergic agent, it acts only on muscarinic receptors and will not cause muscle spasms.  
❌ Mydriasis:
Incorrect: Mydriasis can be caused by anticholinergic agents such as atropine, which inhibit the contraction of the pupillary sphincter muscles. In contrast, the parasympathetic action of bethanechol on the eyes would cause miosis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic with fever, headache, and purulent nasal discharge for the last two days. She does not have a cough, dyspnea, ear discharge, or sore throat. Her past medical history includes type 1 diabetes and allergic rhinitis. The patient was discharged from the hospital two days ago where she was admitted for treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis. The patient does not consume alcohol or use tobacco products. She uses cocaine occasionally, and her last use was four days ago. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Nasal examination reveals a black eschar over the nasal mucosa. Physical examination reveals periorbital edema.  She is admitted to the inpatient ward and initiated on an antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol to create micropores and increase cellular permeability. On day 9, she develops palpitations with an associated ECG as shown below. Which of the following findings would be expected on further evaluation?  


James Heilman, MD / CC BY-SA , Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient has a presentation suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis and is initiated on a medication that targets the fungal cell wall to create micropores–descriptive of amphotericin B, the treatment of choice for mucormycosis rhinosinusitis. Following treatment, she develops palpitations and ECG changes that include ST segment depression and T wave inversions (U-waves) indicative of amphotericin-induced hypokalemia.    

Amphotericin B can induce nephrotoxicity via tubular injury and vasoconstriction, which ultimately results in hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, and the RTA (normal anion gap acidosis). In fungal cells, amphotericin B binds to ergosterol, a component of the fungal cell membrane, and creates micropores. Similarly, it binds to cholesterol in host cell membranes (with lesser affinity) and increases membrane permeability. As a result, membrane electrochemical gradients are reduced, particularly between the renal tubular cells and the lumen. Potassium subsequently moves down this concentration gradient, resulting in a loss of potassium and limitated hydrogen ion secretion. Renal magnesium loss can also occur secondary to amphotericin nephrotoxicity.    

Acute kidney injury is typically the first sign of amphotericin B induced nephrotoxicity. Normally, as the sodium chloride delivery to the distal tubule increases, more NaCl diffuses into the macula densa. Tubuloglomerular feedback is initiated and afferent arteriole vasoconstriction occurs to limit NaCl losses. With amphotericin B use, permeability of macula densa cells increases and results in profound afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction, a fall in GFR, and a subsequent rise in creatinine.  

In order to limit amphotericin B associated nephrotoxicity, lipid formulations (liposomal and lipid complex) are used. Salt loading or volume expansion has also been found to be effective in limiting the fall in GFR as it reduces the sensitivity of the tubuloglomerular feedback system. Preventive measures to reduce nephrotoxicity include administering lower doses and avoiding co-administration of other nephrotoxic agents such as aminoglycosides or cyclosporine. Other adverse effects include fever, chills, and body aches. Intrathecal injections for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis can cause seizures, headache, and nerve palsies.

Option Analysis

✅ Hypokalemia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wide anion gap metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: A wide anion gap metabolic acidosis is frequently associated with ethylene glycol or salicylate use, diabetic ketoacidosis, and methanol poisoning. In the setting of amphotericin B, a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis is more likely to occur secondary to its nephrotoxic effects. 
❌ Hypermagnesemia :
Incorrect: Amphotericin B use causes nephrotoxicity via direct renal tubular injury. This results in magnesium wasting and associated hypomagnesemia as opposed to hypermagnesemia. 
❌ Hyperkalemia :
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia is characterized by peaked T waves, prolonged PR intervals, widened QRS complexes, and sine wave patterns. The given ECG shows “U-wave” changes that are more suggestive of hypokalemia. In the setting of amphotericin administration, hypokalemia secondary to renal toxicity is much more likely. 
❌ Increase in GFR :
Incorrect: Amphotericin induces impairment in tubuloglomerular feedback. This causes profound afferent arteriole vasoconstriction, a rise in creatine, and a fall in GFR.

questions.text:
A 36- year-old woman presents to the clinic with a fever, malaise, and headache for two weeks. She has been sexually active with her partner for one year. Her past medical history includes untreated HIV. The patient drinks 4-5 beers daily and uses both cocaine and marijuana. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. An LP and India ink stain reveal evidence of cryptococcal meningitis, and the patient is initiated on appropriate antifungal therapy. One week later, her laboratory investigations reveal the findings below. Which of the following is the pharmacological agent responsible for this patient’s condition?

Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin      9  g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  4,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  90,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient has cryptococcal meningitis and develops leukopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia following initiation of antifungal therapy. The treatment of choice for cryptococcal meningitis includes induction therapy consisting of liposomal amphotericin B and flucytosine. A major adverse effect associated with flucytosine therapy is bone marrow suppression.    

Flucytosine is an antifungal agent that inhibits both DNA and RNA biosynthesis by deaminating 5-fluorocytosine to 5-fluorouracil, resulting in fungal cell death. It also prevents protein synthesis by a separate mechanism involving the incorporation of a 5-FU metabolite into fungal RNA. Indications for flucytosine use (in combination with other antifungal agents) include severe cryptococcal meningitis, meningoencephalitis, and severe candidiasis.  



Adverse effects of flucytosine are primarily hematological, hepatic, and gastrointestinal. In particular, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia are dose-limiting complications.


Option Analysis

❌ Terbinafine:
Incorrect: Terbinafine use is associated with hepatotoxicity and gastrointestinal disturbances. It is not indicated in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis and does not induce bone marrow suppression. 
❌ Griseofulvin :
Incorrect: Griseofulvin use is limited to the treatment of superficial dermatophyte infections. Adverse effects include gastrointestinal disturbances, headache, photosensitivity, and hypersensitivity. It is not indicated in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis. 
❌ Fluconazole :
Incorrect: Fluconazole is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis as a component of consolidation therapy. Hepatic injury following azole use is common and can range from mild elevation of transaminases to hepatitis. 
❌ Amphotericin B :
Incorrect: Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis that is highly nephrotoxic. Flucytosine is a more likely cause of bone marrow failure. 
✅ Flucytosine :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic due to 2 months of clumsiness, progressive weakness, and personality changes. She also states that her left hand seems to move involuntarily on sporadic occasions. This patient had been treated with rituximab for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is associated with person and place, but not time. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hyperreflexia and upgoing plantar reflex. MRI is shown below. Which of the following is the likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Venous hemorrhage of the bridging veins

questions.solution:
This patient had originally been diagnosed with non- Hodgkin’s lymphoma, treated with rituximab, then developed neurological symptoms of clumsiness, progressive weakness, and personality change. Additionally, this patient shows characteristic symptoms of “alien hand syndrome,” wherein the patient experiences involuntary limb movement. These findings are characteristic of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a complication of treatment with rituximab.   

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20, a marker of B cells. This makes rituximab a common treatment for B cell lymphomas such as non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, rheumatoid arthritis, and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). An important side effect of rituximab therapy is increasing the likelihood of PML. PML is a progressive inflammatory disease of the white matter.
