❌ Tizanidine:
Incorrect: Tizanidine is an ɑ2-receptor agonist used to manage muscle spasticity. Side effects include hypotension, weakness, and xerostomia. In contrast, this patient’s nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and excessive sweating are unlikely to be caused by tizanidine.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Side effects of β-blockers include erectile dysfunction, cardiovascular complications (e.g., bradycardia, AV block, heart failure exacerbation), as well as asthma and COPD exacerbations. Nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and excessive sweating are not seen.  
❌ Fluoxetine :
Incorrect: Fluoxetine can occasionally cause nausea, diarrhea, and excessive sweating. However, it is unlikely this patient was prescribed fluoxetine, given her symptoms are most consistent with myasthenia gravis.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of retrosternal chest pain. The pain started 4 hours ago while playing soccer with his grandson. The pain radiates to his left arm and jaw and is not associated with breathing or positional change. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. Current medications include insulin, enalapril, and sildenafil, and he reports taking all medications earlier this morning. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 3-4 beers on weekends. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 69/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and SaO2 is 95% on pulse oximetry. An electrocardiogram is shown below. Administration of which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with acute onset retrosternal chest pain for 4 hours and ECG findings of ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads is most likely suffering from anterior wall acute myocardial infarction. Nitroglycerin is contraindicated in this patient due to its adverse interaction with sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor (part of his current medication regimen) which can precipitate severe hypotension.  

The primary mechanism of action of nitrates involves decreasing cardiac preload by venodilation and a minor decrease in afterload by vasodilation of arterial beds. This is achieved by promoting the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), which causes smooth muscle relaxation via protein kinase G. Sildenafil, on the other hand, inhibits phosphodiesterase- 5, the enzyme necessary for the breakdown of cGMP. This results in the accumulation of cGMP, leading to excessive vasodilation and hypotension when used in combination with nitrates. If prescribed together, both drugs should be ingested at least 24-48 hours apart.  

Other contraindications to nitrates include bradycardia, right ventricular infarction (due to decreased preload), hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (due to increased outflow obstruction), and severe aortic stenosis. Common side effects include flushing, headache, orthostatic hypotension, and reflex tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory drug administered in all patients with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Its early administration is associated with decreased cardiovascular mortality rate and decreased incidence of re-infarction and stroke. It has no interaction with any drugs the patient is currently on.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol, a β1-antagonist, is administered in nearly all patients with acute STEMI to relieve chest pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce cardiac workload (thereby preserving infarcted myocardial cells); contraindications of use include patients with a STEMI who also have symptoms of heart failure (elevated JVD, crackles on lung auscultation, audible S3). Contraindications of beta-blockers include heart failure, bradycardia, and reactive airway disease.  
❌ Enoxaparin:
Incorrect: Enoxaparin, low molecular weight heparin, is indicated in ACS to prevent intraluminal clot extension, formation, and re-infarction. It should be avoided in patients with contraindicated anticoagulants (history of cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, intracranial neoplasm, recent thromboembolic stroke).  
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is indicated in ACS for persistent chest pain. It provides analgesia and lowers the adrenergic drive, reducing vascular resistance and afterload on the heart and reducing infarct size. It is not contraindicated in this patient.  
✅ Nitroglycerin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a cough and shortness of breath. He states that these symptoms have been gradually worsening, but recently, he woke up in the middle of the night suddenly feeling short of breath. He sleeps in a recliner because he gets short of breath while lying flat. Past medical history of obesity and hypertension, which is currently not treated. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 187/108 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 98% in room air. Physical examination shows mild jugular venous distention. Mild bibasilar crackles are noted on chest auscultation. Which of the following substances will be produced in the small pulmonary vessels in response to this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with cough and shortness of breath, jugular venous distension, and bibasilar crackles are suggestive of decompensated heart failure. The decrease in cardiac output leads to renal hypoperfusion and the subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).    

When blood pressure is low, blood flow to the kidneys decreases. The kidneys respond by secreting renin into the bloodstream. Renin is a proteolytic enzyme that breaks down a protein made in the liver called angiotensinogen, and this gives rise to angiotensin I. When angiotensin I reaches the lungs, angiotensin I is converted into angiotensin II by an enzyme called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in the pulmonary vessels. Angiotensin II binds to receptors in vascular smooth muscle and causes them to constrict, which increases the blood pressure. Finally, angiotensin II also stimulates the release of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone increases the reabsorption of sodium in the kidneys, which also increases water reabsorption. This results in increased blood volume, which also increases blood pressure.  



Option Analysis

❌ Renin:
Incorrect: Renin is secreted by the juxtaglomerular cells in the kidney in response to decreased cardiac output leading to renal hypoperfusion.  
❌ Angiotensin I:
Incorrect: Angiotensinogen is converted to angiotensin I in the systemic circulation via the action of renin.   
✅ Angiotensin II:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aldosterone:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II acts on the adrenal glands to stimulate the production and release of aldosterone, which acts on the collecting duct of the nephron to retain sodium and water.  
❌ Prostaglandin E1:
Incorrect: Prostaglandins are produced by endothelial cells, macrophages, and mast cells. It acts on the afferent arterioles of the nephron to cause vasodilation.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man comes to his primary care physician to evaluate a fluttering sensation in his chest. This symptom has been present for many years. He has decided to seek medical care after a friend recently passed away from a “heart condition.” Past medical history is notable for hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, and osteoarthritis. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown below. The patient is started on a drug that may cause dyspepsia, gastritis, and increased bleeding risk as side effects. Which of the following best describes this drug’s mechanism of action?
 

 Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Inactivation of free and clot-associated thrombin

questions.solution:
This patient has atrial fibrillation and risk factors for thromboembolism, such as old age and a history of hypertension and peripheral vascular disease. The patient should be started on an anticoagulant for stroke prophylaxis. He was most likely started on a direct thrombin inhibitor, which can cause gastritis, dyspepsia, and increased bleeding risk as side effects.

Direct thrombin inhibitors can be administered intravenously (e.g., bivalirudin, lepirudin, argatroban), orally (e.g., dabigatran), or subcutaneously (e.g. desirudin). They are not as frequently used as heparin. However, they can be a second-line medication in patients with deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. They can also be used for stroke prophylaxis in patients with atrial fibrillation and in combination with antiplatelet agents to prevent clot formation in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention. Moreover, direct thrombin inhibitors are beneficial when heparin causes heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, and the patient needs to be switched to an alternative anticoagulant.

In terms of toxicity, direct thrombin inhibitors are associated with hypersensitivity reactions, gastrointestinal symptoms such as dyspepsia and gastritis, and increased bleeding risk in the setting of an overdose.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of γ-carboxylation of clotting factors:
Incorrect: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX; and X proteins C and S. Warfarin can cause transient protein C and S deficiency, resulting in short-term hypercoagulability. Hence, an alternative anticoagulant (e.g. heparin) should be started before bridging to warfarin.  
❌ Activation of antithrombin III  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes heparin’s mechanism of action. Heparin can cause an increased risk of bleeding, osteoporosis, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. However, the medication would not typically cause dyspepsia or gastritis.  
❌ Blockade of platelet P2Y12 receptors:
Incorrect: ADP receptor inhibitors, such as clopidogrel and prasugrel, work via this mechanism of action. The medications cause increased bleeding risk and gastrointestinal irritation. However, anticoagulants (e.g., heparin, direct thrombin inhibitors, factor Xa inhibitors) are more effective than antiplatelet agents in preventing thromboembolic events in patients with atrial fibrillation.  
❌ Direct inhibition of factor Xa:
Incorrect: Direct factor Xa inhibitors, such as apixaban and rivaroxaban, can be used for thromboembolism prophylaxis in patients with atrial fibrillation. While these medications increase bleeding risk, they do not typically cause gastritis or dyspepsia.  
✅ Inactivation of free and clot-associated thrombin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old is undergoing anesthetic induction for a coronary artery bypass operation. The patient is given inhaled anesthetic gas, intubated, sedated with propofol, and placed on the ventilator. While the surgeon is preparing for thoracotomy, the anesthesia team initiates placement of a triple lumen catheter in the right internal jugular vein. The patient receives an injection of bupivacaine between the heads of the sternocleidomastoid for analgesia, and needle aspiration is performed under ultrasound guidance to confirm placement in the internal jugular vein. During cannulation, the patient is noted to become progressively cyanotic. The patient's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 132/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 84% on 100% FIO2. Physical examination demonstrates pale, gray skin, lips, and nail beds. Cardiopulmonary exam demonstrates bilateral breath sounds and normal S1, S2 without murmurs, rubs or gallops. A stat electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus tachycardia and an image of the patient's blood gas sample is demonstrated below.   Which of the following best describes the most likely precipitant of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Oxidation of iron in heme from Ferrous (Fe2+) to ferric (Fe3+) state
Thromboembolism originating in the deep femoral vein
Inhibition of voltage gated Na+ channels and cardiac conduction blockade
Leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air spaces
Mediastinal shift and impairment of venous outflow

questions.solution:
This patient rapidly develops cyanosis, tachycardia, and hypoxemia despite adequate ventilation. An arterial blood gas sample demonstrates the classic chocolate colored blood, indicative of methemoglobinemia, a known side effect of local anesthetics.   

Local anesthetics, while generally safe, do carry a range of side effects that carry significant morbidity and mortality. These medications are commonly used for nerve blocks, minor skin procedures, or prior to placement of indwelling catheters due to their ability to reversibly block voltage gated sodium channels, thereby impeding conduction in pain fibers.  

Side effects of local anesthetics include both central nervous system and cardiovascular toxicity. In particular, the medication bupivacaine is well known for inducing CNS depression at low doses and CNS excitotoxicity such as tremor, convulsions or seizures at higher doses. The cardiovascular side effect profile results from the ability of local anesthetics to bind fast Na+ channels in cardiac myocytes--resulting in reduction of cardiac contractility and arrhythmia generation. The one exception to this cardiac side effect profile is cocaine, which actually stimulates myocytes and increases contractility. Lastly, all local anesthetics (especially benzocaine) are known to induce methemoglobinemia when injected or applied topically. Exposure to the anesthetic agent results in the oxidation of iron found in heme from the ferrous (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) state. The ferric form of heme cannot bind oxygen, resulting in profound cyanosis, and an inability to oxygenate despite adequate ventilation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Oxidation of iron in heme from Ferrous (Fe2+) to ferric (Fe3+) state:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thromboembolism originating in the deep femoral vein:
Incorrect: A massive pulmonary embolism presents with hypotension, tachycardia and failure to oxygenate despite adequate ventilation. This patient is without unilateral lower extremity swelling making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, the change in color of blood to chocolate brown is indicative of methemoglobinemia.   
❌ Inhibition of voltage gated Na+ channels and cardiac conduction blockade:
Incorrect: Local anesthetics have been known to induce cardiac arrhythmias via fast sodium channel blockade and induction of subsequent cardiac arrhythmia. This patient’s telemetry strip demonstrates sinus tachycardia.    
❌ Leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air spaces:
Incorrect: ARDS or acute respiratory distress syndrome is characterized by leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air space. This disease is characterized by bilateral, interstitial, non-cardiogenic edema following an acute insult and a PaO2/FIO2 <300.  
❌ Mediastinal shift and impairment of venous outflow:
Incorrect: A tension pneumothorax can result in mediastinal shift and subsequent impairment of venous outflow. Tension pneumothorax presents with diminished breath sounds, jugular venous distension, hypotension, hypoxia, and tachycardia.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of trauma to his right thumb. The patient was playing with his brother when he accidentally slammed the door on the patient’s thumb. Physical exam shows the patient has an avulsion injury of the right thumbnail. In order to repair the injury without significant pain, the emergency physician performs a digital block via injection of xylocaine at the base of the right thumb. Which of the following types of nerve fibers anesthetized during this procedure are most susceptible to blockade by the aforementioned medication?
questions.solution:
This patient undergoes a peripheral nerve block with xylocaine for repair of a nail avulsion injury to the right thumb. When considering the type of nerve fibers best anesthetized by local anesthetics, the size factor predominates over myelination such that small myelinated fibers are most sensitive to these medications.      

Local anesthetics inlude medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. Local anesthetics are most effective at blocking fast firing nerves--e.g. smaller fibers. Myelinated fibers are blocked more easily than unmyelinated fibers. In the setting of two fibers with equal degrees of myelination, the smaller fiber will be more sensitive to local anesthesia.      

In accordance with this pattern, the degree of sensation loss after administration of local anesthetics includes pain first, followed by temperature, touch, and finally pressure. In addition, pain firing fibers tend to be located more superficially in tissues, such that fibers located in the periphery of a thick nerve bundle are blocked faster than those in the core because they are exposed to higher concentrations of anesthetic.  

Option Analysis

✅  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  2 µm  ++++ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Diameter  Degree of Myelination  15 µm ++++ :
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type A alpha nerve fibers, which conduct proprioception and motor movements. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall low sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  8 µm  ++++ :
Incorrect:  These measurements are indicative of Type A beta nerve fibers, which conduct the sensation of touch and pressure. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall moderate sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  6 µm +++:
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type A gamma nerve fibers, which innervate muscle spindles. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall moderate sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  .5 µm-:
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type C dorsal root ganglion fibers, which conduct pain. This type of pain fiber is small and unmyelinated, and has a high sensitivity to blockade via administration of local anesthetics. However, given the anatomic location of the aforementioned procedure, these fibers would not be blocked.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for evaluation of a boil on his upper back. The patient initially had a small comeodone that he scratched, and it subsequently progressed to become larger and more painful over the past week. The patient has a history of multiple sclerosis and takes baclofen daily for treatment of muscle spasms. The patient has an allergy to tetracaine, and broke out in hives when having a laceration repaired several years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a 2 cm x 2 cm fluctuant abscess over the thoracic spine. The patient is subsequently injected with bupivacaine subcutaneously, directly over the area of highest fluctuance in preparation for incision and drainage. A stab incision is made over the anesthetized area; however, the patient reports significant pain despite administration of bupivacaine. Which of the following best describes the etiology of the phenomenon described above?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of an upper back abscess and has a local amide anesthetic injected prior to incision and drainage. Unfortunately, this provider did not adequately assess for post-injection analgesia – which was poorly controlled in this patient, likely due to injection into acidic tissue.    

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials.   

These medications are inherently weak organic bases that are composed of charged and uncharged forms when in solution–only the uncharged forms are able to exert effects on sodium channels. In acidic solutions (such as in infected tissue), lower pH reduces the proportion of anesthetic in the uncharged form according to Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, resulting in decreased ability for the anesthetic to penetrate the neuronal membrane. Ultimately, this results in more anesthetic required to anesthetize this type of tissue. 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased acidity of injected tissue :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Localized allergic reaction :
Incorrect: While this patient has an allergy to ester anesthetics, he is provided with an amide anesthetic, bupivacaine. This patient's clinical presentation is not consistent with an allergy reaction.  
❌ Medication interaction :
Incorrect: Baclofen does not interact with administration of local anesthetics.   
❌ Poor injection technique :
Incorrect: The provider described in this vignette used adequate technique for local anesthesia--the issue was likely injecting an insufficient amount of anesthetic.   
❌ Degradation of injected medication :
Incorrect: Local anesthetics are not degraded when injected into acidic tissue--they can degrade over time if left out, especially in sunlight environments.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the office because of increased urinary frequency and burning with urination for the past 2 days. She has mild lower abdominal discomfort but no abnormal vaginal discharge. The patient has a history of two similar episodes in the past that resolved spontaneously. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in the patient’s father. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.5 F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals mild lower abdominal tenderness. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urine is sent for culture and sensitivity, and the patient is started on empiric treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. This drug inhibits which of the following processes in the bacterial cell?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from acute cystitis and is treated empirically with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, also referred to as TMP-SMX, and is one of the commonly prescribed agents for the treatment of simple urinary tract infection.  

TMP-SMX are antimetabolites that inhibit bacterial replication by blocking the two successive steps in folic acid metabolism: sulfamethoxazole (a sulfonamide) is a structural analog of p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and competes with it for the active site of the enzyme dihydropteroate synthetase (DHPS) in the first step of folate synthesis and prevents the bacteria from making dihydropteroic acid.    

Trimethoprim inhibits the third step of folate synthesis by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), preventing the formation of tetrahydrofolic acid (THF).    

Each of these drugs is bacteriostatic when used alone, but a combination of trimethoprim plus sulfamethoxazole is bactericidal for E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterobacter, Salmonella, and Shigella.  





Option Analysis

❌ Peptidoglycan cross-linking:
Incorrect: Bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan cross-linking is inhibited by penicillin, cephalosporins, carbapenems, and monobactams. TMP-SMX is a sulfonamide combination.  
✅ Bacterial folate metabolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial DNA unwinding:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones prevent DNA gyrase and topoisomerase from unwinding the bacterial double-stranded DNA. Although it can be used for the treatment of uncomplicated cystitis, it is usually preferred when other agents are not available or ineffective.  
❌ mRNA synthesis:
Incorrect: Rifampin inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which is responsible for mRNA synthesis. It is one of the main components of the anti-tuberculosis treatment regime. It is not, however, indicated in the treatment of lower urinary tract infections.  
❌ Peptidoglycan synthesis:
Incorrect: Vancomycin inhibits cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. It is effective against resistant gram-positive infections (e.g., MRSA) and should not be used to empirically treat a lower urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A scientist is studying the side effects and mechanisms of action of different drugs used to treat hypertension. The scientist identifies a drug inhibiting norepinephrine storage by blocking vesicular monoamine oxidase transporters in the central and peripheral nervous systems. Which of the following medications was most likely identified?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action described in the question stem is most consistent with that of reserpine, a presynaptic adrenergic antagonist.

Reserpine and other presynaptic adrenergic antagonists affect the synthesis and release of norepinephrine. Norepinephrine is synthesized in presynaptic neurons. The first step in this process involves tyrosine, a precursor of norepinephrine, being transported into the noradrenergic nerve terminal by a Na+-dependent carrier. Tyrosine is converted to DOPA by tyrosine hydroxylase. DOPA is then converted to dopamine. Afterward, dopamine is transported into synaptic vesicles with assistance from vesicular monoamine oxidase transporters (VMAT). Within the vesicles, dopamine is converted by dopamine β-hydroxylase into norepinephrine. Whenever the appropriate signal travels down the axon to the axon terminal, these vesicles fuse with the presynaptic membrane, enabling norepinephrine to release into the synaptic cleft and bind to adrenergic receptors of the postsynaptic neuronal membrane.

The drug reserpine primarily works by blocking VMAT, inhibiting dopamine transport from the neuron cytoplasm into the synaptic vesicles. Guanethidine, another adrenergic antagonist, accumulates in the synaptic vesicles, displacing norepinephrine and depleting presynaptic norepinephrine stores. Both reserpine and guanethidine were historically used to treat hypertension. However, they are mainly obsolete nowadays due to their poor absorption, slow metabolism, and side effect profile. Finally, there is metyrosine, which inhibits tyrosine hydroxylase and prevents the conversion of tyrosine to DOPA. Metyrosine is used to manage blood pressure in individuals with pheochromocytoma.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Guanethidine:
Incorrect: Guanethidine inhibits norepinephrine release. It directly competes with norepinephrine for reuptake at the presynaptic terminal. It then enters the presynaptic nerve and accumulates in the synaptic vesicles, where it displaces norepinephrine. Guanethidine blocks the fusion of synaptic vesicles with the presynaptic membrane, preventing norepinephrine release into the synaptic cleft.  
❌ Metyrosine:
Incorrect: Metyrosine prevents the synthesis of norepinephrine by inhibiting tyrosine hydroxylase, which is involved in the first step of catecholamine synthesis.  
✅ Reserpine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amphetamine:
Incorrect: Amphetamines are non-catecholamine sympathomimetic amines that promote the release of catecholamines (primarily dopamine and norepinephrine) from their storage sites in the presynaptic nerve terminals. Less commonly, amphetamines can block the reuptake of catecholamines through competitive inhibition.  
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Cocaine is a central nervous system stimulant and a local anesthetic. Central nervous system effects are mediated primarily through presynaptic norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin reuptake blockade.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office after noticing bright red blood in her sputum this morning. The patient has had a fever, chest pain, and productive cough for the last 3 days. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and chronic myelogenous leukemia. She underwent a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation 8 weeks ago, which was complicated by acute graft-versus-host disease and prolonged neutropenia. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals left-sided crackles. A complete blood profile shows a hematocrit of 25% and a leukocyte count of 1,400/mm<sup>3</sup>. A CT scan of the chest reveals several nodular lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities in the left upper lobe. A combination of voriconazole and caspofungin is started. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of caspofungin?

choices.text: Conversion to 5-fluorouracil and subsequent inhibition of nucleic acid biosynthesis
Interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis
Binds ergosterol to form membrane pores that allow leakage electrolytes
Prevents cell wall synthesis by inhibiting beta-1,3-D-glucan synthase
Inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase

questions.solution:
This patient presents with chest pain, fever, and hemoptysis in combination with a history of immunosuppression and the classic “halo sign” on chest imaging. These findings are suggestive of invasive aspergillosis. Patients are usually treated with a combination of intravenous voriconazole and an echinocandin (e.g., caspofungin, anidulafungin, micafungin).

Echinocandins are antifungal medications that non-competitively bind and inhibit beta-1,3-D-glucan synthase, thereby preventing cell wall synthesis and repair. The cell wall gradually deforms until it ruptures, causing the fungal cell to die.

Echinocandis are only available via the intravenous route since they are not well absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract.

Echinocandins are used to treat fungal infections resistant to the more common antifungal medications like amphotericin-B and the azoles. Common indications include mucocutaneous candidiasis, disseminated candidiasis, and invasive aspergillosis.

Adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal upset, as well as facial flushing and rash due to histamine release. It is generally approved for use in children and the elderly, but not in pregnant or lactating women.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Conversion to 5-fluorouracil and subsequent inhibition of nucleic acid biosynthesis:
Incorrect: Flucytosine is an antifungal agent that is converted to the antimetabolite 5-fluorouracil by cytosine deaminase in fungal cells, where it inhibits DNA synthesis. Flucytosine is usually used in combination with amphotericin B or an azole for treatment of severe systemic infections, such as candidiasis and cryptococcal meningitis. In contrast, caspofungin works via a different mechanism of action.  
❌ Interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis:
Incorrect: Griseofulvin interferes with fungal microtubule function and disrupts mitosis. It deposits in keratin-containing tissues (e.g. nails) and is used to treat superficial fungal infections.  
❌ Binds ergosterol to form membrane pores that allow leakage electrolytes:
Incorrect: Nystatin and amphotericin B bind ergosterol in fungal cell membranes to form membrane pores that allow for the leakage of electrolytes. In contrast, caspofungin works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ Prevents cell wall synthesis by inhibiting beta-1,3-D-glucan synthase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase:
Incorrect: Terbinafine inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, thereby decreasing the synthesis of ergosterol from squalene and increasing cellular membrane permeability. It is typically used in the management of dermatophyte infections, especially onychomycosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after an episode of unconsciousness. Her son witnessed the event that occurred an hour ago when the patient was eating dinner. The patient slumped over the dining table and woke up spontaneously after about 30 seconds. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease, hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and Alzheimer disease.  Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg while sitting, and 122/75 mmHg while standing. Physical examination is within normal limits. The patient is admitted for observation and is found to have episodic bradyarrhythmia and atrioventricular heart block. Which medication is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s brief loss of consciousness is suggestive of syncope and most likely resulted from the use of donepezil, an acetylcholinesterase (AchE) inhibitor.  

 In Alzheimer disease, acetylcholine levels are decreased, especially at a location called the basal nucleus of Meynert. Since AchE inhibitors (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) inhibit the enzyme acetylcholinesterase from breaking down the neurotransmitter acetylcholine into choline and acetate, it thereby increases both the level and duration of action of acetylcholine in the central nervous system, autonomic ganglia and neuromuscular junctions, resulting in some improvement in symptoms. These are the first-line treatment options for Alzheimer disease.  

Side effects include symptoms of cholinergic toxicity, including gastrointestinal symptoms (upset stomach, nausea, diarrhea, anorexia), miosis, urination, and bronchospasms, as well as increased secretions leading to salivation, lacrimation, and sweating. Bradycardia, heart block, and syncope can arise due to enhanced vagal tone.  



Option Analysis

❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an antihypertensive drug that may contribute to orthostatic hypotension (syncope after standing), another possible syncope etiology, unlike this patient’s syncope secondary to arrhythmia. Additionally, this patient’s vital signs do not demonstrate orthostatic hypotension, an unlikely cause of syncope in this patient.  
❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that may cause headache, diarrhea, constipation, or flatulence. It does not slow the conduction of impulses in the heart.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: Metformin is known to cause gastrointestinal disturbances, lactic acidosis, and vitamin B12 deficiency.  It does not slow the conduction of impulses in the heart.  
✅ Donepezil:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atorvastatin:
Incorrect: Atorvastatin is known to cause hepatotoxicity and myopathy, especially in combination with fibrates and niacin, but does not slow the conduction of impulses in the heart.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found confused at home with scattered pill bottles at the bedside. Past medical history is notable for depression, anxiety, and peripheral neuropathy. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), respirations are 22/min, pulse is 109/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg.  Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, mydriasis, and urinary retention. An electrocardiogram demonstrates QT prolongation. A medication overdose is suspected, and the patient is empirically administered ammonium chloride to enhance renal drug excretion. Which of the following medications did this patient most likely ingest?
questions.solution:
This patient presents clinical features concerning tricyclic antidepressant overdose, including antimuscarinic toxidrome findings and QT prolongation on an electrocardiogram. Given that these medications are weak bases, patients presenting with overdose are often treated with ammonium chloride, which enhances renal excretion of these substances.    

Several medications are considered weak bases, including tricyclic antidepressants and amphetamines, among many others. Historically, an adjunct to overdose treatment with these medications involves administering ammonium chloride, which has been shown to reduce total body pH. The drug molecules are weak bases and will exist primarily in protonated charged form. The charged molecules are less likely to induce toxicity by crossing the blood-brain barrier and have enhanced elimination in the urine. The latter phenomenon is because charged particles have a more challenging time back-diffusing across the renal epithelium into the systemic circulation.    

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  



Option Analysis

✅ Amitriptyline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate (not ammonium chloride) can be administered to alkalize the urine, cause aspirin to deprotonate, and trap the polarized drug molecules in the renal tubules. These changes can increase aspirin elimination via urine.  
❌ Phenobarbital:
Incorrect: Phenobarbital is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in the setting of an overdose to increaelimination via urine.  
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in the setting of an overdose to increase drug elimination via urine.  
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in case of an overdose to increase drug elimination via urine.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with three days of fever, chills, back pain, and dysuria. The patient is diagnosed with pyelonephritis and started on an intravenous (IV) antibiotic. The plasma concentration of this IV antibiotic is graphed over time. After two days the patient is switched to an oral antibiotic, and the plasma concentration of the oral antibiotic is also graphed over time. Which of the following could be used to calculate the bioavailability of this antibiotic?

choices.text: Total amount of drug ingested / plasma drug concentration
Plasma drug concentration / total amount of drug ingested
Total amount of drug ingested  x  plasma drug concentration
Area under the curve (AUC) for oral drug / AUC for IV medication
AUC for IV medication / AUC for oral medication

questions.solution:
Bioavailability refers to the proportion of a medication that reaches circulation and can be determined by graphing the plasma concentration of a medication over time for both IV and oral forms. The area under the curve (AUC) of the oral medication is divided by the AUC for the IV medication to determine the bioavailability. It can be expressed as a fraction of 1, or as a percentage.  

Since intravenous (IV) medications are delivered directly into the bloodstream, their bioavailability is said to be 1, or 100%. Ingested medications have varying amounts of bioavailability, thus making IV medications more effective in many cases. Some oral medications have such high bioavailability that they are almost equivalent to IV doses. As a medication passes through the GI tract, some of it may be delivered to the liver and partially metabolized, leaving less medication available for delivery to target tissues. This is referred to as the first-pass effect. In addition, the medication needs to diffuse across cellular membranes, further lowering bioavailability.  

Option Analysis

❌ Total amount of drug ingested / plasma drug concentration:
Incorrect: This represents the volume of distribution which indicates the degree a drug is distributed throughout body tissues (e.g., predominantly in plasma or distributed throughout most tissues).
❌ Plasma drug concentration / total amount of drug ingested:
Incorrect: This would be the inverse of the volume of distribution and does not represent bioavailability.
❌ Total amount of drug ingested  x  plasma drug concentration:
Incorrect: This would not provide any useful information to this patient. If the total amount of drug ingested were instead divided by plasma concentration, this would yield the volume of distribution. 
✅ Area under the curve (AUC) for oral drug / AUC for IV medication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ AUC for IV medication / AUC for oral medication:
Incorrect: If the numerator and denominator were reversed, this would be the correct calculation for bioavailability.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with end-stage liver disease secondary to chronic hepatitis C infection undergoes liver transplantation. The liver was received from the patient’s daughter. The patient had no complications in the perioperative period and is subsequently started on tacrolimus to decrease the likelihood of transplant rejection.  Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which tacrolimus reduces transplant rejection?
questions.solution:
This patient underwent hepatic transplantation and was given tacrolimus to prevent organ rejection. Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor that is used to prevent organ rejection in transplant patients. It can also be used in some autoimmune disorders.  

Tacrolimus exerts its immunosuppressive properties by binding to a protein called FK-binding protein and then inhibiting calcineurin. This suppresses the activation of the Nuclear Factor of Activated T cells (NFAT), which in turn leads to decreased IL-2 production. The lack of IL-2 impairs the proliferation and differentiation of T lymphocytes, which are the main cells responsible for transplant rejection.  

As with cyclosporine, tacrolimus also has vasoconstrictive properties that can lead to nephrotoxicity and hypertension. Neurotoxicity (e.g. convulsions) is more commonly associated with tacrolimus than cyclosporine. On the other hand, tacrolimus is not associated with gingival hyperplasia or hirsutism. Other side effects of tacrolimus include hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia,  and hyperglycemia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Decreases intracellular response to interleukin-2 (IL-2):
Incorrect: Sirolimus decreases the intracellular response to IL-2 by binding to and inhibiting mTOR, inhibiting T cell growth and proliferation in response to IL-2 receptor activation. This patient is receiving tacrolimus.
✅ Inhibits Interleukin-2 (IL-2) production:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blocks interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor:
Incorrect: Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-2 receptors. It binds to and blocks IL-2 receptors, thereby preventing the action of IL-2 in promoting T cell immune response.
❌ Inhibits purine synthesis:
Incorrect: Azathioprine is an antimetabolite that gets converted to 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits the synthesis of purine bases. This impairs nucleotide synthesis and immune cell proliferation.
❌ Inhibits pyrimidine synthesis:
Incorrect: Methotrexate exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting the synthesis of pyrimidine bases. This impairs immune cell division and proliferation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic to discuss recent hepatitis C virus (HCV) laboratory results. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled HIV and prior intravenous drug use for 5 years. Current medications include bictegravir-emtricitabine-tenofovir and melatonin. Laboratory studies from last week show a positive anti-HCV antibody and significantly elevated levels of HCV RNA. After discussion of the indications and side effects of HCV treatment, the patient is started on ribavirin. Which of the following medications can also be added to this patient’s treatment of HCV?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic hepatitis C infection. One of the approved treatment regimens for hepatitis C virus infection is the combination of ribavirin and interferon-alpha; however, the use of interferons has fallen out of favor due to their side effect profile.  

Interferons are cytokines involved in regulating the immune response. Interferons are crucial in fighting viral infections, and also have immunomodulatory effects and tumor suppression effects. Interferons increase the expression of MHC I which activates CD8+ T cells. They also increase the expression of MHC II receptors. Additionally, interferons activate B cells causing more antibody production and recruit macrophages and natural killer cells. Natural killer cells in particular help in fighting cancer cells and also virally-infected cells. Finally, interferons also inhibit various steps in the viral replication cycle and can have anti-proliferative effects by inducing apoptosis.    

Interferon-alpha is used in multiple disease processes such as chronic hepatitis B and C virus infection, hairy cell leukemia, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Interferon-beta can be used in the management of multiple sclerosis. Interferon-gamma can be used in the management of chronic granulomatous disease.  

Side effects of interferons include nausea and vomiting, and flu-like symptoms (fever, myalgia, and fatigue). In addition, some patients may experience autoimmune reactions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recombinant interferon-alpha:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recombinant interferon-beta:
Incorrect: Interferon-beta is not used in the management of hepatitis C virus infection. It is used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis.
❌ Infliximab:
Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody against tumor necrosis factor-alpha, and is used in many disorders such as psoriatic arthritis and ulcerative colitis. It has no role in the management of hepatitis C virus infection. 
❌ Aldesleukin:
Incorrect: Aldesleukin, a recombinant interleukin-2 that has been used for the management of renal cell carcinoma and melanoma. It is not used in the management of hepatitis C virus infection.
❌ Recombinant Interferon-gamma :
Incorrect: Recombinant interferon-gamma is used in the management of chronic granulomatous disease, but is not used in the treatment of hepatitis C virus infection.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening fatigue and abdominal pain. His symptoms started several months ago but have worsened to the point where he feels like he cannot function at work. He states, “I am having so much trouble sleeping; maybe I am depressed.” Their past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which he takes levothyroxine. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or recreational substances. Temperature is 37.0°C, blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Laboratory testing is shown below. Physical examination is notable for skin hyperpigmentation. Which medications are most appropriate for treating this patient’s clinical condition?  

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Sodium  130 mEq/L 
 Potassium  5.1 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  26 mEq/L 
 Thyroid stimulating hormone  3.2 µU/mL 
 Free T4  10 µg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of hypothyroidism presents with chronic fatigue, non-specific abdominal pain, and hyperpigmentation. Laboratory testing is notable for hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and normal thyroid function tests. These findings are consistent with primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease). The most appropriate treatment for this condition is fludrocortisone, which has significant mineralocorticoid activity.    

Mineralocorticoids are a class of corticosteroids that primarily influence salt and water balance. Physiologically, the primary mineralocorticoid in the human body is aldosterone. The primary synthetic mineralocorticoid in use is fludrocortisone, which is recombinant aldosterone. Additional medications such as hydrocortisone or prednisone have some mineralocorticoid activity. However, they also possess glucocorticoid activity, making them less potent agents in treating hypoaldosteronism.  

Mineralocorticoids work by mimicking the effects of aldosterone via increasing the retention of sodium and water and excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions into the cortical collecting tubule of the kidney. They are used primarily in the treatment of hypoaldosteronism but are also utilized in the treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Adverse side effects include hypokalemia, hypertension, and weight gain due to water retention.

Option Analysis

✅ Fludricortisone :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Spironolactone :
Incorrect: Spironolactone carries anti-mineralocorticoid effects, which would make this patient’s primary hyperaldosteronism worse. 
❌ Prednisone :
Incorrect: Prednisone has some mineralocorticoid activity. However, it is primarily a glucocorticoid. In contrast, fludrocortisone is a more appropriate treatment for this patient’s primary hypoaldosteronism.
❌ Liothyronine:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of hypothyroidism, his thyroid function tests are within normal limits. As a result, it is unlikely that his current symptoms are secondary to hypothyroidism.
❌ Metyrapone:
Incorrect: Metyrapone is a pyridine derivative and a glucocorticoid synthesis inhibitor. The medication is used to aid in diagnosing, not treating, primary adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for burns sustained to his thighs and palms of the hands while playing with matches in a garage. The patient weighs 48 kg and has a height of 135 cm. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 105/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilateral circumferential wounds from ankle to mid-thigh and burns on both palms. The patient is admitted to the burn unit and initiated on intravenous fluids and a topical antibiotic ointment containing bacitracin. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of bacitracin?

choices.text: Binds to transpeptidases and inhibits cross-linking of peptidoglycan in bacterial cell wall
Inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors
Blocks peptidyl transferase at 50s ribosomal subunit
Inhibits transport of peptidoglycan proteins across the cell membrane

questions.solution:
This patient has sustained partial thickness burns on the hands and legs and is being treated with an antibiotic ointment containing bacitracin. Bacitracin is an antibiotic agent active against gram-positive cocci, including Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococcus pyogenes. It inhibits bactoprenol phosphate, a transmembrane transporter embedded within the bacterial cell membrane. Bactoprenol phosphate promotes the transport of N-acetyl-muramic acid and N-acetyl mucopeptides that form components of the bacterial cell wall. Bacitracin inhibits the transport of these mucopeptides and inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Bacitracin is commonly used for topical application in partial thickness burns, particularly those that involve the face and the perineum, and for photokeratitis. Topical agents are used cautiously in patients with impaired renal function and neurotoxic or nephrotoxic adverse effects.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibits dihydropteroate synthase:
Incorrect: Sulfamethoxazole inhibits dihydropteroate synthase, an enzyme that is involved in folate synthesis. It is bacteriostatic when combined with trimethoprim. However, it is not used topically in the treatment of burns.  
❌ Binds to transpeptidases and inhibits cross-linking of peptidoglycan in bacterial cell wall:
Incorrect: Penicillin and modified penicillins are beta-lactam antibiotics that bind to transpeptidases and inhibit cross-linking within the cell wall.  
❌ Inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors:
Incorrect: Vancomycin directly binds to D-Ala D-Ala portions of the cell wall. It is a systemic agent in treating MRSA (+) skin and soft tissue infections. In the absence of a previous episode of MRSA or lack of clinical improvement in 48 hours, IV vancomycin is not likely indicated.  
❌ Blocks peptidyl transferase at 50s ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol is an antimicrobial agent that targets the 50s ribosomal subunit. Its use is limited due to the hematologic toxicity associated with its use. Gentamicin (which targets the initiation complex of the 30s subunit) can be used topically.  
✅ Inhibits transport of peptidoglycan proteins across the cell membrane:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for osteomyelitis of the right ankle due to Staphylococcus aureus. Medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease stage two and myelodysplastic syndrome. On admission, the patient was started on an antibiotic that directly inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis. While rounding on the patient on hospital day seven, he mentioned tinnitus and hearing loss which began over the last 24 hours. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 90/min, respirations 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 96% on room air. Physical examination shows bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is normal. Which of the following additional adverse effects is this patient at risk for if this antibiotic is continued long-term?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with staphylococcal osteomyelitis and has now developed auditory symptoms. This presentation is suggestive of vancomycin-induced ototoxicity.

Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent that inhibits bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. It is indicated in the empiric treatment of osteomyelitis and third-generation cephalosporin. Treatment with this combination covers methicillin-resistant S. aureus (by vancomycin) and most gram-negative organisms (by ceftriaxone).

Vancomycin is associated with adverse effects, which include nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, thrombophlebitis and red man syndrome (flushing and pruritus due to the infusion of vancomycin) and DRESS syndrome (drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms). Significant renal injury – as evidenced by an acute drop in urine output or a significant rise in serum creatinine – is an indication to reduce the dose of vancomycin or switch to a different antibiotic.  

Option Analysis

❌ Neuromuscular blockade:
Incorrect: Aminoglycosides can cause neuromuscular blockade, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity. They are bactericidal agents that inhibit bacterial protein synthesis; they do not inhibit peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis.  
❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is associated with using agents such as chloramphenicol, zidovudine, and TMP-SMX. None of these agents are known to cause ototoxicity, and they do not inhibit peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis.  
❌ Tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones can cause tendon rupture and should be avoided in patients above 60 or those taking prednisone. They do not inhibit peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis or cause ototoxicity.  
❌ Seizures:
Incorrect: Carbapenems inhibit PBPs/transpeptidases that cause cross-linking in bacterial cell wall synthesis. CNS toxicity (myoclonus, seizures, and altered mental status) is associated with carbapenem use (especially imipenem). Carbapenems do not usually cause ototoxicity and would not be used to treat S. aureus osteomyelitis.  
✅ Acute reduction in urine output:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man with no significant past medical history develops a bowel perforation and subsequently undergoes surgical repair. He develops significant hypotension while under general anesthesia. Intraoperative blood loss is minimal. A large dose of epinephrine is administered, which temporarily raises the patient's blood pressure. Several subsequent doses of epinephrine are administered and cause a much weaker response. Which of the following mechanisms is likely contributing to the decreased effects of this medication?

choices.text: Increased activity of intracellular arrestin proteins
Increased production of secondary messenger molecules

questions.solution:
Desensitization and tolerance are important concepts in pharmacodynamics and refers to a decreased effect of a drug (e.g. alcohol, heroin) or medication over time following subsequent doses. Over time, as an agonist binds to its cellular receptor, it may lose its ability to produce a robust response within cells via secondary messengers. Desensitization (also called tachyphylaxis) generally occurs rapidly and can occur after the first dose of a medication. On the other hand, tolerance occurs always after repeated doses and may take weeks or months. In this patient, he is likely experiencing desensitization (tachyphylaxis) to epinephrine, so repeated doses exert a weaker effect than the original dose.

Desensitization and tolerance can occur via many mechanisms, with several of the most common mechanisms outlined below:

  1. Downregulation of receptor expression. For example, chronic opioid use results in downregulating the number of receptors available to bind the opioid or may increase the degradation or sequestration of receptors. This results in stronger doses of opioids needed to produce the same effect.
  2. Uncoupling of receptors to secondary messengers. This is often mediated by proteins called arrestins, which bind to G-protein-coupled receptors to prevent interaction with secondary messengers. They can also tag these receptors for endocytosis. This is common in desensitization (tachyphylaxis).
  3. Exhaustion of intracellular intermediary molecules. This can occur with drugs such as amphetamines, which eventually leads to the depletion of secondary messengers within cells.
  4. Increased breakdown of agonists. For example, this can occur with chronic alcohol use, as “tolerance” increases with repeated chronic use due to more rapid degradation of ethanol.
  5. Physiologic adaptation in the body. For example, this can occur with thiazide diuretics due to increased activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased activity of intracellular arrestin proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Increased number of extracellular receptors:
Incorrect: If more extracellular receptors were available, there would be more binding to the agonist (medication), making it more likely to maintain or increase a cellular response (i.e. drug effect).  
❌ Increased production of secondary messenger molecules:
Incorrect: Since medications/drugs work by binding to a cellular receptor and causing effects via secondary messengers, an increase in secondary messengers is more likely to maintain or increase a cellular response (i.e. drug effect).  
❌ Decreased breakdown of the medication:
Incorrect: Since more medication would be available, this is unlikely to lead to decreased effect.  
❌ Decreased sequestration of extracellular receptors:
Incorrect: Decreased sequestration of receptors to bind the medication would result in more receptors available for drug binding, and thus more intracellular changes (i.e. effect) from the medication.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a fever, cough, and a lump in his neck for the past 3-months. The neck mass is non-tender, has not grown in size, and is not associated with any skin changes. The patient has experienced a 3 kg (7 lb) weight loss in the past 3-months and a significant decrease in appetite. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or recreational substances. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. Physical examination reveals non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy and pallor. A chest radiograph reveals a mediastinal mass. Biopsy reveals specimens containing Reed-Sternberg cells. The patient is initiated on a chemotherapeutic regimen involving a drug that prevents polymerization of microtubules. Which of the following side effects is associated with this agent?

choices.text: Prolonged fever, sore throat, and bleeding gums
Sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo

questions.solution:
This patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and decreased appetite. Imaging reveals a mediastinal mass and biopsy reveals Reed-Sternberg cells, which are suggestive of Hodgkin lymphoma. He was most likely started on a vinca alkaloid chemotherapeutic, which can cause an increased risk of bleeding from the gums.

Vinca alkaloids (e.g., vincristine, vinblastine) are microtubule inhibitors indicated in the treatment of a variety of solid organ tumors, Hodgkin lymphoma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. These medications inhibit microtubule polymerization by binding to ꞵ-tubulin and inhibiting mitotic spindle formation.

Vinca alkaloids inhibit DNA replication in the M phase of the cell cycle. Rapidly dividing somatic cells (e.g., gastrointestinal tract, oral cavity, bone marrow, hair follicles) are particularly susceptible to the effects of vinca alkaloids.

Vinblastine, in particular, can cause profound myelosuppression resulting in symptoms that indicate a decrease in all cell lines. Patients can present with fatigue, pallor from anemia, fever from leukopenia, and bleeding from mucous membranes as a result of thrombocytopenia. Vinblastine has been found to be less neurotoxic as compared to vincristine, possibly due to differences in affinity to neural tissue.

In contrast, vincristine can cause peripheral neuropathy and autonomic dysfunction. Moreover, this medication can cause sensory peripheral neuropathy, areflexia, and orthostatic hypotension.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Blood in urine:
Incorrect: Hematuria is an adverse effect encountered in the use of the alkylating agent cyclophosphamide. Cyclophosphamide is a nitrogen mustard that creates interstrand cross-links between adjacent guanine molecules, resulting in DNA damage. Although it is used in the treatment of lymphoma, it does not bind to tubulin and does not play a role in the inhibition of microtubule polymerisation.  
✅ Prolonged fever, sore throat, and bleeding gums:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nonproductive chronic cough:
Incorrect: A nonproductive cough following the use of an antineoplastic agent may signify pulmonary fibrosis in conjunction with an abnormal pulmonary function test. This adverse effect is encountered in the use of bleomycin and busulfan. Bleomycin causes DNA damage by inducing free radical formation. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that induces DNA damage by creating cross-links. Neither medication inhibits the polymerization of microtubules.  
❌ Convulsions, dizziness, and ataxia:
Incorrect: Neurologic symptoms indicative of CNS toxicity may develop following the use of nitrosoureas, such as carmustine. These agents cross the blood-brain barrier and create DNA cross-links in malignant brain tumor cells. However, they are not the therapeutic agents preferred in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma.  
❌ Sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo:
Incorrect: Ototoxicity is an adverse effect encountered with the use of platinum-containing compounds such as cisplatin. These agents are non-cell cycle specific and induce DNA damage by creating cross-links between adjacent guanine molecules.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician due to significant pain during her menstrual cycles. The patient tells the physician that this started eight months ago and has been interfering with her activities of daily living. After an appropriate workup, the diagnosis of endometriosis is made. The physician decides to start the patient on a medication that has pro-androgenic effects and anti-estrogenic effects. Which of the following is the most likely medication used in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with endometriosis, a condition in which the endometrial gland grows outside the uterine cavity. Many options can be used in treating endometriosis, one of which is danazol.

Danazol is a synthetic androgen with androgen agonist and antagonist effects on estrogen. Danazol suppresses ovarian function through both direct and indirect effects. It directly inhibits ovarian function by inhibiting the ovary's steroidogenesis and indirectly decreases estrogen synthesis by decreasing the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the pituitary gland. It also has androgenic agonist effects, as it stimulates androgen receptors.

Danazol has been proven to be effective in treating endometriosis. By creating amenorrhea and hypoestrogenism, danazol causes atrophy and regression of the ectopic endometrial tissues. Its use in treating endometriosis has decreased pain and improved fertility.

However, it is not usually used as a first-line treatment option because of its androgenic side effects i.e. acne, voice changes (e.g., deepening of the voice, hoarseness), decreased breast size, and hirsutism. Additionally, it may lead to menstrual irregularities, flushing, and sweating. Sometimes, patients can have nausea, vomiting, and a rise in blood pressure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Danazol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Leuprolide:
Incorrect: Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist that can sometimes be used to treat endometriosis; it has no androgenic effects.  
❌ Combined oral contraceptive pills:
Incorrect: Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) are the first-line treatment of endometriosis and be efficacious in reducing pain. However, they have no androgenic effects.  
❌ Progestin-only pills:
Incorrect: Progestin-only pills can also be used in treating endometriosis, but they have no androgenic effects.  
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: NSAIDs are usually used to control pain in endometriosis patients; however, they do not directly influence the hormones in the body.

questions.text: A 35-year-old gravida 2 para 1 woman at 34 weeks gestation comes to her obstetrician for follow-up. She was diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus, which is well-controlled with diet modification and metformin. Her past medical history includes asthma, but she does not take any medications for asthma control. Her previous delivery occurred via spontaneous vaginal delivery.  The patient was noted to have placenta previa on ultrasonography at the 28th week of gestation. Repeat ultrasound reveals the placenta in a normal anatomic location and is no longer covering the cervical os. The fetus is positioned in a transverse lie. Which of the following is a contraindication to oxytocin administration for labor induction?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin is a peptide hormone produced by the posterior pituitary that stimulates uterine contractions. Exogenous oxytocin administration is indicated to initiate or facilitate vaginal delivery and treat postpartum hemorrhage.

Oxytocin administration is contraindicated in a few settings. Patients with hypersensitivity to oxytocin cannot receive this medication. In addition, oxytocin is contraindicated in any patient with a contraindication to vaginal delivery. This includes patients with unfavorable fetal position or presentation (e.g. transverse lie or cord presentation), active genital herpes, invasive cervical carcinoma, placenta previa, vasa previa, or cord prolapse.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transverse lie:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Placenta previa:
Incorrect: Although this patient had placenta previa, the placenta has now ascended to its normal anatomic location. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Gestational diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Gestational diabetes mellitus is neither a contraindication for vaginal delivery nor oxytocin induction of labor. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Asthma:
Incorrect: Asthma is not a contraindication to oxytocin administration. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.  
❌ Patient age:
Incorrect: Patient age is not a contraindication for oxytocin administration. This patient has a different contraindication to oxytocin administration.

questions.text: A 28-year-old gravida 2 para 2 woman develops severe vaginal bleeding after delivery. The patient had gestational diabetes mellitus during pregnancy and delivered a 9 lb 3 oz infant. Uterine massage is applied, and oxytocin is administered without hemorrhage control. Three units of packed red blood cells are administered, and she is also provided with dinoprostone. Which of the following side effects are most commonly associated with dinoprostone?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed postpartum hemorrhage likely due to uterine atony. She was administered dinoprostone, a prostaglandin analog.

Prostaglandin analogs like misoprostol (PGE2) and dinoprostone (PGE1) are effective in stimulating uterine contractions for the management of postpartum hemorrhage and in facilitating labor or inducing abortion. They act by stimulating receptors on the uterine smooth muscle. These receptors are coupled with Gq, and once stimulated, they induce the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, causing muscle contraction.

Side effects of prostaglandin analogs include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. They can also cause uterine pain and hyperstimulation. Because dinoprostone can stimulate prostaglandin receptors on the smooth muscle of the bronchioles, it can also cause bronchoconstriction and must be avoided in patients with underlying asthma.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Bronchoconstriction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Oxytocin can cause hyponatremia if administered excessively or for prolonged periods due to its structural similarity to antidiuretic hormone. However, hyponatremia is not a known side effect of dinoprostone.  
❌ Gastric ulcers:
Incorrect: Gastric ulcers can develop as a side effect of prostaglandin inhibitors. However, dinoprostone is a prostaglandin analog and is protective against gastric ulcers.  
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is a known side effect of ergonovine; it is not associated with dinoprostone use.  
❌ Venous thromboembolism:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic drug that can be used to treat postpartum hemorrhage and can cause venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 24-year-old gravida 2 para 1 woman comes to the obstetrician for evaluation of painful uterine contractions. The patient is in the 32<sup>nd</sup> week of gestation. She describes her contractions as regular and increasing in frequency. The patient has a history of preterm delivery in her previous pregnancy. She did not have any complications during this pregnancy. Examination reveals cervical dilation. The physician decides to administer terbutaline. Which of the following is a possible side effect of terbutaline?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with preterm labor, defined as regular uterine contractions before 37 weeks of gestation. Preterm labor carries significant morbidity and mortality to neonates, especially before the 34th week of gestation. Patients with onset of labor before 34 weeks of gestation are administered tocolytics to delay labor and provide time for corticosteroid administration to stimulate fetal lung maturation.

Tocolytics are a group of medications that delay the onset of labor in patients presenting with preterm labor. Specifically, Terbutaline is a beta-agonist that is used for tocolysis. Beta-2 receptors are found in the walls of the uterine smooth muscles. These are Gs protein-coupled receptors and, once activated, induce cyclic AMP formation (cAMP) by activating adenylyl cyclase. Once cAMP is formed, it phosphorylates protein kinase A and deactivates myosin light-chain kinase, inhibiting smooth muscle contraction.

Terbutaline is a selective Beta-2 adrenergic receptor agonist used to delay labor by inhibiting uterine contractions. It is used for short-term tocolysis and uterine tachysystole.

Adverse effects of terbutaline occur secondary to its effects on beta-receptors. In the mother, terbutaline can cause tachycardia, arrhythmias, myocardial ischemia, hypotension, and pulmonary edema. Finally, terbutaline can lead to hyperglycemia and is contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperglycemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia, is a known side-effect of terbutaline, as it is a beta-agonist.  
❌ Premature closure of ductus arteriosus:
Incorrect: Closure of ductus arteriosus is a known effect of indomethacin due to inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis, but terbutaline does not affect prostaglandins.  
❌ Gastritis:
Incorrect: Gastritis is a known complication of indomethacin use but is not associated with terbutaline.  
❌ Bradycardia:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is a beta-agonist, leading to tachycardia and tachyarrhythmias, not bradycardia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider to evaluate excessive sweating, anxiety, and weight loss despite an increased appetite. Her past medical history is notable for a toxic thyroid adenoma, for which she has been prescribed multiple medications. However, the patient reports that her symptoms have been poorly controlled. In the office, her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 127/76 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for mild eyelid retraction, and a non-tender, solitary nodule is palpated in the left thyroid lobe. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. The physician recommends that the patient undergo treatment that will improve her condition but may cause side effects of hypothyroidism, xerostomia, and sialadenitis. Which of the following best describes this treatment option’s mechanism of action?

choices.text: Removal of autoantibodies from the bloodstream

questions.solution:
This patient has a toxic adenoma, causing symptoms of hyperthyroidism that are refractory to medical management. The patient is started on a radioactive iodine treatment regimen called radioiodine ablation therapy. The isotope of iodine that is used is I131. It is taken orally and eventually gets taken up by the thyroid. Over a few weeks, the radioactive isotope collects in the colloid and emits beta radiation that causes permanent damage to the thyroid.

Radioiodine ablation therapy can provide definitive treatment for hyperthyroidism caused by Graves disease, toxic multinodular goiter, and toxic adenoma. Since the thyroid is permanently destroyed, the patient will need to take thyroid hormone replacements like levothyroxine to prevent hypothyroidism. Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and is secreted in breast milk. Hence, it is contraindicated in pregnant or breastfeeding individuals. Finally, as far as side effects go, radioactive iodide can cause radiation-induced thyroiditis, increased risk of neoplasia, hematopoietic suppression, exacerbation of Graves ophthalmopathy, salivary, and lacrimal toxicity. Salivary and lacrimal toxicity arise since the radioactive iodine can also be uptaken by these glands and cause tissue damage.  

Option Analysis

❌ Non-selective blockade of beta-receptors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of non-selective beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol). Side effects may include bradycardia, fatigue, bronchoconstriction/asthma exacerbation, and weight gain. However, this medication class would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.  
✅ Radiation-induced thyroid gland destruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of thyroid peroxidase:
Incorrect: Thionamides (e.g., methimazole, propylthiouracil) block thyroid hormone production by inhibiting thyroid peroxidase. Side effects include agranulocytosis, hepatotoxicity, aplastic anemia, and skin rash. However, thionamides would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.  
❌ Promotion of lymphocyte apoptosis:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are immunosuppressants that function via several mechanisms of action. One involves promoting the apoptosis of lymphocytes, monocytes, and other immune cells. The medication treats Graves ophthalmopathy and thyroid storm, but not toxic adenoma. Side effects include hyperglycemia, skin atrophy, weight gain, and increased infection risk.  
❌ Removal of autoantibodies from the bloodstream:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of plasmapheresis. It is occasionally used in the management of severe Graves disease. However, plasmapheresis would not be useful in treating a toxic adenoma, given that autoantibodies do not mediate the condition.

questions.text: A graduate student studies the pharmacodynamics of exemestane, a medication used to treat breast cancer. Assuming the target enzyme follows Michaelis-Menten kinetics, which of the following best describes exemestane’s binding site on the target enzyme and its effect on the target enzyme’s V<sub>max</sub> (maximum rate of enzyme activity) and K<sub>m</sub> (Michaelis constant)?
questions.solution:
Aromatase inhibitors (AIs) block estrogen formation by inhibiting the aromatase enzyme, which converts androgen to estrogen.

Aromatase inhibitors are used to treat estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer in postmenopausal individuals. This is because, in postmenopausal women, estrogen is synthesized in the adrenal glands, muscle, fat, and skin. AIs block this pathway and suppress estrogen levels. In premenopausal women, estrogen is synthesized primarily in the ovaries and regulated by gonadotropin. As a result, administration of AIs would increase gonadotropin release secondary to reduced negative estrogen feedback on the pituitary gland, resulting in increased ovarian stimulation.

There are two main types of aromatase inhibitors. Type I AIs (e.g. exemestane) are steroidal agents that are irreversible competitive inhibitors of aromatase. They bind to aromatase’s active site. They reduce the Vmax but do not affect the Km. Type II AIs (e.g., anastrozole, letrozole) are non-steroidal agents. They are reversible competitive inhibitors that bind to the active site. They do not affect Vmax but increase the Km of aromatase.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation   
❌ :
Incorrect: These parameters are consistent with those of a reversible competitive inhibitor. In contrast, exemestane is an irreversible competitive inhibitor of aromatase.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Exemestane is an irreversible competitive inhibitor of aromatase. The medication binds to the active site of aromatase and reduces its Vmax. It would not affect the Km, the substrate concentration needed for aromatase to reach half of its maximum rate of reaction.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Exemestane is an irreversible competitive aromatase inhibitor. As a result, it binds to the active site of aromatase instead of an allosteric site.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Exemestane is an irreversible competitive aromatase inhibitor. As a result, it binds to the active site of aromatase instead of an allosteric site.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman came to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and chest tightness for the past hour.
