The patient appears tachypneic but is able to speak full sentences. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies. Family history is significant for asthma in the patient’s mother. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows diffuse wheezing on pulmonary auscultation bilaterally. After further evaluation, treatment with an inhaled medication is begun. The patient reports improvement in symptoms after 10 minutes which was evident by increased flow rate on spirometry. Which of the following is the most common adverse effect of the inhaled therapy that was most likely administered in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with acute shortness of breath and chest tightness is consistent with airway bronchoconstriction, most likely due to an asthma attack. Administration of a bronchodilator, most likely a beta-2 (β2)-agonist (e.g.-albuterol) improved her symptoms.

β2-agonists are bronchodilators that relax the airway smooth muscle cells. It activates the enzyme adenylyl cyclase leading to increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production that ultimately causes relaxation of the smooth muscle by reducing the concentration of intracellular calcium (Ca+2) ions. β2-agonists are mainstays of reliever or rescue therapy for asthma patients. Major side effects are caused by increased sympathetic stimulation and include tachycardia, palpitations, muscle tremors, restlessness, and insomnia. There is a slight fall in plasma potassium due to increased uptake by skeletal muscle cells, but this effect does not usually cause any clinical problems due to the significantly small dose.  

Option Analysis

❌ Myelosuppression:
Incorrect: Steroid-sparing therapy such as methotrexate can be used in patients with severe asthma to reduce the requirement for oral corticosteroids. Myelosuppression is the major side effect of methotrexate therapy.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: For severe asthma and COPD, muscarinic antagonists are often given with long-acting beta-agonists as this combination produces an additive effect, leading to stronger and longer-lasting bronchodilation. Side effects of muscarinic antagonists include tachycardia, dry mouth, urinary retention, and pupil dilation.  
✅ Palpitations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral thrush:
Incorrect: Use of inhaled corticosteroids can cause oral thrush. It is not the first-line treatment for an acute asthma attack.  
❌ Drug-drug interactions:
Incorrect: Theophylline has been used for bronchodilation previously, but its use is limited due to narrow therapeutic index and adverse effects (e.g., cardiotoxicity, neurotoxicity). It is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 and is involved in significant drug-drug interactions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of worsening shortness of breath and dry cough. The patient reports exertional shortness of breath for the past few days to the extent that he is now unable to perform his daily activities. He does not have chest pain but reports noticing whitish sputum with cough. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Family history is significant for lung cancer in the patient’s father. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. BMI is 33 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg. Pulmonary auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds with scattered wheezes bilaterally. Medication is prescribed to counter the increase in mucus secretion, smooth muscle contraction, and bronchoconstriction in the airways. Which of the following is the most likely agent?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The mainstays of treatment are bronchodilators, especially antimuscarinic agents.

Muscarinic receptors are located primarily on autonomic effector cells (including the  heart, vascular endothelium, smooth muscle, presynaptic nerve terminals, and exocrine glands). It includes:
  
  • M1 receptors: mediates higher cognitive functions, stimulates the enteric nervous system 
  • M2 receptors: decreases heart rate and contractility of atria 
  • M3 receptors: increases exocrine gland secretions (e.g., lacrimal, sweat, salivary, gastric acid, airway secretions), decreases gut peristalsis, increases bladder contraction, bronchoconstriction, increased pupillary sphincter muscle contraction (miosis), ciliary muscle contraction (accommodation), increases insulin release and causes endothelium-mediated vasodilation 
Antimuscarinic medications used in the management of COPD bind to M3 muscarinic receptors on the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles, blocking acetylcholine binding, consequently leading to less smooth muscle constriction. These medications also decrease mucous secretions from airway glands.  

Option Analysis

❌ Alpha-1 (α-1) adrenergic antagonist  :
Incorrect: α-1 adrenergic antagonists are primarily used in the management of benign prostatic hyperplasia, hypertension, and post-traumatic stress disorder (prazosin). It is not useful in the management of COPD.  
❌ Alpha-2 (α-2) adrenergic agonist:
Incorrect:  Clonidine and ɑ-methyldopa are α-2 adrenergic agonist used in the management of hypertension.  It does not help with COPD.  
❌ Beta-1 (β-1) adrenergic antagonist:
Incorrect: β-1 adrenergic antagonist may exacerbate pulmonary symptoms in patients with COPD via bronchoconstriction.  
❌ Muscarinic-2 (M2) cholinergic antagonist:
Incorrect: M2 cholinergic antagonist, would cause an increase in heart rate and contractility. It is not indicated in COPD.  
✅ Muscarinic-3 (M3) cholinergic antagonist  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of painful swelling and erythema on his right leg. The patient reports that he suffered minor cuts a few days ago while he was cleaning his garage. A review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily. He does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an indurated lesion surrounded by minor lacerations which are draining a purulent exudate. Complete blood profile shows a leukocyte count of 14,000 /mm3. Empiric antibiotic treatment is started after obtaining a sample of discharge for culture and sensitivity. Results of the culture reveal gram-positive cocci in clusters that are resistant to methicillin. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of resistance to methicillin in this bacteria?

choices.text: Increased efflux of the drug out of bacteria by plasmid-encoded transport pumps
Chromosomal mutation in bacterial DNA gyrase
Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase
Replacement of alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with painful erythematous swelling on right leg draining purulent exudate is most likely suffering from cellulitis. Gram-positive cocci in clusters that are resistant to methicillin is consistent with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection.  

Resistance to methicillin and other β-lactams is due to one of the following mechanisms: 
  • Mutation in penicillin-binding protein (PBP) altering its affinity for β-lactams (basis of methicillin resistance in staphylococci and of penicillin resistance in pneumococci and most resistant enterococci) 
  •  Inactivation of antibiotics by β-lactamase (penicillinases) is the most common mechanism of resistance of  staphylococci and many Gram-negative organisms 
  • Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs, which is only in Gram-negative species because of the impermeable outer membrane of their cell wall 
  •  Efflux pump that efficiently transports some β-lactam antibiotics from the periplasm back across the cell wall outer membrane

Option Analysis

❌ Increased efflux of the drug out of bacteria by plasmid-encoded transport pumps:
Incorrect: Decreased uptake or Increased efflux of the drug out of bacterial cells by plasmid-encoded transport pumps is the mechanism of resistance of tetracyclines.
❌ Chromosomal mutation in bacterial DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Resistance to quinolones is due primarily to chromosomal-encoded mutations that modify the bacterial DNA gyrase.
✅ Mutation in penicillin-binding protein (PBP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase:
Incorrect: Decreased activity of bacterial catalase-peroxidase is the mechanism of mycobacterial resistance to isoniazid. Mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase activity is required to synthesize the active metabolite of isoniazid that inhibits the growth of M. tuberculosis.
❌ Replacement of alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan:
Incorrect: Resistance to vancomycin is caused by a change in the peptide component of peptidoglycan from D-alanyl-D-alanine, which is the normal binding site for vancomycin, to D-alanine-D-lactate, to which the drug does not bind.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man undergoes elective coronary artery bypass grafting. Postoperative course is complicated by acute renal failure, pulmonary edema, and atrial fibrillation. An attempt to extubate the patient on the fourth postoperative day fails. The patient develops a temperature of 38.3°C (100.9 F) on the following day. Complete blood profile shows a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. Chest x-ray shows dense infiltrates in the upper and middle right lobes of the lungs. Lower respiratory tract samples are obtained. Gram stain is shown below. Culture on McConkey agar shows oxidase-positive organisms that do not ferment lactose. Treatment with piperacillin is initiated. Adding tazobactam to this treatment regimen would serve which of the following purposes?



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Facilitate piperacillin binding to the bacterial cells
Decrease piperacillin cleavage by bacterial cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia, which is a type of nosocomial pneumonia that develops ≧ 48 hours after endotracheal intubation. The most commonly implicated organisms include Gram-negative bacilli (e.g., Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli) and Gram-positive cocci (e.g. methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). This patient is infected with Gram-negative rods that are oxidase-positive and lactose non-fermenting, making P. aeruginosa the most likely pathogen.    

Certain bacterial strains, such as P. aeruginosa, produce the beta-lactamase enzymes that hydrolyze the beta-lactam ring of the penicillins, resulting in the loss of its antibacterial activity. The addition of a β-lactamase inhibitor (e.g., clavulanic acid, sulbactam, tazobactam) can protect hydrolyzable penicillins from inactivation by these enzymes. An inhibitor extends the spectrum of its companion β-lactam provided that the inactivity against a particular organism is due to destruction by a β-lactamase and that the inhibitor is active against the β-lactamase that is produced. They are available only in fixed combinations with specific penicillins and cephalosporins, for example, ampicillin-sulbactam, amoxicillin-clavulanate, and piperacillin-tazobactam.  

Option Analysis

❌ Facilitate piperacillin binding to the bacterial cells:
Incorrect: Penicillin-binding proteins in bacterial cells are responsible for bacterial binding of the antibiotic. Beta-lactamase inhibitors do not affect this function.
✅ Decrease piperacillin cleavage by bacterial cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decrease renal clearance of piperacillin:
Incorrect: Clearance of both piperacillin and tazobactam are directly proportional to renal function. Moreover, probenecid can decrease the renal excretion of penicillins by inhibiting tubular organic acid secretion.
❌ Act synergistically with piperacillin:
Incorrect: Piperacillin–tazobactam often demonstrates synergy against P. aeruginosa in combination with an aminoglycoside.
❌ Slow liver metabolism of piperacillin:
Incorrect: Tazobactam has no effect on the biotransformation of piperacillin.

questions.text: A group of researchers are studying the pharmacodynamics of acetaminophen toxicity. The researchers note that in rats, metabolism primarily occurs through various phase II drug metabolism reactions in hepatocytes. However, after a certain dosage, these pathways are saturated, and acetaminophen is subsequently metabolized to NAPQI by cytochrome P450. The researchers determined that although NAPQI is a toxic substance, it is safely reduced to nontoxic mercaptate and cysteine compounds via a specific phase II reaction. Which of the following reactions is most likely taking place during this phase of drug metabolism?
questions.solution:
Biotransformation is a metabolic process that takes place mainly in hepatocytes and helps facilitate the excretion of exogenous substances. A series of reactions alter the chemical structures of these substances. The enzymes catalyzing these reactions can cause the substrate to become inactive, active, and toxic.

These reactions can be classified into two main phases: phase I and phase II. However, it is important to realize that these reactions do not have to take place sequentially, and can even take place in reverse.
   
  • Phase I metabolism consists of reduction, oxidation, and hydrolysis reactions. These reactions convert lipophilic drugs into more polar molecules by adding or exposing a polar functional group such as -NH2 or -OH. These reactions also serve to create active metabolites, which are necessary for converting prodrugs into their active and therapeutic forms. Phase I metabolism involves the use of the cytochrome P450 system found in the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum. 
 
  • Phase II reactions are conjugation reactions, meaning the medications or metabolites are conjugated, or joined with another compound and therefore, include methylation, acetylation, sulfation, glutathionylation, and glucuronidation. These reactions create highly polar, water-soluble metabolites that cannot diffuse through cell membranes, so they are trapped in the urine, and eliminated by the kidneys. The purpose of this phase is to create inactive compounds that can be excreted by the body. 
In the context of acetaminophen metabolism, 95% of metabolism occurs via phase II reactions involving glucuronidation and sulfation. However, 5% is converted into the toxic metabolite NAPQI, which can cause significant cellular damage. Glutathione can react with NAPQI, converting it into inert, excretable metabolites.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Glutathione conjugation   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Glycine conjugation   :
Incorrect: Although glycine conjugation is a phase II drug metabolism reaction, it is not responsible for the reduction of NAPQI into its nontoxic metabolites.   
❌ Hydrolysis:
Incorrect: Hydrolysis is a phase I metabolism reaction, which is responsible for converting lipophilic drugs into more polar molecules. These reactions also serve to create active metabolites, which are necessary for converting prodrugs into their active and therapeutic form. However, hydrolysis is not responsible for the reduction of NAPQI into its nontoxic metabolites.   
❌ Methylation:
Incorrect: Although methylation is a phase II drug metabolism reaction, it is not responsible for the reduction of NAPQI into its nontoxic metabolites.   
❌ Glucuronidation:
Incorrect: Glucuronidation and sulfation are responsible for metabolizing the vast majority of acetaminophen (approximately 95%) into nontoxic compounds. However, these processes are not responsible for the reduction of NAPQI into its nontoxic metabolites.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to a primary care provider for evaluation of vague abdominal pain. The patient typically has her menstrual cycle every 28 days but has not had one in 6 weeks now. She takes oral contraceptive pills daily and frequently has unprotected sex with male partner. She was recently seen by a neurologist and was diagnosed with a seizure disorder, for which she was prescribed an anti-epileptic medication. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The patient is an avid runner and frequently runs 7-8 miles daily. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?

choices.text: False-positive pregnancy result caused by anti-epileptic medication

questions.solution:
The cytochrome P450 system is classified by similar gene sequences. Enzymes are assigned a family number (e.g., CYP1, CYP2), a subfamily letter (e.g., CYP1A, CYP2D), and a number for the isoform or individual enzyme (e.g., CYP1A1, CYP2D6). It is important to note that medications that share a common metabolism pathway may cause drug-drug interactions.

Typically, if a drug acts as a CYP inducer, then it causes concurrently administered drugs metabolized by the same CYP isozyme to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure. In contrast, if a drug acts as a CYP inhibitor, then it causes other drugs to accumulate to toxic levels, potentially leading to overdose and side effects.

In the case of this patient, she was on an oral contraceptive pill (OCP) and then started on an antiepileptic medication (e.g., carbamazepine, phenytoin), which are CYP-450 inducers. There will be increased metabolism of OCPs, decreased serum concentration to subtherapeutic levels, and increased chance of pregnancy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Reduced serum estradiol levels   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ False-positive pregnancy result caused by anti-epileptic medication   :
Incorrect: Anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) are not frequently known to cause false-positive pregnancy test results.   
❌ Elevated serum prolactin levels   :
Incorrect: Hyperprolactinemia can cause anovulation and abnormal uterine bleeding. However, this patient does not have any other symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, and moreover, elevated serum prolactin levels can cause reduced fertility.   
❌ Increased androgen production   :
Incorrect: Increased androgen production can be seen in patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), but is also typically accompanied by other physical examination findings, such as hirsutism, acne, and obesity. None of these other findings are present in this patient.   
❌ Decreased serum thyroxine levels   :
Incorrect: Abnormal uterine bleeding can be caused by hypothyroidism. However, hypothyroidism is also typically accompanied by other physical examination findings such as cold sensitivity, fatigue, and weight gain, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of indigestion. After eating meals, the patient often feels a substernal, epigastric burning sensation that worsens while laying flat. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation, for which he is taking metformin, lisinopril, and warfarin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 136/84 mmHg, pulse is 92/min and irregularly irregular, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. The patient is started on cimetidine for acid reflux. Which of the following complications is this patient at risk due to this new medication?

choices.text: Development of a dry, hacking cough
Sudden onset pain, pallor, and paresthesia of left lower extremity

questions.solution:
The cytochrome P450 system is classified by similar gene sequences. Enzymes are assigned a family number (e.g., CYP1, CYP2), a subfamily letter (e.g., CYP1A, CYP2D), and a number for the isoform or individual enzyme (e.g., CYP1A1, CYP2D6). It is important to note that medications that share a common metabolism pathway may cause drug-drug interactions.

Typically, if a drug acts as a CYP inducer, then it causes concurrently administered drugs metabolized by the same CYP isozyme to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure. In contrast, if a drug acts as a CYP inhibitor, then it causes other drugs to accumulate to toxic levels where overdoses and side effects may occur.

For example, this patient was on warfarin and subsequently started on cimetidine, which is a CYP450 inhibitor. There will be decreased metabolism of warfarin, resulting in increased serum levels and elevated prothrombin time.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated prothrombin time   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Development of a dry, hacking cough   :
Incorrect: Lisinopril, an ACE-inhibitor, is used in the treatment of hypertension. Since the enzyme ACE prevents the breakdown of bradykinin, the use of ACE inhibitors results in bradykinin accumulation, which can cause a dry cough and in rare cases, angioedema. Lisinopril is not significantly metabolized via the CYP450 mechanism.   
❌ Sudden onset left-sided hemiparesis   :
Incorrect: CYP inducers, such as carbamazepine, phenytoin, or griseofulvin, result in rapid metabolism of warfarin, which can lead to subtherapeutic levels. In patients with atrial fibrillation, subtherapeutic warfarin levels can increase the risk of developing atrial thrombus and subsequent embolic stroke. In contrast, cimetidine is a CYP450 enzyme inhibitor and would not cause this complication.   
❌ Elevated partial thromboplastin time   :
Incorrect: Warfarin affects prothrombin time, which is also referred to as international normalized ratio (INR). The medication does not affect partial thromboplastin time.   
❌ Sudden onset pain, pallor, and paresthesia of left lower extremity   :
Incorrect: CYP inducers, such as carbamazepine, phenytoin, or griseofulvin, result in rapid metabolism of warfarin, which can lead to subtherapeutic levels. In patients with atrial fibrillation, subtherapeutic warfarin levels can increase the risk of developing atrial thrombus and subsequent embolic stroke. In contrast, cimetidine is a CYP-450 enzyme inhibitor and would not cause this complication.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man undergoes hemorrhoidectomy under spinal anesthesia. The next day, he begins experiencing worsening lower abdominal discomfort. The patient has not urinated since the procedure. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a palpable bladder 4 cm above the symphysis pubis. Urinary catheterization drains 900 mL of urine from the bladder. The patient is treated with a drug that directly increases detrusor muscle tone. This medication acts by binding to which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
This patient likely received bethanechol, a direct muscarinic agonist commonly given for postoperative urinary retention.

Medications that directly act on muscarinic or nicotinic receptors are called direct cholinomimetics. These medications exert their effect by mimicking acetylcholine, which is the neurotransmitter that normally binds to nicotinic and muscarinic receptors. Examples of such medications include bethanechol, carbachol, methacholine, and pilocarpine.

The effects of each medication in this class differ depending on which muscarinic receptor subtypes it interacts with. The receptor subtypes and their characteristics are detailed in the following table:
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors:
Incorrect: This patient likely received bethanechol, a direct muscarinic agonist commonly given for postoperative or postpartum urinary retention. Bethnecol does not act on nicotinic receptors.  
✅ Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alpha-1 receptors:
Incorrect: Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists help relieve the mechanical obstruction associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia. It achieves this function by relaxing the smooth muscle at the bladder neck and prostatic capsule. It does not act on the detrusor muscle.  
❌ Beta-3 receptors:
Incorrect: Sympathomimetics (e.g., mirabegron) act on the beta-3 receptor, causing relaxation of the detrusor smooth muscle and leading to increased bladder capacity. These medications are used in the management of urinary incontinence, not retention.  
❌ Histamine-2 receptors:
Incorrect: H-2 receptor blockers (e.g. cimetidine) reduce gastric acid secretion and can alleviate gastroesophageal reflux. These medications do not act on the detrusor muscle.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man admitted to the inpatient unit is found to have an acute reduction in urine output over the last 24 hours. He was diagnosed with cryptococcal meningitis one week ago and was initiated on a treatment regimen involving amphotericin B and flucytosine. His medical history includes AIDS and IgA nephropathy. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Mucous membranes appear moist. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below. Which of the following is the target of the pharmacological agent responsible for this patient’s condition?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   135 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.0 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.9 mg/dL 
 Mg  2.0 g/dL 
 BUN  30
questions.solution:
This patient with recent treatment for cryptococcal meningitis, presents with evidence of acute kidney injury, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia consistent with amphotericin B induced nephrotoxicity.   Amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol–a key component of the fungal cell membrane–creating “micropores”, increasing cellular permeability. It is fungicidal at high doses and fungistatic at lower concentrations and clinically indicated in the treatment of invasive aspergillosis, cryptococcal meningitis, invasive candidiasis, blastomycosis, histoplasmosis and leishmaniasis.  

Amphotericin B is available in both conventional and liposomal formulations and is only administered intravenously. Lipid-based formulations are considerably less nephrotoxic and preferred in patients at increased risk of developing acute kidney injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fungal cell membrane :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fungal cell wall :
Incorrect: Echinocandins like caspofungin inhibit beta-glucan synthesis (a component of the fungal cell wall). The most common adverse effects associated with echinocandins include gastrointestinal disturbance. 
❌ Microtubules :
Incorrect: Griseofulvin is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis. It does not adversely affect kidney function or cause electrolyte abnormalities. 
❌ Lanosterol synthesis :
Incorrect: Terbinafine is used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, which is involved in lanosterol synthesis. Terbinafine use can cause gastrointestinal disturbance.
❌ Nucleic acid synthesis :
Incorrect: Flucytosine is an antifungal agent that inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis by converting 5- flucytosine to 5-fluorouracil. Although it is a component of the treatment regimen for cryptococcal meningitis, it does not cause acute kidney injury. Adverse effects encountered with flucytosine use include bone marrow suppression and gastrointestinal disturbance.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy comes to the clinic for a routine annual health check-up. His past medical history includes asthma and allergic rhinitis. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler, a corticosteroid inhaler, and oral corticosteroids. He has not traveled out of the country recently. Family history is noncontributory. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Oral examination reveals white lesions on the tongue and posterior pharynx. These lesions bleed after scraping them with a tongue depressor. An antifungal agent is initiated that binds to ergosterol in fungal cell walls to create micropores. Which of the following is the most likely pharmacological agent used in the treatment of this patient?


Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with oropharyngeal white plaques that bleed when scraped, suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Patients who use corticosteroid inhalers are at increased risk of acquiring an oral candidal infection. Other high-risk groups include immunocompromised patients, those with dentures, infants, and those treated with radiation/chemotherapy to the head/neck.    

Nystatin is a polyene antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane to create micropores, which alters fungal cell permeability and subsequent cell death.    

Oral “swish and swallow” nystatin preparations are used for the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Topical formulations are useful in the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis and for diaper rashes. It can also be used topically for corneal, conjunctival, and cutaneous candidiasis. Adverse effects associated with nystatin use include nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea.  



Option Analysis

❌ Griseofulvin :
Incorrect: Griseofulvin is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of oral candidiasis. 
❌ Ketoconazole :
Incorrect: Ketoconazole is a topically administered azole indicated in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. It targets the fungal cell membrane and blocks lanosterol synthesis.
✅ Nystatin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caspofungin:
Incorrect: Echinocandins like caspofungin inhibit fungal cell wall synthesis. Indications for use include esophageal candidiasis and invasive aspergillosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. 
❌ Amphotericin B :
Incorrect: Amphotericin B does target the fungal cell membrane and create micropores, but it is not the treatment of choice for patients with oropharyngeal candidiasis due to the systemic toxicity associated with its use.

questions.text: During a tumor board meeting, the oncology team is asked to review the clinical therapy for a 63-year-old man who had a recently resected colonic tumor. Gross pathology shows that the tumor was large and nearly completely obstructing the colonic lumen. A recent PET scan conducted on this patient shows distant metastases which have penetrated the liver. The oncology team proposes starting the patient on the FOLFOX chemotherapy regimen. Before initiating therapy, the team proposes using a medication that will prime the patient’s immune system by increasing the immune visibility of the tumor. The patient is treated with cetuximab and is found to have little effect on metastatic tumor populations on imaging. A biopsy of the metastatic liver deposits is taken. A mutation in which of the following receptors is most likely?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a patient with a newly diagnosed stage IV colon cancer with metastases to the liver. Standard treatment for stage IV colon cancers includes either FOLFOX (Folinic acid, Fluorouracil, and Oxaliplatin) or FOLFIRI (Folinic acid, Fluorouracil, irinotecan) chemotherapy regimens. Before starting either of these chemotherapy regimens, it is now common to “prime” the patient’s immune system with targeted monoclonal antibodies, which help the patient’s immune system increase the immune visibility of tumor cells.    

Approximately 60-80% of cancer cells in colorectal tumors overexpress the EGFR receptor. Both  Cetuximab and Panitumumab are monoclonal antibody therapies targeted against the EGFR receptor used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer and some head and neck tumors. Panitumumab is a human monoclonal antibody, whereas Cetuximab is a chimeric mouse monoclonal antibody. Both Cetuximab and Panitumumab have similar side effects, including rash, elevated LFTs, and diarrhea. Neither therapy is more efficacious in the treatment of colorectal cancer. A key difference between the two drugs is the role that cetuximab plays in immunological priming. Cetuximab has been shown to increase ADCC and other immunostimulatory activities such as cell maturation, T-cell recruitment to the tumor, increased antigen presentation, and cytotoxic NK T-cell priming. On the other hand, Panitumumab notably does not engage in cytotoxic NK T-cell priming. It does, however, engage in immune cytotoxicity at a much lower extent via neutrophil-driven ADCC. While it remains to be seen which of these drugs are superior in clinical efficacy, it’s clear that cetuximab has robust effects in modulating immune cytotoxic effects in cancer cells.   

Option Analysis

❌ VEGF:
Incorrect: This patient initially received cetuximab, which targets EGFR. A mutation in EGFR is most likely the cause of the tumor’s non-responsiveness to treatment.
❌ HER2:
Incorrect: Mutations in HER2 occur in breast cancers, not colorectal cancers. 
❌ CD20 :
Incorrect: CD20 is a pan-B-Cell marker useful in diagnosing and treating leukemia. 
❌ KIT:
Incorrect: Mutations in KIT are common in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs)
✅ EGFR:
Correct: See main explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of severe headaches, which are worse in the morning and have been ongoing for the past month. They are 8/10 in severity and throbbing in quality. She has also experienced associated nausea and vomiting. Moreover, her ability to concentrate has declined, and she has experienced word-finding difficulty. Vital signs are within normal limits. Strength and sensation are intact in the upper and lower extremities. An MRI scan of the brain is obtained, which reveals a multicentric, hemorrhagic tumor in the right temporal lobe. She is prescribed an oral glucocorticoid to decrease cerebral edema associated with the mass. Which of the following glucocorticoids has the most prolonged duration of action?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids can be classified according to their duration of action. Of the answer choices listed, dexamethasone has the longest course of action. It can be administered orally, intravenously, or via inhalation. It is often used to treat inflammation, acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis, cerebral edema (as in this clinical vignette), shock, allergic conditions, and multiple myeloma. It is very potent and can cause marked suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. For this reason, it is also used in the dexamethasone suppression test, which assists in diagnosing Cushing syndrome.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hydrocortisone:
Incorrect: Hydrocortisone is a short-acting glucocorticoid that can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. It has the lowest potency among glucocorticoids. It can systemically treat acute adrenal insufficiency and topically treat skin rashes.
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: Prednisone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders.
❌ Prednisolone:
Incorrect: Prednisolone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders. Moreover, since prednisolone is the biologically active form of prednisone, it is often used in patients with liver disease who cannot convert prednisone to prednisolone.
❌ Methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: Methylprednisolone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders.
✅ Dexamethasone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic with voluminous watery diarrhea for the past five days. The patient has been unable to go to work since he has frequent urges to defecate and multiple bowel movements daily. He has also experienced nausea, bloating, and abdominal cramps. There has been no blood in the patient’s stool. He recently returned from a trip to Mexico. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is diagnosed with traveler’s diarrhea caused by Escherichia coli and is started on a three-day course of ciprofloxacin. Which of the following adverse effects is this patient at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient was prescribed ciprofloxacin to treat traveler’s diarrhea caused by Escherichia coli.   

Fluoroquinolones are a class of bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit prokaryotic topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV. They are used in treating infections by Gram-negative rods in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts, Pseudomonas, and some Gram-positive bacteria.    

Fluoroquinolones can cause tendon rupture and tendonitis, especially in individuals over 60 years old or those concurrently taking prednisone. The Achilles tendon is often affected, and patients can develop pain, swelling, or inflammation of the involved tendon. These side effects can develop anytime during treatment and up to six months post-treatment. Given this risk, fluoroquinolones should be avoided in athletes. Should tendon rupture or tendonitis develop, the fluoroquinolone should be discontinued, and the patient is switched to a different antibiotic.    

Moreover, fluoroquinolones are associated with gastrointestinal upset, rashes, headache, and dizziness. They can also cause cartilage damage. As a result, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated for use in pregnant women, nursing mothers, and children under 18 years old. Finally, they can cause QT prolongation, and ciprofloxacin, in particular, can inhibit cytochrome P450.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute cholestatic hepatitis:
Incorrect: This side effect concerns using macrolide antibiotics such as erythromycin. Acute cholestatic hepatitis may present with or without jaundice. It will resolve with medication withdrawal and does not lead to chronic liver disease. Acute cholestatic hepatitis is not associated with the use of fluoroquinolones. 
✅ Tendon rupture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Agranulocytosis:
Incorrect: This side effect is associated with medications such as clozapine, dapsone, and ganciclovir. Complete blood counts should be monitored regularly in patients taking these medications. Agranulocytosis is not associated with fluoroquinolones. 
❌ Drug-induced lupus:
Incorrect: This side effect is a concern with the use of minocycline. It is associated with the development of anti-histone antibodies. Patients with minocycline-induced lupus will present with fever, arthritis, rash, pneumonitis, and vasculitis. In contrast, fluoroquinolones are not associated with drug-induced lupus. 
❌ Interstitial nephritis:
Incorrect: This side effect is associated with using antibiotics such as penicillins, cephalosporins, rifampin, and sulfa drugs. It is not associated with fluoroquinolone use.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician with a fever and sore throat. The patient’s symptoms started two days ago. She was diagnosed with a partial seizure last month and was started on anti-epileptic medication. Temperature is 38°C (100.4 °F), blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and pulse is 89 beats per minute. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following medications is this patient most likely taking?

 Erythrocyte count   5 million (cells/mcL) 
 Hemoglobin   13 (g/dL) 
 Mean corpuscular volume   80 (fL) 
 Leukocyte count   1500 (cells/mm3) 
 Absolute Neutrophil count   80 (cells/mm3) 
 Platelets count   200,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a fever, sore throat, and low absolute neutrophil count, indicative of agranulocytosis. This patient’s agranulocytosis likely resulted from the use of carbamazepine.  Other common side effects of carbamazepine include diplopia, ataxia, and stevens-johnson syndrome. Side effects of associated anti-epileptic medications are listed in the chart detailed below.



Option Analysis

✅ Carbamazepine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lamotrigine :
Incorrect: Lamotrigine’s side-effect profile include Stevens-Johnson syndrome and hemophagocytic  lymphohistiocytosis. Lamotrigine is not associated with agranulocytosis.   
❌ Levetiracetam :
Incorrect: Common side effects of levetiracetam include neuropsychiatric manifestations, headache, and drowsiness. Agranulocytosis is not associated with the use of this medication. 
❌ Gabapentin :
Incorrect: Gabapentin use can lead to sedation and ataxia, but it is not associated with agranulocytosis. 
❌ Vigabatrin :
Incorrect: Vigabatrin’s side effects include permanent vision loss but not agranulocytosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the clinic for evaluation of a chronic cough. The cough is non-productive and associated with dyspnea and fatigue. He denies fever, hemoptysis, or chest pain. His medical history included a hematopoietic stem cell transplant for acute myelogenous leukemia eight months ago. He received busulfan as a part of a conditioning regimen before the transplant. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 90%. There is no lower extremity edema. JVP is 3 cm of H20. Pulmonary examination reveals bibasilar rales. CT of the chest with contrast shows ground glass opacities in lower lung lobes. Pulmonary function testing shows a reduction in the diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the agent responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Induction of free radical formation and DNA damage
Purine analog that inhibits DNA polymerase

questions.solution:
This patient presents symptoms of a non-productive cough, dyspnea, and evidence of ground glass opacities on CT with a history of busulfan use. These findings are consistent with pulmonary fibrosis secondary to busulfan.    

Patients who undergo hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) can experience pulmonary toxicity from various etiologies, including post-transplant infections (e.g. CMV), heart failure, pulmonary thromboembolism, graft versus host disease, secondary malignancy, and antineoplastic therapy.    

Busulfan is primarily used as a myeloablative procedure as part of the conditioning regimen in preparation for an HSCT. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that induces DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links.    

Patients with busulfan toxicity commonly present with a nonproductive cough and progressive dyspnea on exertion. This may accompany a low-grade fever, fatigue, and weight loss. In most cases, patients present with symptoms within one-year post-transplant. A restrictive pulmonary function pattern with a reduced DLCO, interstitial infiltrates, and ground glass opacities on CT scans are common. Other adverse effects caused by busulfan include severe myelosuppression and hyperpigmentation (busulfan tan).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Induction of free radical formation and DNA damage :
Incorrect:  Bleomycin is an antitumor antibiotic that causes DNA damage by inducing free radical damage. Pulmonary fibrosis is one of the known adverse effects of bleomycin. This patient received busulfan. 
❌ Folate antagonist :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that inhibits tetrahydrofolate reductase. Methotrexate can cause lung injury with chronic low-dose therapy. This patient has not received methotrexate. 
✅ Cross-links DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase :
Incorrect: 5- fluorouracil inhibits thymidylate synthase and the conversion of dUMP to dTMP. Adverse effects include myelosuppression, diarrhea, and photosensitivity. 
❌ Purine analog that inhibits DNA polymerase :
Incorrect: Cladribine is a purine analog and an antimetabolite. It is active during the S phase of the cell cycle and inhibits DNA polymerase. Adverse effects include myelosuppression, nephrotoxicity, and neurotoxicity.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency room with incoherent speech. He is accompanied by his spouse, who states the patient has had a headache for two weeks and that he appeared confused this morning. His medical history includes atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and diabetes. His current medications include warfarin, lisinopril, and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. He returned from a trip to India a month ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Extraocular movements are within normal limits. His speech is intangible, but he can pick up a pen and copy a picture of a matchstick when prompted. Axial MRI scan reveals a butterfly-shaped intracranial mass crossing the corpus callosum. Following a biopsy, he is initiated on procarbazine, lomustine, and vincristine regimen. Which of the following adverse effects can be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Progressive dyspnea on exertion, S3 on cardiac examination
Asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction
Bleeding from the gums, fever, and pallor

questions.solution:
This patient presents with expressive motor aphasia, chronic headache, and an MRI revealing a butterfly-shaped intracranial mass crossing the corpus callosum consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.  

Procarbazine is a non-cell, cycle-specific alkylating agent indicated in treating Hodgkin lymphoma, glioblastoma multiforme, and other brain tumors. Its mechanism of action is not well defined. Myelosuppression is the most common, acute, dose-limiting toxicity of this agent. Resultant effects include depression of all cell lineages resulting in pallor secondary to anemia, bacterial infections due to leukopenia, and bleeding from mucous membranes due to thrombocytopenia. Granulocyte stimulating factors such as filgrastim are commonly administered in case of bone marrow suppression. Other adverse effects of procarbazine include pulmonary toxicity and secondary leukemia. Procarbazine has also been shown to induce mild reversible encephalopathy and neuropathy. 

Option Analysis

❌ Progressive dyspnea on exertion, S3 on cardiac examination:
Incorrect: These symptoms indicate a presentation suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. Cardiotoxicity is anticipated with the administration of doxorubicin and daunorubicin.
❌ Asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction:
Incorrect: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody instrumental in treating HER2-positive breast cancers. Reversible cardiotoxicity is a known complication of its use and manifests as a reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction. 
❌ Transaminitis :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can cause hepatotoxicity at all doses. Patients may present with transaminitis or fibrosis. Hepatotoxicity is not associated with procarbazine, vincristine, or lomustine use. 
✅ Bleeding from the gums, fever, and pallor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infertility :
Incorrect: Alkylating agents like cyclophosphamide are known to exert long-term effects on male and female fertility. Women on cyclophosphamide experience premature menopause and infertility, while men may have a reduction in sperm count. Infertility is not a known adverse effect of procarbazine, lomustine, or vincristine.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion. He is accompanied by his spouse, who states that he has appeared confused and lethargic since this morning. Since then, he has had three episodes of vomiting. He has also reported ýellow tinted vision. His medical history includes chronic systolic heart failure and hypertension. His current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, spironolactone, digoxin and metoprolol.  He was hospitalized two days ago for an episode of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, which was treated with metoprolol and an amiodarone drip. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. He consumes 2-3 beers on the weekends. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/85 mmHg. Mucous membranes are moist. Fingerstick glucose is 110 mg/dL. ECG is shown below. Which of the following additional findings would you expect to find in the laboratory evaluation of this patient?
 
 By Jer5150 - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,  Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents gastrointestinal symptoms, vision abnormalities, altered mental status, and a history of digoxin intake. These findings, coupled with recent amiodarone administration, are consistent with acute digoxin toxicity. Medications like amiodarone, verapamil, quinidine, and spironolactone can induce digoxin toxicity by reducing the renal filtration of digoxin.
 

Arrhythmias are the most dangerous manifestation of acute digoxin toxicity. They may include atrial tachycardia with AV block, premature ventricular contractions, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, complete heart block, Mobitz type II heart block, symptomatic bradycardia, and asystole.
 

Electrolyte imbalances often accompany digitalis toxicity as this medication inhibits the sodium potassium channel of cardiac myocytes. Hyperkalemia is the most commonly encountered electrolyte abnormality and is a significant predictor of mortality.

Acute management of digitalis toxicity involves the administration of antibody fragments that bind to and eliminate digoxin. If antibody fragments are not immediately available, atropine or temporary transvenous pacing can be used to treat symptomatic bradycardia.

Due to its vagomimetic actions, digoxin is considered an option for rate control in atrial arrhythmias. However, it is not the first line agent for atrial arrhythmias owing to its low therapeutic window and adverse cardiac effects.  Digoxin is an effective treatment of atrial fibrillation in patients with concomitant heart failure or hypotension due to its added inotropic actions and its negative chronotropic effects.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Hypokalemia is a concern in the setting of chronic digoxin toxicity. Acute digitalis toxicity is more commonly associated with hyperkalemia due to sodium-potassium channel blockade.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia can manifest with neuroglycopenic symptoms (confusion, altered mental status, dizziness) and autonomic symptoms (tremors, palpitations, diaphoresis). Complete heart block is not commonly encountered. Normal fingerstick glucose makes hypoglycemia unlikely.  
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Symptoms of hyponatremia include headache, confusion, malaise, coma, and seizures. Complete heart block, visual abnormalities, and gastrointestinal disturbances indicate digitalis toxicity.  
✅ Hyperkalemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Wide anion metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: A wide anion gap metabolic acidosis is encountered with ethylene glycol, ethanol, and salicylate poisoning. Although these toxidromes can present with gastrointestinal and neurologic disturbances, complete heart block makes digoxin toxicity a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman presents to the office for a routine visit. She is feeling well and is asymptomatic. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus. She takes metformin daily. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and myocardial infarction in the patient’s father—review of systems is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Body mass index is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. A lipid profile is obtained and the results are shown below. The patient is started on simvastatin. Which of the following best describes the effects of simvastatin on serum low-density lipoprotein, high-density lipoprotein, and triglyceride levels?  

Laboratory Value
Results
Total cholesterol
325 mg/dL
Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)
195 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
35 mg/dL
Triglyceride (TG)
100 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient’s lipid profile exhibits elevated serum cholesterol and LDL levels. Statins, a class of lipid-lowering drugs, are the first-line agent in such cases since they significantly decrease LDL levels, increase HDL levels, and improve cardiovascular mortality.

Statins competitively inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which normally converts HMG-CoA to mevalonate (a cholesterol precursor). In turn, there is a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and an increase in LDL recycling via the up-regulation of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. The LDL receptors not only increase the uptake of LDL-cholesterol but also increase the uptake of VLDLs (the major carrier of TG) to a smaller extent, resulting in a moderate decrease in triglyceride levels. Furthermore, the liver increases its production of HDLs, which carry cholesterol back from the peripheral tissues to the liver.

The net effect is a significant reduction in LDL levels, a modest decrease in TG levels, and a modest increase in HDL levels.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) tend to decrease LDL cholesterol by preventing bile acid reabsorption in the intestine. Bile acid resins also slightly increase HDL and triglyceride levels. In contrast, this patient was prescribed a statin.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These changes are observed with fish oil and marine omega-3 fatty acids. Such medications decrease the transport of free fatty acids to the liver and inhibit the activity of TG-synthesizing enzymes. They also slightly increase LDL levels. In contrast, this patient was prescribed a statin.   
❌ :
Incorrect: A major reduction in TG is seen with the use of fibrates. Fibrates act by upregulating lipoprotein lipase, increasing the clearance of serum triglycerides. This class of medication also activates PPAR-α to induce HDL synthesis.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient was started on a statin. Statins increase, as opposed to decrease, serum HDL levels.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician for a routine follow-up six weeks after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient has no active complaints at this visit but would like to discuss contraception. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. After discussing the risks and benefits of multiple contraceptive options, the patient elects to start depot medroxyprogesterone. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Depot medroxyprogesterone is an injectable, progestin-only contraceptive that provides highly effective, reversible contraception for three months. It causes menstrual irregularities such as prolonged bleeding or spotting, especially during the first six months of use. Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestogen called progestin.  Progestins can be divided into two groups: the progesterone derivatives and the testosterone derivatives.

Progestins suppress ovulation by inhibiting the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone from the hypothalamus, induce atrophic changes in the endometrium, and thicken the cervical mucus. While they can stabilize the endometrium, they can’t support pregnancy effectively as endogenous progesterone does.

Common indications include:
 
  • Contraception, either alone or in combination with an estrogen 
  • Used in combination with estrogen in hormone replacement therapy after menopause in women with an intact uterus to prevent endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer 
  • Diagnosis and treatment of various gynecological conditions such as secondary amenorrhea, abnormal uterine bleeding, and endometriosis. 
Side effects associated with progestins include fatigue, mood changes, menstrual irregularities, edema, vaginal dryness or atrophy, headaches, nausea, breast tenderness, and decreased libido. Progestins with androgenic activity can also cause acne, hirsutism, seborrhea, voice deepening, changes in liver protein production, and weight gain.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Menstrual irregularities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type 2 diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Although estrogen oral contraceptive pills have shown to increase the risk of glucose intolerance, progestins have not been linked to the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Breast cancer:
Incorrect: The data for progestin-only contraceptives are inadequate to make a definitive conclusion regarding the risk of breast cancer.  
❌ Endometrial hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Progestins reverse endometrial hyperplasia via activation of progesterone receptors, which results in stromal decidualization and subsequent thinning of the endometrium. It is used to prevent endometrial hyperplasia and cancer by mitigating the effect of estrogen on the endometrium.  
❌ Migraine headaches:
Incorrect: Estrogen therapy often improves both symptoms for women with hot flashes and estrogen-associated migraines (which typically worsen during perimenopause). Migraine headaches (with or without aura) are not a complication of progestin therapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up of hypertension. The patient has had elevated blood pressure measurements on several occasions. The patient feels well and does not report any symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in the patient’s father. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/98 mmHg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on a drug that acts on the segment of the nephron labeled “A” below. Which of the following best describes the normal function of this segment of nephron?

choices.text: Major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption
Pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney
Reabsorbs calcium under the control of parathyroid hormone
Primary site of acidification of the urine and is controlled by aldosterone
Passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium

questions.solution:
The segment of the nephron labeled A is the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). It is affected by thiazide diuretics (e.g. hydrochlorothiazide). This segment of the nephron reabsorbs sodium and chloride via the Na+/Cl– carrier on the apical surface of the tubule and is responsible for 5% of filtered sodium reabsorption. The cotransporter moves Na+ in the direction of its concentration gradient and uses that energy to move a chloride against its concentration gradient. Once inside, chloride leaves via Cl- channels on the basolateral surface into the interstitium, down its concentration gradient. It is impermeable to H2O and makes urine fully dilute (hypotonic).

There are also Ca++ channels on the apical surface and Na+/Ca++ channels on the basolateral surface of the tubule cells. Ca++ ions can diffuse across the apical surface into the tubule cells, down their concentration gradient, and then move across the basolateral surface into the interstitium against their concentration gradient as 1 Na+ moves from the interstitium into the tubule cells. Calcium reabsorption is regulated by the parathyroid hormone (PTH). Moreover, the Na+/K+ ATPase on the basolateral surface keeps the intracellular Na+ level low, and that allows more Na+ to flow into the tubule, down its concentration gradient on the basolateral surface through the Na+/Ca++ channels, and on the apical surface through the Na+/Cl- cotransporter.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption :
Incorrect: The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) carries out isosmotic reabsorption of amino acids, glucose, and numerous ions. It is the major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption. The proximal tubule is responsible for 60–70% of the total reabsorption of sodium. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
❌ Pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney :
Incorrect: The thick ascending loop of Henle has a Na-K-2Cl symporter which pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
✅ Reabsorbs calcium under the control of parathyroid hormone :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Primary site of acidification of the urine and is controlled by aldosterone :
Incorrect: The collecting duct is the final segment of the nephron and is the last tubular site of sodium reabsorption that is controlled by aldosterone. It is also the primary site of acidification of the urine and the last site of potassium excretion. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
❌ Passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium :
Incorrect: The descending limb of loop of Henle passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of balance issues, headache, and nausea for the past 4 days. The patient endorses a sensation of objects moving around him. The patient was diagnosed with infective endocarditis one week ago and has been receiving penicillin G and gentamicin. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, heart failure, and hypertension. Other medications include furosemide, metformin, atorvastatin, aspirin, and metoprolol. Vitals are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination is normal. Air conduction is better than bone conduction with Renne testing, and sound is heard better in the left ear with Weber testing. Rapid movement of the head away from a fixed target induces a horizontal eye saccade with redirection towards the target. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient receiving gentamicin for the treatment of infective endocarditis presents with new-onset hearing loss, imbalance, and sensations of objects moving around him (oscillopsia). This presentation is consistent with aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicity likely exacerbated by coadministration with furosemide (another ototoxic drug). Other risk factors for aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicity include bacteremia, as well as hepatic, or renal impairment.

Irreversible vestibular and auditory dysfunction can follow aminoglycoside administration. Presentation varies and includes clinical features such as:

  •  High-pitched tinnitus (usually the first symptom of cochlear toxicity)  
  •  Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and loss of high-frequency range (outside the conversational range)  
  •  Imbalance and oscillopsia   
  •  A positive head thrust test (impaired vestibulo-ocular reflex)  

Management of aminoglycoside-induced vestibular toxicity includes immediate discontinuation of the offending medication. Associated renal toxicity is typically reversible and presents in the form of acute tubular necrosis (ATN). It is common in elderly patients receiving aminoglycosides as well as in those concurrently receiving amphotericin B, cephalosporins, or vancomycin.

Option Analysis

❌ Meniere disease :
Incorrect: Meniere disease is caused by increased endolymphatic volume/pressure in the labyrinthine system. It presents with a triad of episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. Acute onset of vestibular dysfunction, rather than episodic dysfunction, makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
✅ Medication-induced ototoxicity :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cholesteatoma :
Incorrect: Cholesteatomas are erosive expansile masses of squamous cell debris in the middle ear visible on the otoscopy. This condition typically presents with recurrent otorrhea and asymmetric conductive hearing loss (bone conduction> air conduction in the affected ear). 
❌ Otosclerosis :
Incorrect: Otosclerosis results from ossification of the ossicles and presents with conductive hearing loss (bone conduction> air conduction) rather than sensorineural hearing loss. 
❌ Presbycusis :
Incorrect: Presbycusis is common in the elderly (age > 75 years) and presents with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because of bilateral leg swelling and increased abdominal girth. The symptoms started around 2-weeks ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for liver cirrhosis that has been well-managed with furosemide for the past 4-years. The patient has also taken over-the-counter ibuprofen for the past few weeks due to back strain. The patient has not made any changes to dietary sodium or fluid intake. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 144/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral +2 pitting edema and moderate ascites. Laboratory evaluations reveal decreased fractional excretion of sodium. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of liver cirrhosis well-managed with furosemide developed worsening lower extremity edema and ascites over the past 2-weeks. These symptoms are likely due to recent ibuprofen use.       

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Loop diuretics also increase the synthesis of prostaglandin in the afferent renal arterioles to increase renal blood flow (RBF), glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and NaCl excretion via the urine.        

In healthy patients, NSAIDs (e.g. ibuprofen) have minimal effect on renal perfusion due to low prostaglandin synthesis. However, in patients with intravascular volume depletion (e.g., cirrhosis, dehydration), the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis by NSAIDs results in a markedly decreased RBF and GFR. These effects result in reduced delivery of fluids and electrolytes to the renal tubule, thereby causing water and salt retention as well as symptoms of volume overload in susceptible patients.    

Option Analysis

❌ Insufficient dose of furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient’s condition has been well-managed with furosemide for the past 4 years. The deterioration of his condition is most likely a result of reduced renal blood flow and glomerular filtration secondary to recent ibuprofen use. 
✅ Use of ibuprofen for pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Incompetent venous valves:
Incorrect: Varicose veins are dilated, tortuous, subcutaneous veins that result from incompetent venous valves in the lower extremity. No such veins were identified on physical examination. In contrast, the progressively worsening lower extremity edema and ascites in this patient is more suggestive of fluid retention secondary to NSAID administration. 
❌ Occlusion of the hepatic veins:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome results from occlusion of the hepatic veins. Although it can present with abdominal ascites and lower extremity edema, patients typically also have abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and jaundice. The deterioration of this patient’s condition is more likely due to reduced renal blood flow and glomerular filtration secondary to ibuprofen intake. 
❌ Thrombosis of the deep veins :
Incorrect: Deep vein thrombosis usually presents with unilateral lower extremity pain, erythema, and tenderness. It does not present with ascites or bilateral lower extremity edema.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office for a routine follow-up. He does not have any active complaints at this visit. The patient last visited the emergency department five months ago to evaluate a skin rash and difficulty breathing following the ingestion of furosemide for hypertension. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily and does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. His home glucose measurement review shows his postprandial glucose levels are frequently elevated. Laboratory testing reveals hemoglobin HbA1c is 7.5%. A decision to add a hypoglycemic drug acts on pancreatic beta cells' K-ATP channel to release insulin at all blood glucose levels. Which of the following best describes the drug added to this patient’s medication regimen?
questions.solution:
This patient with inadequate glycemic control on metformin is most likely started on a meglitinide, a non-sulfonylurea insulin secretagogue. It binds to a different site on pancreatic beta cells than sulfonylurea. Still, it results in a similar effect, i.e., inhibition of potassium ATP channels in the pancreatic beta cells, leading to depolarization and calcium influx, with subsequent insulin release in the blood at all glucose levels.  



They have a rapid onset and shorter duration of action (approximately one hour) compared to sulfonylureas and are usually administered with meals to manage postprandial glucose levels. Common examples include repaglinide and nateglinide. As they are structurally different from sulfonylureas, this class of drugs can be used in patients with known sulfa allergies (such as this patient). Side effects include hypoglycemia and weight gain but are less severe than sulfonylureas. 

Option Analysis

❌ Glucagon-like peptide-1 agonist :
Incorrect: Glucagon-like peptide-1 agonist (e.g. exenatide) binds GLP-1 receptors and stimulates glucose-dependent insulin release from the pancreatic islets. It does not affect the K-ATP channel and only causes insulin release in response to elevated blood glucose levels. 
❌ Dipeptidyl peptidase four inhibitors :
Incorrect: Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4) inhibitors (e.g. sitagliptin) inhibit DPP-4, an enzyme that deactivates glucagon-like peptide 1. Its inhibition results in the same effect as that of GLP-1 analogs, i.e. increased glucose-induced insulin release. Although it is used to manage postprandial blood glucose levels, it does not directly inhibit the K-ATP channel on pancreatic beta cells. 
❌ Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor :
Incorrect: Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor (e.g. canagliflozin) acts on the renal tubule to prevent the reabsorption of glucose. Although it manages postprandial blood glucose levels, it does not affect insulin production by pancreatic beta cells. 
✅ Meglitinide :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thiazolidinediones :
Incorrect: Thiazolidinediones (e.g. pioglitazone) are synthetic ligands that bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma receptors leading to increased insulin sensitivity (not release) by upregulating the transcription of insulin-responsive genes in peripheral tissues (e.g., adipose tissue, skeletal muscles, and liver).

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office because of progressive exertional dyspnea. The patient has had dyspnea over the past year that has progressively worsened in the last two months, making it difficult to walk the half a block to the local convenience store without having to rest. The patient has not had a cough, fever, or leg swelling. Past medical history is unremarkable and the patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 23 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals a loud S2 at the left upper sternal border. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Chest x-ray is normal. ECG shows right axis deviation. Echocardiography reveals right ventricular dilation with increased wall thickness and peak tricuspid regurgitant velocity of 3.5 m/s. After further work-up, the physician decides to start the patient on selexipag. This medication is most likely to help this patient via which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Increasing cAMP-mediated bronchial smooth muscle relaxation

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with progressive exertional dyspnea and right axis deviation on ECG, in combination with echocardiographic findings of right ventricular dilation with increased wall thickness and peak tricuspid regurgitant velocity of 3.5 m/s are virtually diagnostic of pulmonary hypertension. After ruling out secondary causes with further workup, diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is made and the patient is started on selexipag.       

Selexipag, epoprostenol, treprostinil, beraprost, and inhaled iloprost are analogues of prostacyclin, an endogenous product of arachidonic acid metabolism in the vascular endothelium that is known to cause pulmonary vasodilation. These are the approved medications for the treatment of PAH. They are shown to inhibit smooth muscle proliferation and platelet aggregation by the stimulation of intracellular cAMP. Selexipag and treprostinil are available in oral formulations, while epoprostenol is intravenous medication that is reserved for severe PAH.       

Besides PAH, prostacyclin analogs are sometimes indicated in patients with right heart failure. Common side effects include thrombocytopenia and bleeding, jaw pain, leg pain, flushing, headache, nausea, and vomiting.   

Option Analysis

❌ Decreasing airway inflammation :
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin E (IgE) binding monoclonal antibodies (e.g. omalizumab), decrease airway inflammation and are effective in the treatment of asthma that is unresponsive to other medications. They have no role in the management of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). 
❌ Increasing cAMP-mediated bronchial smooth muscle relaxation :
Incorrect: Beta-2 receptor agonists act by increasing cAMP-mediated bronchial smooth muscle relaxation and are effective in treating asthma. They have no role in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). 
❌ Decreasing airway collagen deposition :
Incorrect: Decreasing airway collagen deposition by tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g. imatinib) is effective to slow the progression of pulmonary fibrosis. It plays no role in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). 
✅ Increasing pulmonary vasodilation :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Decreasing alveolar destruction :
Incorrect: Alveolar destruction can be decreased in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) by smoking cessation. It plays no role in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate bloating and flatulence for the past two months.  His symptoms do not impair his routine daily functioning, but they leave him with a sense of constant discomfort. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He has been taking metformin and lisinopril for two years. He states that a new medication was added to his regimen two months ago to help control his post-meal blood glucose levels. He drinks 2-3 beers on weekends. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild generalized abdominal discomfort. His HbA1c obtained two months ago was 7.9%. The medication causing this patient’s symptoms works by targeting which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bloating and flatulence following the initiation of a hypoglycemic medication to control postprandial blood glucose levels, most likely due to alpha-glucosidase inhibitor (e.g., acarbose and miglitol).        

Alpha-glucosidase is an enzyme found in the intestinal brush border that breaks down complex carbohydrates into monosaccharide units (e.g. glucose). Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors prevent this process by delaying the breakdown of carbohydrates, ultimately lowering postprandial blood glucose levels.        

Intestinal bacteria subsequently digest undigested carbohydrates, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms including bloating and diarrhea. They are uncommonly used in combination with oral hypoglycemic drugs or insulin; however, they can be considered if monotherapy fails to achieve target HbA1c and post-prandial blood glucose levels.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Intracellular nuclear receptor :
Incorrect: Thiazolidinediones (e.g., rosiglitazone and pioglitazone) bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPAR)-ɣ (an intracellular nuclear receptor), which results in increased insulin sensitivity. Significant side effects include weight gain and edema.  
✅ Surface membrane-bound enzymes :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intracellular mitochondrial enzymes :
Incorrect: Metformin inhibits intracellular mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD), leading to the inhibition of gluconeogenesis by blocking pyruvate carboxylase, the first step of gluconeogenesis. While metformin can cause GI upset, this patient has been on metformin for two years and is unlikely to contribute to new symptoms.  
❌ Membrane ion channels :
Incorrect: Sulfonylureas are insulin secretagogues that inhibit the K-ion channel on pancreatic beta-cell membranes. Common side effects include weight gain and hypoglycemia.  
❌ Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) :
Incorrect: Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor in the renal tubular cells, preventing glucose reabsorption. It is rarely used as a second-line agent due to its high cost, modest improvement in glycemic control, and absence of long-term safety data. Gastrointestinal side effects include increased incidence of vulvovaginal candidiasis and bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man with type II diabetes mellitus comes to the office for a routine follow-up. He was diagnosed with diabetes three years ago and was initially advised regarding lifestyle modifications and metformin. Glyburide was added to his regimen three months ago due to persistently elevated blood glucose levels. Vital signs are within normal limits. BMI is 34 kg/m2. Laboratory investigation shows fasting blood glucose of 175 mg/dL and HbA1c of 8.9%. The patient is reluctant to take insulin or other injectable antidiabetic drugs. The physician decides to initiate a medication that blocks glucose reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules. Initiation of this new medication will increase the risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
